verses.textLa: Et facta est habitatio eorum de Messa pergentibus usque Sephar montem orientalem.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of Shem according to their kindred, and tongues, and the regions within their nations.
verses.textLa: Isti filii Sem secundum cognationes et linguas, et regiones in gentibus suis.

verses.textEn: These are the families of Noah, according to their peoples and nations. The nations became divided according to these, on the earth after the great flood.
verses.textLa: Hæ familiæ Noe iuxta populos et nationes suas. Ab his divisæ sunt gentes in terra post diluvium.

verses.textEn: Now the earth was of one language and of the same speech.
verses.textLa: Erat autem terra labii unius, et sermonum eorumdem.

verses.textEn: And when they were advancing from the east, they found a plain in the land of Shinar, and they dwelt in it.
verses.textLa: Cumque proficiscerentur de oriente, invenerunt campum in terra Senaar, et habitaverunt in eo.

verses.textEn: And each one said to his neighbor, “Come, let us make bricks, and bake them with fire.” And they had bricks instead of stones, and pitch instead of mortar.
verses.textLa: Dixitque alter ad proximum suum: Venite, faciamus lateres, et coquamus eos igni. Habueruntque lateres pro saxis, et bitumen pro cæmento:

verses.textEn: And they said: “Come, let us make a city and a tower, so that its height may reach to heaven. And let us make our name famous before we are divided into all the lands.”
verses.textLa: et dixerunt: Venite, faciamus nobis civitatem et turrim, cuius culmen pertingat ad cælum: et celebremus nomen nostrum antequam dividamur in universas terras.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord descended to see the city and the tower, which the sons of Adam were building.
verses.textLa: Descendit autem Dominus ut videret civitatem et turrim, quam ædificabant filii Adam,

verses.textEn: And he said: “Behold, the people are united, and all have one tongue. And since they have begun to do this, they will not desist from their plans, until they have completed their work.
verses.textLa: et dixit: Ecce, unus est populus, et unum labium omnibus: cœperuntque hoc facere, nec desistent a cogitationibus suis, donec eas opere compleant.

verses.textEn: Therefore, come, let us descend, and in that place confound their tongue, so that they may not listen, each one to the voice of his neighbor.”
verses.textLa: Venite igitur, descendamus, et confundamus ibi linguam eorum, ut non audiat unusquisque vocem proximi sui.

verses.textEn: And so the Lord divided them from that place into all the lands, and they ceased to build the city.
verses.textLa: Atque ita divisit eos Dominus ex illo loco in universas terras, et cessaverunt ædificare civitatem.

verses.textEn: And for this reason, its name was called ‘Babel,’ because in that place the language of the whole earth became confused. And from then on, the Lord scattered them across the face of every region.
verses.textLa: Et idcirco vocatum est nomen eius Babel, quia ibi confusum est labium universæ terræ: et inde dispersit eos Dominus super faciem cunctarum regionum.

verses.textEn: These are the generations of Shem. Shem was one hundred years old when he conceived Arphaxad, two years after the great flood.
verses.textLa: Hæ sunt generationes Sem: Sem erat centum annorum quando genuit Arphaxad, biennio post diluvium.

verses.textEn: And after he conceived Arphaxad, Shem lived for five hundred years, and he conceived sons and daughters.
verses.textLa: Vixitque Sem postquam genuit Arphaxad, quingentis annis: et genuit filios et filias.

verses.textEn: Next, Arphaxad lived for thirty-five years, and then he conceived Shelah.
verses.textLa: Porro Arphaxad vixit triginta quinque annis, et genuit Sale.

verses.textEn: And after he conceived Shelah, Arphaxad lived for three hundred and three years, and he conceived sons and daughters.
verses.textLa: Vixitque Arphaxad postquam genuit Sale, trecentis tribus annis: et genuit filios et filias.

verses.textEn: Likewise, Shelah lived for thirty years, and then he conceived Eber.
verses.textLa: Sale quoque vixit triginta annis, et genuit Heber.

verses.textEn: And after he conceived Eber, Shelah lived for four hundred and three years, and he conceived sons and daughters.
verses.textLa: Vixitque Sale postquam genuit Heber, quadringentis tribus annis: et genuit filios et filias.

verses.textEn: Then Eber lived for thirty-four years, and he conceived Peleg.
verses.textLa: Vixit autem Heber triginta quatuor annis, et genuit Phaleg.

verses.textEn: And after he conceived Peleg, Eber lived for four hundred and thirty years, and he conceived sons and daughters.
verses.textLa: Et vixit Heber postquam genuit Phaleg, quadringentis triginta annis: et genuit filios et filias.

verses.textEn: Likewise, Peleg lived for thirty years, and then he conceived Reu.
verses.textLa: Vixit quoque Phaleg triginta annis, et genuit Reu.

verses.textEn: And after he conceived Reu, Peleg lived for two hundred and nine years, and he conceived sons and daughters.
verses.textLa: Vixitque Phaleg postquam genuit Reu, ducentis novem annis, et genuit filios et filias.

verses.textEn: Then Reu lived for thirty-two years, and then he conceived Serug.
verses.textLa: Vixit autem Reu triginta duobus annis, et genuit Sarug.

verses.textEn: Likewise, after he conceived Serug, Reu lived for two hundred and seven years, and he conceived sons and daughters.
verses.textLa: Vixit quoque Reu postquam genuit Sarug, ducentis septem annis: et genuit filios et filias.

verses.textEn: In truth, Serug lived for thirty years, and then he conceived Nahor.
verses.textLa: Vixit vero Sarug triginta annis, et genuit Nachor.

verses.textEn: And after he conceived Nahor, Serug lived for two hundred years, and he conceived sons and daughters.
verses.textLa: Vixitque Sarug postquam genuit Nachor, ducentis annis: et genuit filios et filias.

verses.textEn: And so Nahor lived for twenty-nine years, and then he conceived Terah.
verses.textLa: Vixit autem Nachor viginti novem annis, et genuit Thare.

verses.textEn: And after he conceived Terah, Nahor lived for one hundred and nineteen years, and he conceived sons and daughters.
verses.textLa: Vixitque Nachor postquam genuit Thare, centum decem et novem annis: et genuit filios et filias.

verses.textEn: And Terah lived for seventy years, and then he conceived Abram, and Nahor, and Haran.
verses.textLa: Vixitque Thare septuaginta annis, et genuit Abram et Nachor, et Aran.

verses.textEn: And these are the generations of Terah. Terah conceived Abram, Nahor, and Haran. Next Haran conceived Lot.
verses.textLa: Hæ sunt autem generationes Thare: Thare genuit Abram, Nachor, et Aran. Porro Aran genuit Lot.

verses.textEn: And Haran died before his father Terah, in the land of his nativity, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
verses.textLa: Mortuusque est Aran ante Thare patrem suum, in terra nativitatis suæ in Ur Chaldæorum.

verses.textEn: Then Abram and Nahor took wives. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai. And the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah, and the father of Iscah.
verses.textLa: Duxerunt autem Abram et Nachor uxores: nomen uxoris Abram, Sarai: et nomen uxoris Nachor, Melcha filia Aran patris Melchæ, et patris Ieschæ.
verses.notes: This Haran might not be the same as the brother of Nachor. This Haran is the father of Milcah and Iscah, whereas the other Haran is the father of Lot. This also explains the redundancy of saying that Milcah is Haran’s daughter, and then saying that Haran is the father of Milcah and Iscah.

verses.textEn: But Sarai was barren and had no children.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Sarai sterilis, nec habebat liberos.

verses.textEn: And so Terah took his son Abram, and his grandson Lot, the son of Haran, and his daughter-in-law Sarai, the wife of his son Abram, and he led them away from Ur of the Chaldeans, to go into the land of Canaan. And they approached as far as Haran, and they dwelt there.
verses.textLa: Tulit itaque Thare Abram filium suum, et Lot filium Aran, filium filii sui, et Sarai nurum suam, uxorem Abram filii sui, et eduxit eos de Ur Chaldæorum, ut irent in terram Chanaan: veneruntque usque Haran, et habitaverunt ibi.

verses.textEn: And the days of Terah that passed were two hundred and five years, and then he died in Haran.
verses.textLa: Et facti sunt dies Thare ducentorum quinque annorum, et mortuus est in Haran.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to Abram: “Depart from your land, and from your kindred, and from your father’s house, and come into the land that I will show you.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus ad Abram: Egredere de terra tua, et de cognatione tua, et de domo patris tui, et veni in terram, quam monstrabo tibi.

verses.textEn: And I will make of you a great nation, and I will bless you and magnify your name, and you will be blessed.
verses.textLa: Faciamque te in gentem magnam, et benedicam tibi, et magnificabo nomen tuum, erisque benedictus.

verses.textEn: I will bless those who bless you, and curse those who curse you, and in you all the families of the earth will be blessed.”
verses.textLa: Benedicam benedicentibus tibi, et maledicam maledicentibus tibi, atque IN TE benedicentur universæ cognationes terræ.

verses.textEn: And so Abram departed just as the Lord had instructed him, and Lot went with him. Abram was seventy-five years old when he departed from Haran.
verses.textLa: Egressus est itaque Abram sicut præceperat ei Dominus, et ivit cum eo Lot: septuaginta quinque annorum erat Abram cum egrederetur de Haran.

verses.textEn: And he took his wife Sarai, and Lot, the son of his brother, and all the substance which they had come to possess, and the lives which they had acquired in Haran, and they departed in order to go to the land of Canaan. And when they arrived in it,
verses.textLa: Tulitque Sarai uxorem suam, et Lot filium fratris sui, universamque substantiam quam possederant, et animas quas fecerant in Haran: et egressi sunt ut irent in terram Chanaan. Cumque venissent in eam,

verses.textEn: Abram passed through the land even to the place of Shechem, as far as the famous steep valley. Now at that time, the Canaanite was in the land.
verses.textLa: pertransivit Abram terram usque ad locum Sichem, usque ad convallem illustrem: Chananæus autem tunc erat in terra.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord appeared to Abram, and he said to him, “To your offspring, I will give this land.” And there he built an altar to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
verses.textLa: Apparuit autem Dominus Abram, et dixit ei: Semini tuo dabo terram hanc. Qui ædificavit ibi altare Domino, qui apparuerat ei.

verses.textEn: And passing on from there to a mountain, which was opposite the east of Bethel, he pitched his tent there, having Bethel to the west, and Hai on the east. He also built an altar there to the Lord, and he called upon his name.
verses.textLa: Et inde transgrediens ad montem, qui erat contra orientem Bethel, tetendit ibi tabernaculum suum, ab occidente habens Bethel, et ab oriente Hai: ædificavit quoque ibi altare Domino, et invocavit nomen eius.

verses.textEn: And Abram traveled, going out and continuing further on, toward the south.
verses.textLa: Perrexitque Abram vadens, et ultra progrediens ad meridiem.

verses.textEn: But a famine occurred in the land. And Abram descended to Egypt, to sojourn there. For famine prevailed over the land.
verses.textLa: Facta est autem fames in terra: descenditque Abram in Ægyptum, ut peregrinaretur ibi: prævaluerat enim fames in terra.
verses.notes: People went to Egypt during a famine. For famines were often caused by droughts. Israel and the surrounding regions have little rain even in a year of average rainfall. When there is a drought, they cannot grow crops without rain. And many of their smaller rivers or streams would dry up completely during a drought. But even during a severe drought, the river Nile never went dry. So Egypt could always grow food.

verses.textEn: And when he was close to entering Egypt, he said to his wife Sarai: “I know you to be a beautiful woman.
verses.textLa: Cumque prope esset ut ingrederetur Ægyptum, dixit Sarai uxori suæ: Novi quod pulchra sis mulier:

verses.textEn: And when the Egyptians see you, they will say, ‘She is his wife.’ And they will put me to death, and retain you.
verses.textLa: et quod cum viderint te Ægyptii, dicturi sunt: Uxor ipsius est: et interficient me, et te reservabunt.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I beg you to say that you are my sister, so that it may be well with me because of you, and so that my soul may live by your favor.”
verses.textLa: Dic ergo, obsecro te, quod soror mea sis: ut bene sit mihi propter te, et vivat anima mea ob gratiam tui.

verses.textEn: And so, when Abram had arrived in Egypt, the Egyptians saw that the woman was exceedingly beautiful.
verses.textLa: Cum itaque ingressus esset Abram Ægyptum, viderunt Ægyptii mulierem quod esset pulchra nimis.

verses.textEn: And the princes reported it to Pharaoh, and they praised her to him. And the woman was inducted into the house of Pharaoh.
verses.textLa: Et nunciaverunt principes Pharaoni, et laudaverunt eam apud illum: et sublata est mulier in domum Pharaonis.

verses.textEn: In truth, they treated Abram well because of her. And he had sheep and oxen and male donkeys, and men servants, and women servants, and female donkeys, and camels.
verses.textLa: Abram vero bene usi sunt propter illam: Fueruntque ei oves et boves, et asini, et servi et famulæ, et asinæ et cameli.

verses.textEn: But the Lord scourged Pharaoh and his house with great wounds because of Sarai, the wife of Abram.
verses.textLa: Flagellavit autem Dominus Pharaonem plagis maximis, et domum eius propter Sarai uxorem Abram.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh called Abram, and he said to him: “What is this that you have done to me? Why did you not tell me she was your wife?
verses.textLa: Vocavitque Pharao Abram, et dixit ei: Quidnam est hoc quod fecisti mihi? Quare non indicasti quod uxor tua esset?

verses.textEn: For what reason did you claim her to be your sister, so that I would take her to me as a wife? Now therefore, behold your mate, receive her and go.”
verses.textLa: Quam ob causam dixisti esse sororem tuam, ut tollerem eam mihi in uxorem? Nunc igitur ecce coniux tua, accipe eam, et vade.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh instructed his men about Abram. And they led him away with his wife and all that he had.
verses.textLa: Præcepitque Pharao super Abram viris: et deduxerunt eum, et uxorem illius, et omnia quæ habebat.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Abram ascended from Egypt, he and his wife, and all that he had, and Lot with him, toward the southern region.
verses.textLa: Ascendit ergo Abram de Ægypto, ipse et uxor eius, et omnia quæ habebat, et Lot cum eo ad australem plagam.
verses.notes: Abram went south from Egypt, therefore, he was further south in Africa. The term Meridian, in Daniel and in this passage from Genesis, refers to Africa at or near the Equator.

verses.textEn: But he was very wealthy by the possession of gold and silver.
verses.textLa: Erat autem dives valde in possessione auri et argenti.

verses.textEn: And he returned by the way that he came, from the meridian into Bethel, all the way to the place where before he had pitched his tent, between Bethel and Hai.
verses.textLa: Reversusque est per iter, quo venerat, a meridie in Bethel usque ad locum ubi prius fixerat tabernaculum inter Bethel et Hai:

verses.textEn: There, at the place of the altar he had made before, he again called upon the name of the Lord.
verses.textLa: in loco altaris quod fecerat prius, et invocavit ibi nomen Domini.

verses.textEn: But Lot also, who was with Abram, had flocks of sheep, and cattle, and tents.
verses.textLa: Sed et Lot qui erat cum Abram, fuerunt greges ovium, et armenta, et tabernacula.

verses.textEn: Neither was the land able to contain them, so that they might dwell together. Indeed, their substance was so great that they could not live in common.
verses.textLa: Nec poterat eos capere terra, ut habitarent simul: erat quippe substantia eorum multa, et nequibant habitare communiter.

verses.textEn: And then there also arose a conflict between the shepherds of Abram and of Lot. Now at that time the Canaanite and the Perizzite lived in that land.
verses.textLa: Unde et facta est rixa inter pastores gregum Abram et Lot. Eo autem tempore Chananæus et Pherezæus habitabant in terra illa.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Abram said to Lot: “I ask you, let there be no quarrel between me and you, and between my shepherds and your shepherds. For we are brothers.
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Abram ad Lot: Ne quæso sit iurgium inter me et te, et inter pastores meos, et pastores tuos: fratres enim sumus.

verses.textEn: Behold, the entire land is before your eyes. Withdraw from me, I beg you. If you will go to the left, I will take the right. If you choose the right, I will pass to the left.”
verses.textLa: Ecce universa terra coram te est: recede a me, obsecro: si ad sinistram ieris, ego dexteram tenebo: si tu dexteram elegeris, ego ad sinistram pergam.

verses.textEn: And so Lot, lifting up his eyes, saw all the region around the Jordan, which was thoroughly irrigated, before the Lord overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah. It was like the Paradise of the Lord, and it was like Egypt, approaching toward Zoar.
verses.textLa: Elevatis itaque Lot oculis, vidit omnem circa regionem Iordanis, quæ universa irrigabatur antequam subverteret Dominus Sodomam et Gomorrham, sicut Paradisus Domini, et sicut Ægyptus venientibus in Segor.

verses.textEn: And Lot chose for himself the region around the Jordan, and he withdrew by way of the east. And they were divided, one brother from the other.
verses.textLa: Elegitque sibi Lot regionem circa Iordanem, et recessit ab Oriente: divisique sunt alterutrum a fratre suo.

verses.textEn: Abram dwelt in the land of Canaan. In truth, Lot stayed in the towns that were around the Jordan, and he lived in Sodom.
verses.textLa: Abram habitavit in terra Chanaan: Lot vero moratus est in oppidis, quæ erant circa Iordanem, et habitavit in Sodomis.

verses.textEn: But the men of Sodom were very wicked, and they were sinners before the Lord beyond measure.
verses.textLa: Homines autem Sodomitæ pessimi erant, et peccatores coram Domino nimis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Abram, after Lot was divided from him: “Lift up your eyes, and gaze out from the place where you are now, to the north and to the meridian, to the east and to the west.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Abram, postquam divisus est ab eo Lot: Leva oculos tuos, et vide a loco, in quo nunc es, ad aquilonem et meridiem, ad orientem et occidentem.

verses.textEn: All the land that you see, I will give to you, and to your offspring even forever.
verses.textLa: Omnem terram, quam conspicis, tibi dabo, et semini tuo usque in sempiternum.

verses.textEn: And I will make your offspring like the dust of the earth. If any man is able to number the dust of the earth, he will be able to number your offspring as well.
verses.textLa: Faciamque semen tuum sicut pulverem terræ: si quis potest hominum numerare pulverem terræ, semen quoque tuum numerare poterit.

verses.textEn: Arise and walk through the land in its length, and breadth. For I will give it to you.”
verses.textLa: Surge, et perambula terram in longitudine, et in latitudine sua: quia tibi daturus sum eam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, moving his tent, Abram went and dwelt by the steep valley of Mamre, which is in Hebron. And he built an altar there to the Lord.
verses.textLa: Movens igitur tabernaculum suum Abram, venit et habitavit iuxta convallem Mambre, quæ est in Hebron: ædificavitque ibi altare Domino.

verses.textEn: Now it happened in that time that Amraphel, king of Shinar, and Arioch, king of Pontus, and Chedorlaomer, king of the Elamites, and Tidal, king of the Nations,
verses.textLa: Factum est autem in illo tempore, ut Amraphel rex Senaar, et Arioch rex Ponti, et Chodorlahomor rex Elamitarum, et Thadal rex Gentium

verses.textEn: went to war against Bera, king of Sodom, and against Birsha, king of Gomorrah, and against Shinab, king of Admah, and against Shemeber, king of Zeboiim, and against the king of Bela, that is Zoar.
verses.textLa: inirent bellum contra Bara regem Sodomorum, et contra Bersa regem Gomorrhæ, et contra Sennaab regem Adamæ, et contra Semeber regem Seboim, contraque regem Balæ, ipsa est Segor.

verses.textEn: All these came together in the wooded valley, which is now the Sea of Salt.
verses.textLa: Omnes hi convenerunt in vallem Silvestrem, quæ nunc est Mare Salis.

verses.textEn: For they had served Chedorlaomer for twelve years, and in the thirteenth year they withdrew from him.
verses.textLa: Duodecim enim annis servierunt Chodorlahomor, et tertiodecimo anno recesserunt ab eo.

verses.textEn: Therefore, in the fourteenth year, Chedorlaomer arrived, and the kings who were with him. And they struck the Rephaim at Ashteroth of the two horns, and the Zuzim with them, and the Emim at Shaveh-Kiriathaim.
verses.textLa: Igitur quartodecimo anno venit Chodorlahomor, et reges qui erant cum eo: percusseruntque Raphaim in Astarothcarnaim, et Zuzim cum eis, et Emim in Save Cariathaim,

verses.textEn: and the Chorreans in the mountains of Seir, even to the plains of Paran, which is in the wilderness.
verses.textLa: et Chorræos in montibus Seir, usque ad Campestria Pharan, quæ est in solitudine.

verses.textEn: And they returned and arrived at the fountain of Mishpat, which is Kadesh. And they struck the entire region of the Amalekites, and the Amorites who dwelt in Hazazontamar.
verses.textLa: Reversique sunt, et venerunt ad fontem Misphat, ipsa est Cades: et percusserunt omnem regionem Amalecitarum, et Amorrhæum, qui habitabat in Asasonthamar.

verses.textEn: And the king of Sodom, and the king of Gomorrah, and the king of Admah, and the king of Zeboiim, and indeed the king of Bela, which is Zoar, went forth. And they directed their point against them in the wooded valley,
verses.textLa: Et egressi sunt rex Sodomorum, et rex Gomorrhæ, rexque Adamæ, et rex Seboim, necnon et rex Balæ, quæ est Segor: et direxerunt aciem contra eos in valle Silvestri:

verses.textEn: namely, against Chedorlaomer, king of the Elamites, and Tidal, king of the Nations, and Amraphel, king of Shinar, and Arioch, king of Pontus: four kings against five.
verses.textLa: scilicet adversus Chodorlahomor regem Elamitarum, et Thadal regem Gentium, et Amraphel regem Sennaar, et Arioch regem Ponti: quatuor reges adversus quinque.

verses.textEn: Now the wooded valley had many pits of bitumen. And so the king of Sodom and the king of Gomorrah turned back and they fell there. And those who remained, fled to the mountain.
verses.textLa: Vallis autem Silvestris habebat puteos multos bituminis. Itaque rex Sodomorum, et Gomorrhæ, terga verterunt, cecideruntque ibi: et qui remanserant, fugerunt ad montem.
verses.notes: These two armies did not want to fight amidst the tar pits, so they turned back and were caught in battle by the enemy, having to way to retreat. The word ‘cecideruntque’ indicates that they fell in battle, not that they fell into the tar pits.

verses.textEn: Then they took all the substance of the Sodomites and the Gomorrhites, and all that pertained to food, and they went away,
verses.textLa: Tulerunt autem omnem substantiam Sodomorum et Gomorrhæ, et universa quæ ad cibum pertinent, et abierunt:
verses.notes: All that pertains to food includes food, utensils, cooking material, etc.

verses.textEn: along with both Lot, the son of Abram’s brother, who lived in Sodom, and his substance.
verses.textLa: necnon et Lot et substantiam eius, filium fratris Abram, qui habitabat in Sodomis.

verses.textEn: And behold, one who had escaped reported it to Abram the Hebrew, who lived in the steep valley of Mamre the Amorite, who was the brother of Eshcol, and the brother of Aner. For these had formed an agreement with Abram.
verses.textLa: Et ecce unus, qui evaserat, nunciavit Abram Hebræo, qui habitabat in convalle Mambre Amorrhæi fratris Escol, et fratris Aner: hi enim pepigerant fœdus cum Abram.

verses.textEn: When Abram had heard this, namely, that his brother Lot had been taken captive, he numbered three hundred and eighteen of his own armed men and he went in pursuit all the way to Dan.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset Abram, captum videlicet Lot fratrem suum, numeravit expeditos vernaculos suos trecentos decem, et octo: et persecutus est usque Dan.
verses.notes: These 318 were not servants, but a group of armed men who worked for Abram, guarding his possessions and his servants. There were no police in those days, and someone with a very large contingent of servants and a very large family needed armed men to protect them. These men are analogous to a large corporation having its own security guards. Also, it was brave and daring for such a small and lightly armed group, without experience in warfare, to actually attack a large army deployed in the field.

verses.textEn: And dividing his company, he rushed upon them in the night. And he struck them and pursued them as far as Hobah, which is on the left hand of Damascus.
verses.textLa: Et divisis sociis, irruit super eos nocte: percussitque eos, et persecutus est eos usque Hoba, quæ est ad lævam Damasci.

verses.textEn: And he brought back all the substance, and Lot his brother, with his substance, likewise the women and the people.
verses.textLa: Reduxitque omnem substantiam, et Lot fratrem suum cum substantia illius, mulieres quoque et populum.

verses.textEn: Then the king of Sodom went out to meet him, after he returned from the slaughter at Chedorlaomer, and the kings who were with him at the valley of Shaveh, which is the valley of the king.
verses.textLa: Egressus est autem rex Sodomorum in occursum eius postquam reversus est a cæde Chodorlahomor, et regum qui cum eo erant in valle Save, quæ est vallis regis.

verses.textEn: Then in truth, Melchizedek, the king of Salem, brought forth bread and wine, for he was a priest of the Most High God;
verses.textLa: At vero Melchisedech rex Salem, proferens panem et vinum, erat enim sacerdos Dei Altissimi,
verses.notes: Salem (Shalom) means peace; Melchizedek is the king of peace and a foreshadowing of Christ, the King of Peace.

verses.textEn: he blessed him, and he said: “Blessed be Abram by the Most High God, who created heaven and earth.
verses.textLa: benedixit ei, et ait: Benedictus Abram Deo Excelso, qui creavit cælum et terram:

verses.textEn: And blessed be the Most High God, through whose protection the enemies are in your hands.” And he gave him tithes from everything.
verses.textLa: et benedictus Deus Excelsus, quo protegente, hostes in manibus tuis sunt. Et dedit ei decimas ex omnibus.

verses.textEn: Then the king of Sodom said to Abram, “Give me these souls, and take the rest for yourself.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem rex Sodomorum ad Abram: Da mihi animas, cetera tolle tibi.

verses.textEn: And he responded to him: “I lift up my hand to the Lord God, the Most High, the Possessor of heaven and earth,
verses.textLa: Qui respondit ei: Levo manum meam ad Dominum Deum excelsum Possessorem cæli et terræ,

verses.textEn: that from one thread within a blanket, even to a single shoelace, I will not take anything from that which is yours, lest you say, ‘I have enriched Abram,’
verses.textLa: quod a filo subtegminis usque ad corigiam caligæ, non accipiam ex omnibus quæ tua sunt, ne dicas: Ego ditavi Abram:

verses.textEn: except that which the young men have eaten, and the shares for the men who came with me: Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre. These will take their shares.”
verses.textLa: exceptis his, quæ comederunt iuvenes, et partibus virorum, qui venerunt mecum, Aner, Eschol, et Mambre: isti accipient partes suas.

verses.textEn: And so, these things having been transacted, the word of the Lord came to Abram by a vision, saying: “Do not be afraid, Abram, I am your protector, and your reward is exceedingly great.”
verses.textLa: His itaque transactis, factus est sermo Domini ad Abram per visionem, dicens: Noli timere Abram, ego protector tuus sum, et merces tua magna nimis.

verses.textEn: And Abram said: “Lord God, what will you give to me? I may go without children. And the son of the steward of my house is this Eliezer of Damascus.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Abram: Domine Deus, quid dabis mihi? ego vadam absque liberis: et filius procuratoris domus meæ iste Damascus Eliezer.

verses.textEn: And Abram added: “Yet to me you have not given offspring. And behold, my servant born in my house will be my heir.”
verses.textLa: Addiditque Abram: Mihi autem non dedisti semen: et ecce vernaculus meus, heres meus erit.

verses.textEn: And immediately the word of the Lord came to him, saying: “This one will not be your heir. But he who will come from your loins, the same will you have for your heir.”
verses.textLa: Statimque sermo Domini factus est ad eum, dicens: Non erit hic heres tuus: sed qui egredietur de utero tuo, ipsum habebis heredem.
verses.notes: The word ‘utero’ can refer to a man or a woman. When referring to a woman, it is usually translated as ‘womb,’ but it can also refer more generally to a woman’s ability to procreate. When referring to a man, it can be translated as ‘belly,’ or ‘abdomen,’ or ‘loins.’ But it often refers, in men, more generally to the male ability to procreate.

verses.textEn: And he brought him outside, and he said to him, “Take in the heavens, and number the stars, if you can.” And he said to him, “So also will your offspring be.”
verses.textLa: Eduxitque eum foras, et ait illi: Suscipe cælum, et numera stellas, si potes. Et dixit ei: Sic erit semen tuum.

verses.textEn: Abram believed God, and it was reputed to him unto justice.
verses.textLa: Credidit Abram Deo, et reputatum est illi ad iustitiam.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, “I am the Lord who led you away from Ur of the Chaldeans, so as to give you this land, and so that you would possess it.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad eum: Ego Dominus qui eduxi te de Ur Chaldæorum ut darem tibi terram istam, et possideres eam.

verses.textEn: But he said, “Lord God, in what way may I be able to know that I will possess it?”
verses.textLa: At ille ait: Domine Deus, unde scire possum, quod possessurus sim eam?

verses.textEn: And the Lord responded by saying: “Take for me a cow of three years, and a she-goat of three years, and a ram of three years, also a turtle-dove and a pigeon.”
verses.textLa: Et respondens Dominus: Sume, inquit, mihi vaccam triennem, et capram trimam, et arietem annorum trium, turturem quoque, et columbam.
verses.notes: The words ‘dove’ and ‘pigeon’ are generally interchangeable. The word turtle-dove is more specific, but, in the context of ancient times, it probably does not refer to only one species.

verses.textEn: Taking all these, he divided them through the middle, and placed both parts opposite one another. But the birds he did not divide.
verses.textLa: Qui tollens universa hæc, divisit ea per medium, et utrasque partes contra se altrinsecus posuit: aves autem non divisit.

verses.textEn: And birds descended upon the carcasses, but Abram drove them away.
verses.textLa: Descenderuntque volucres super cadavera, et abigebat eas Abram.

verses.textEn: And when the sun was setting, a deep sleep fell upon Abram, and a dread, great and dark, invaded him.
verses.textLa: Cumque sol occumberet, sopor irruit super Abram, et horror magnus et tenebrosus invasit eum.

verses.textEn: And it was said to him: “Know beforehand that your future offspring will be sojourners in a land not their own, and they will subjugate them in servitude and afflict them for four hundred years.
verses.textLa: Dictumque est ad eum: Scito prænoscens quod peregrinum futurum sit semen tuum in terra non sua, et subiicient eos servituti, et affligent quadringentis annis.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, I will judge the nation that they will serve, and after this they will depart with great substance.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen gentem, cui servituri sunt, ego iudicabo: et post hæc egredientur cum magna substantia.

verses.textEn: But you will go to your fathers in peace and be buried at a good old age.
verses.textLa: Tu autem ibis ad patres tuos in pace, sepultus in senectute bona.

verses.textEn: But in the fourth generation, they will return here. For the iniquities of the Amorites are not yet completed, even to this present time.”
verses.textLa: Generatione autem quarta revertentur huc: necdum enim completæ sunt iniquitates Amorrhæorum usque ad præsens tempus.

verses.textEn: Then, when the sun had set, there came a dark mist, and there appeared a smoking furnace and a lamp of fire passing between those divisions.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo occubuisset sol, facta est caligo tenebrosa, et apparuit clibanus fumans, et lampas ignis transiens inter divisiones illas.

verses.textEn: On that day, God formed a covenant with Abram, saying: “To your offspring I will give this land, from the river of Egypt, even to the great river Euphrates:
verses.textLa: In illo die pepigit Dominus fœdus cum Abram, dicens: Semini tuo dabo terram hanc a fluvio Ægypti usque ad fluvium magnum Euphraten,

verses.textEn: the land of the Kenites and the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites
verses.textLa: Cinæos, et Cenezæos, Cedmonæos,

verses.textEn: and the Hittites, and the Perizzites, likewise the Rephaim,
verses.textLa: et Hethæos, et Pherezæos, Raphaim quoque,

verses.textEn: and the Amorites, and the Canaanites, and the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.”
verses.textLa: et Amorrhæos, et Chananæos, et Gergesæos, et Iebusæos.

verses.textEn: Now Sarai, the wife of Abram, had not conceived children. But, having an Egyptian handmaid named Hagar,
verses.textLa: Igitur Sarai, uxor Abram, non genuerat liberos: sed habens ancillam Ægyptiam nomine Agar,

verses.textEn: she said to her husband: “Behold, the Lord has closed me, lest I give birth. Enter to my handmaid, so that perhaps I may receive sons of her at least.” And when he agreed to her supplication,
verses.textLa: dixit marito suo: Ecce, conclusit me Dominus, ne parerem: ingredere ad ancillam meam, si forte saltem ex illa suscipiam filios. Cumque ille acquiesceret deprecanti,

verses.textEn: she took Hagar the Egyptian, her handmaid, ten years after they began to live in the land of Canaan, and she gave her to her husband as a wife.
verses.textLa: tulit Agar Ægyptiam ancillam suam post annos decem quam habitare cœperant in terra Chanaan: et dedit eam viro suo uxorem.

verses.textEn: And he entered to her. But when she saw that she had conceived, she despised her mistress.
verses.textLa: Qui ingressus est ad eam. At illa concepisse se videns, despexit dominam suam.

verses.textEn: And Sarai said to Abram: “You have acted unfairly against me. I gave my handmaid into your bosom, who, when she saw that she had conceived, held me in contempt. May the Lord judge between me and you.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Sarai ad Abram: Inique agis contra me: ego dedi ancillam meam in sinum tuum, quæ videns quod conceperit, despectui me habet. Iudicet Dominus inter me, et te.

verses.textEn: Abram responded to her by saying, “Behold, your handmaid is in your hand to treat as it pleases you.” And so, when Sarai afflicted her, she took flight.
verses.textLa: Cui respondens Abram: Ecce, ait, ancilla tua in manu tua est, utere ea ut libet. Affligente igitur eam Sarai, fugam iniit.

verses.textEn: And when the Angel of the Lord had found her, near the fountain of water in the wilderness, which is on the way to Shur in the desert,
verses.textLa: Cumque invenisset eam Angelus Domini iuxta fontem aquæ in solitudine, qui est in via Sur in deserto,

verses.textEn: he said to her: “Hagar, handmaid of Sarai, where have you come from? And where will you go?” And she answered, “I flee from the face of Sarai, my mistress.”
verses.textLa: dixit ad illam: Agar ancilla Sarai, unde venis? et quo vadis? Quæ respondit: A facie Sarai dominæ meæ ego fugio.
verses.notes: The dangling participle at the end of the Angel’s question is grammatically incorrect, but is left in that form because that is the way that people speak in conversation.

verses.textEn: And the Angel of the Lord said to her, “Return to your mistress, and humble yourself under her hand.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ei Angelus Domini: Revertere ad dominam tuam, et humiliare sub manu illius.

verses.textEn: And again he said, “I will multiply your offspring continuously, and they will not be numbered because of their multitude.”
verses.textLa: Et rursum: Multiplicans, inquit, multiplicabo semen tuum, et non numerabitur præ multitudine.
verses.notes: The repetition of using multiplicans with multiplicabo does not merely indicate intensity, but in this case also indicates that the multiplying of her offspring continues through subsequent generations, and does not merely refer to her immediate offspring.

verses.textEn: But thereafter he said: “Behold, you have conceived, and you will give birth to a son. And you shall call his name Ishmael, because the Lord has heard your affliction.
verses.textLa: Ac deinceps: Ecce, ait, concepisti, et paries filium: vocabisque nomen eius Ismael, eo quod audierit Dominus afflictionem tuam.

verses.textEn: He will be a wild man. His hand will be against all, and all hands will be against him. And he will pitch his tents away from the region of all his brothers.”
verses.textLa: Hic erit ferus homo: manus eius contra omnes, et manus omnium contra eum: et e regione universorum fratrum suorum figet tabernacula.

verses.textEn: Then she called upon the name of the Lord who had spoken to her: “You are the God who has seen me.” For she said, “Certainly, here I have seen the back of the one who sees me.”
verses.textLa: Vocavit autem nomen Domini qui loquebatur ad eam: Tu Deus qui vidisti me. Dixit enim: Profecto hic vidi posteriora videntis me.
verses.notes: She saw His back, in other words, not His face, which would connotate a greater knowledge of God than she had. She met God, but did not know him well, seeing as it were His back, not His face.

verses.textEn: Because of this, she called that well: ‘The well of the one who lives and who sees me.’ The same is between Kadesh and Bered.
verses.textLa: Propterea appellavit puteum illum, Puteum viventis et videntis me. Ipse est inter Cades et Barad.

verses.textEn: And Hagar gave birth to a son for Abram, who called his name Ishmael.
verses.textLa: Peperitque Agar Abræ filium: qui vocavit nomen eius Ismael.

verses.textEn: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar gave birth to Ishmael for him.
verses.textLa: Octoginta et sex annorum erat Abram quando peperit ei Agar Ismaelem.

verses.textEn: In truth, after he began to be ninety-nine years of age, the Lord appeared to him. And he said to him: “I am the Almighty God. Walk in my sight and become complete.
verses.textLa: Postquam vero nonaginta et novem annorum esse cœperat, apparuit ei Dominus: dixitque ad eum: Ego Deus omnipotens: ambula coram me, et esto perfectus.

verses.textEn: And I will set my covenant between me and you. And I will multiply you very exceedingly.”
verses.textLa: Ponamque fœdus meum inter me et te, et multiplicabo te vehementer nimis.
verses.notes: The use of ‘vehementer’ with ‘nimis’ indicates an extreme degree, for each of those words alone means ‘very much’ or ‘exceedingly.’ When used together it is hard to express the meaning.

verses.textEn: Abram fell prone on his face.
verses.textLa: Cecidit Abram pronus in faciem.

verses.textEn: And God said to him: “I AM, and my covenant is with you, and you will be the father of many nations.
verses.textLa: Dixitque ei Deus: EGO SUM, et pactum meum tecum, erisque pater multarum gentium.

verses.textEn: No longer will your name be called Abram. But you will be called Abraham, for I have established you as the father of many nations.
verses.textLa: Nec ultra vocabitur nomen tuum Abram: sed appellaberis Abraham: quia patrem multarum gentium constitui te.

verses.textEn: And I will cause you to increase very greatly, and I will set you among the nations, and kings will come forth from you.
verses.textLa: Faciamque te crescere vehementissime, et ponam te in gentibus, regesque ex te egredientur.

verses.textEn: And I will establish my covenant between me and you, and with your offspring after you in their generations, by a perpetual covenant: to be God to you and to your offspring after you.
verses.textLa: Et statuam pactum meum inter me et te, et inter semen tuum post te in generationibus suis fœdere sempiterno: ut sim Deus tuus, et seminis tui post te.

verses.textEn: And I will give to you and to your offspring, the land of your sojourn, all the land of Canaan, as an eternal possession, and I will be their God.”
verses.textLa: Daboque tibi et semini tuo terram peregrinationis tuæ, omnem terram Chanaan in possessionem æternam, eroque Deus eorum.

verses.textEn: Again God said to Abraham: “And you therefore shall keep my covenant, and your offspring after you in their generations.
verses.textLa: Dixit iterum Deus ad Abraham: Et tu ergo custodies pactum meum, et semen tuum post te in generationibus suis.

verses.textEn: This is my covenant, which you shall observe, between me and you, and your offspring after you: All the males among you shall be circumcised.
verses.textLa: Hoc est pactum meum quod observabitis inter me et vos, et semen tuum post te: Circumcidetur ex vobis omne masculinum:

verses.textEn: And you shall circumcise the flesh of your foreskin, so that it may be a sign of the covenant between me and you.
verses.textLa: et circumcidetis carnem præputii vestri, ut sit in signum fœderis inter me et vos.
verses.notes: Circumcision is chosen as the sign of the covenant because God intends men and women to have fundamentally different roles in the family, in religion, and in society.

verses.textEn: An infant of eight days will be circumcised among you, every male in your generations. So also servants born to you, as well as those bought, shall be circumcised, even those who are not of your stock.
verses.textLa: Infans octo dierum circumcidetur in vobis, omne masculinum in generationibus vestris: tam vernaculus, quam emptitius circumcidetur, et quicumque non fuerit de stirpe vestra:

verses.textEn: And my covenant shall be with your flesh as an eternal covenant.
verses.textLa: eritque pactum meum in carne vestra in fœdus æternum.

verses.textEn: The male, the flesh of whose foreskin will not be circumcised, that soul shall be eliminated from his people. For he has made my covenant void.”
verses.textLa: Masculus, cuius præputii caro circumcisa non fuerit, delebitur anima illa de populo suo: quia pactum meum irritum fecit.

verses.textEn: God said also to Abraham: “Your wife Sarai, you shall not call Sarai, but Sarah.
verses.textLa: Dixit quoque Deus ad Abraham: Sarai uxorem tuam non vocabis Sarai, sed Saram.

verses.textEn: And I will bless her, and from her I will give you a son, whom I will bless, and he will be among the nations, and the kings of the peoples will rise from him.”
verses.textLa: Et benedicam ei, et ex illa dabo tibi filium cui benedicturus sum, eritque in nationes, et reges populorum orientur ex eo.

verses.textEn: Abraham fell on his face, and he laughed, saying in his heart: “Do you think a son can be born to a one hundred year old man? And will Sarah give birth at the age of ninety?”
verses.textLa: Cecidit Abraham in faciem suam, et risit, dicens in corde suo: Putasne centenario nascetur filius? et Sara nonagenaria pariet?

verses.textEn: And he said to God, “If only Ishmael would live in your sight.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad Deum: Utinam Ismael vivat coram te.

verses.textEn: And God said to Abraham: “Your wife Sarah shall give birth to a son, and you shall call his name Isaac, and I will establish my covenant with him as a perpetual covenant, and with his offspring after him.
verses.textLa: Et ait Deus ad Abraham: Sara uxor tua pariet tibi filium, vocabisque nomen eius Isaac, et constituam pactum meum illi in fœdus sempiternum, et semini eius post eum.
verses.notes: Here is an example where two different words in Latin, ‘pactum’ and ‘fœdus,’ are translated by the same word in English.

verses.textEn: Likewise, concerning Ishmael, I have heard you. Behold, I will bless and enlarge him, and I will multiply him greatly. He will produce twelve leaders, and I will make him into a great nation.
verses.textLa: Super Ismael quoque exaudivi te. Ecce, benedicam ei, et augebo, et multiplicabo eum valde: duodecim duces generabit, et faciam illum in gentem magnam.

verses.textEn: Yet in truth, I will establish my covenant with Isaac, to whom Sarah will give birth for you at this time next year.”
verses.textLa: Pactum vero meum statuam ad Isaac, quem pariet tibi Sara tempore isto in anno altero.

verses.textEn: And when he had finished speaking with him, God ascended from Abraham.
verses.textLa: Cumque finitus esset sermo loquentis cum eo, ascendit Deus ab Abraham.

verses.textEn: Then Abraham took his son Ishmael, and all who were born in his house, and all whom he had bought, every male among the men of his house, and he circumcised the flesh of their foreskin promptly, the very same day, just as God had instructed him.
verses.textLa: Tulit autem Abraham Ismael filium suum, et omnes vernaculos domus suæ, universosque quos emerat, cunctos mares ex omnibus viris domus suæ: et circumcidit carnem præputii eorum statim in ipsa die, sicut præceperat ei Deus.

verses.textEn: Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he circumcised the flesh of his foreskin.
verses.textLa: Abraham nonaginta et novem erat annorum quando circumcidit carnem præputii sui.

verses.textEn: And his son Ishmael had completed thirteen years at the time of his circumcision.
verses.textLa: Et Ismael filius tredecim annos impleverat tempore circumcisionis suæ.

verses.textEn: On the very same day, Abraham was circumcised with his son Ishmael.
verses.textLa: Eadem die circumcisus est Abraham et Ismael filius eius.

verses.textEn: And all the men of his house, those born in his house, as well as those who were bought, even the foreigners, were circumcised with him.
verses.textLa: Et omnes viri domus illius, tam vernaculi, quam emptitii et alienigenæ pariter circumcisi sunt.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord appeared to him, in the steep valley of Mamre, when he was sitting at the door of his tent, in the very heat of the day.
verses.textLa: Apparuit autem ei Dominus in convalle Mambre sedenti in ostio tabernaculi sui in ipso fervore diei.

verses.textEn: And when he had lifted up his eyes, there appeared to him three men, standing near him. When he had seen them, he ran to meet them from the door of his tent, and he reverenced them on the ground.
verses.textLa: Cumque elevasset oculos, apparuerunt ei tres viri stantes prope eum: quos cum vidisset, cucurrit in occursum eorum de ostio tabernaculi, et adoravit in terram.
verses.notes: The word ‘adoravit’ in Latin does not always refer to adoration; it can also refer to treating someone with reverence or respect.

verses.textEn: And he said: “If I, O lord, have found grace in your eyes, do not pass by your servant.
verses.textLa: Et dixit: Domine, si inveni gratiam in oculis tuis, ne transeas servum tuum:

verses.textEn: But I will bring a little water, and you may wash your feet and rest under the tree.
verses.textLa: sed afferam pauxillum aquæ, et lavate pedes vestros, et requiescite sub arbore.
verses.notes: Because ‘lavate’ and ‘requiescite’ are imperative, it implies that the washing of the feet will be done by the visitors, not by Abram. Otherwise, the verb would have been indicative first person singular.

verses.textEn: And I will set out a meal of bread, so that you may strengthen your heart; after this you will pass on. It is for this reason that you have turned aside to your servant.” And they said, “Do as you have spoken.”
verses.textLa: Ponamque buccellam panis, et confortate cor vestrum, postea transibitis: idcirco enim declinastis ad servum vestrum. Qui dixerunt: Fac ut locutus es.

verses.textEn: Abraham hurried into the tent to Sarah, and he said to her, “Quickly, mix together three measures of the finest wheat flour and make loaves baked under the ashes.”
verses.textLa: Festinavit Abraham in tabernaculum ad Saram, dixitque ei: Accelera, tria sata similæ commisce, et fac subcinericios panes.
verses.notes:
The word ‘sata’ refers to something that is cultivated, as opposed to grain that is wild. There is also a strong implication that it was cultivated locally, that is, by the servants of Abraham; it was not bought, but home-grown. This could be translated as ‘home-grown wheat flour,’ but it is usually translated as ‘the finest wheat flour,’ since wheat has a strong symbolic connection to the Eucharist, the finest Sacrament.
 The word ‘subcinericios’ probably refers to an ancient type of heat retention cooking, where loaves were placed under the ashes of a fire to bake.

verses.textEn: In truth, he himself ran to the herd, and he took a calf from there, very tender and very good, and he gave it to a servant, who hurried and boiled it.
verses.textLa: Ipse vero ad armentum cucurrit, et tulit inde vitulum tenerrimum et optimum, deditque puero: qui festinavit, et coxit illum.

verses.textEn: Likewise, he took butter and milk, and the calf which he had boiled, and he placed it before them. Yet truly, he himself stood near them under the tree.
verses.textLa: Tulit quoque butyrum et lac, et vitulum quem coxerat, et posuit coram eis: ipse vero stabat iuxta eos sub arbore.

verses.textEn: And when they had eaten, they said to him, “Where is Sarah your wife?” He answered, “Behold, she is in the tent.”
verses.textLa: Cumque comedissent, dixerunt ad eum: Ubi est Sara uxor tua? ille respondit: Ecce in tabernaculo est.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, “When returning, I will come to you at this time, with life as a companion, and your wife Sarah will have a son.” Hearing this, Sarah laughed behind the door of the tent.
verses.textLa: Cui dixit: Revertens veniam ad te tempore isto, vita comite, et habebit filium Sara uxor tua. Quo audito, Sara risit post ostium tabernaculi.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘vita comite’ literally means ‘with life as a companion.’ Wycliffe translates this as ‘if I live.’ But other translations see it as referring to the time of his return, the springtime. The phrase, in this context, has a dual meaning. It refers to the springtime: life springing up when he returns, as if his companion. It also refers to the life in Sarah’s womb, for this new life’s birth will coincide with his return.

verses.textEn: Now they were both old, and in an advanced state of life, and it had ceased to be with Sarah after the manner of women.
verses.textLa: Erant autem ambo senes, provectæque ætatis, et desierant Saræ fieri muliebria.

verses.textEn: And she laughed secretly, saying, “After I have grown old, and my lord is elderly, shall I give myself to the work of delight?”
verses.textLa: Quæ risit occulte dicens: Postquam consenui, et dominus meus vetulus est, voluptati operam dabo?

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to Abraham: “Why did Sarah laugh, saying: ‘How can I, an old woman, actually give birth?’
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus ad Abraham: Quare risit Sara, dicens: Num vere paritura sum anus?

verses.textEn: Is anything difficult for God? According to the announcement, he will return to you at this same time, with life as a companion, and Sarah will have a son.”
verses.textLa: Numquid Deo quidquam est difficile? iuxta condictum revertar ad te hoc eodem tempore, vita comite, et habebit Sara filium.
verses.notes: The Douay-Rheims versions have ‘I shall return,’ but the text says ‘he shall return,’ using the third person singular.

verses.textEn: Sarah denied it, saying, “I did not laugh.” For she was terribly afraid. But the Lord said, “It is not so; for you did laugh.”
verses.textLa: Negabit Sara, dicens: Non risi, timore perterrita. Dominus autem: Non est, inquit, ita: sed risisti.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when the men had risen up from there, they directed their eyes against Sodom. And Abraham traveled with them, leading them.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo surrexissent inde viri, direxerunt oculos contra Sodomam: et Abraham simul gradiebatur, deducens eos.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said: “How could I hide what I am about to do from Abraham,
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus: Num celare potero Abraham quæ gesturus sum:

verses.textEn: since he will become a great and very robust nation, and in him all the nations of the earth will be blessed?
verses.textLa: cum futurus sit in gentem magnam, ac robustissimam, et benedicendæ sint in illo omnes nationes terræ?

verses.textEn: For I know that he will instruct his sons, and his household after him, to keep to the way of the Lord, and to act with judgment and justice, so that, for the sake of Abraham, the Lord may bring about all the things that he has spoken to him.”
verses.textLa: Scio enim quod præcepturus sit filiis suis, et domui suæ post se ut custodiant viam Domini, et faciant iudicium et iustitiam: ut adducat Dominus propter Abraham omnia quæ locutus est ad eum.

verses.textEn: And so the Lord said, “The outcry from Sodom and Gomorrah has been multiplied, and their sin has become exceedingly grievous.
verses.textLa: Dixit itaque Dominus: Clamor Sodomorum et Gomorrhæ multiplicatus est, et peccatum eorum aggravatum est nimis.

verses.textEn: I will descend and see whether they have fulfilled the work of the outcry that has reached me, or whether it is not so, in order that I may know.”
verses.textLa: Descendam, et videbo utrum clamorem qui venit ad me, opere compleverint: an non est ita, ut sciam.
verses.notes: Scripture is explaining God’s actions in human terms, as a figure of speech, because it is difficult to describe or even imagine the fullness of Eternity and Knowledge found in God. Scripture is not saying that God could not know without going down to investigate.

verses.textEn: And they turned themselves from there, and they went toward Sodom. Yet in truth, Abraham still stood in the sight of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Converteruntque se inde, et abierunt Sodomam: Abraham vero adhuc stabat coram Domino.
verses.notes: Abraham traveled, but he still was, in a manner of speaking always standing in front of the Lord.

verses.textEn: And as they drew near, he said: “Will you destroy the just with the impious?
verses.textLa: Et appropinquans ait: Numquid perdes iustum cum impio?

verses.textEn: If there were fifty of the just in the city, will they perish with the rest? And will you not spare that place for the sake of fifty of the just, if they were in it?
verses.textLa: Si fuerint quinquaginta iusti in civitate, peribunt simul? Et non parces loco illi propter quinquaginta iustos, si fuerint in eo?

verses.textEn: Far be it from you to do this thing, and to kill the just with the impious, and for the just to be treated like the impious. No, this is not like you. You judge all the earth; you would never make such a judgment.”
verses.textLa: Absit a te, ut rem hanc facias, et occidas iustum cum impio, fiatque iustus sicut impius, non est hoc tuum: qui iudicas omnem terram, nequaquam facies iudicium hoc.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to him, “If I find in Sodom fifty of the just in the midst of the city, I will release the entire place because of them.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad eum: Si invenero Sodomis quinquaginta iustos in medio civitatis, dimittam omni loco propter eos.

verses.textEn: And Abraham responded by saying: “Since now I have begun, I will speak to my Lord, though I am dust and ashes.
verses.textLa: Respondensque Abraham, ait: Quia semel cœpi, loquar ad Dominum meum, cum sim pulvis et cinis.

verses.textEn: What if there were five less than fifty of the just? Would you, despite the forty-five, eliminate the entire city?” And he said, “I will not eliminate it, if I find forty-five there.”
verses.textLa: Quid si minus quinquaginta iustis quinque fuerint? Delebis, propter quadraginta quinque, universam urbem? Et ait: Non delebo, si invenero ibi quadraginta quinque.

verses.textEn: And again he said to him, “But if forty were found there, what would you do?” He said, “I will not strike, for the sake of the forty.”
verses.textLa: Rursumque locutus est ad eum: Sin autem quadraginta ibi inventi fuerint, quid facies? Ait: Non percutiam propter quadraginta.
verses.notes: Too many different words in Latin are all typically translated with the English word ‘destroy.’

verses.textEn: “I ask you,” he said, “not to be angry, Lord, if I speak. What if thirty were found there?” He responded, “I will not act, if I find thirty there.”
verses.textLa: Ne quæso, inquit, indigneris Domine, si loquar: Quid si ibi inventi fuerint triginta? Respondit: Non faciam, si invenero ibi triginta.

verses.textEn: “Since now I have begun,” he said, “I will speak to my Lord. What if twenty were found there?” He said, “I will not put to death, for the sake of the twenty.”
verses.textLa: Quia semel, ait, cœpi loquar ad Dominum meum: Quid si ibi inventi fuerint viginti? Ait: Non interficiam propter viginti.

verses.textEn: “I beg you,” he said, “not to be angry, Lord, if I speak yet once more. What if ten were found there?” And he said, “I will not destroy it for the sake of the ten.”
verses.textLa: Obsecro, inquit, ne irascaris Domine, si loquar adhuc semel: Quid si inventi fuerint ibi decem? Et dixit: Non delebo propter decem.

verses.textEn: And the Lord departed, after he had ceased speaking to Abraham, who then returned to his place.
verses.textLa: Abiitque Dominus, postquam cessavit loqui ad Abraham: et ille reversus est in locum suum.

verses.textEn: And the two Angels arrived at Sodom in the evening, and Lot was sitting at the gate of the city. And when he had seen them, he rose up and went to meet them. And he reverenced prone on the ground.
verses.textLa: Veneruntque duo Angeli Sodomam vespere, et sedente Lot in foribus civitatis. Qui cum vidisset eos, surrexit, et ivit obviam eis: adoravitque pronus in terram,

verses.textEn: And he said: “I beg you, my lords, turn aside to the house of your servant, and lodge there. Wash your feet, and in the morning you will advance on your way.” And they said, “Not at all. But we will lodge in the street.”
verses.textLa: et dixit: Obsecro, domini, declinate in domum pueri vestri, et manete ibi: lavate pedes vestros, et mane proficiscemini in viam vestram. Qui dixerunt: Minime, sed in platea manebimus.

verses.textEn: He pressed them very much to turn aside to him. And when they had entered his house, he made a feast for them, and he cooked unleavened bread, and they ate.
verses.textLa: Compulit illos oppido ut diverterent ad eum: ingressisque domum illius fecit convivium, et coxit azyma: et comederunt.
verses.notes: The verb ‘coxit’ can refer to baking or other types of cooking, but it often refers to boiling.

verses.textEn: But before they went to bed, the men of the city surrounded the house, from boys to old men, all the people together.
verses.textLa: Prius autem quam irent cubitum, viri civitatis vallaverunt domum a puero usque ad senem, omnis populus simul.

verses.textEn: And they called out to Lot, and they said to him: “Where are the men who entered to you in the night? Bring them out here, so that we may know them.”
verses.textLa: Vocaveruntque Lot, et dixerunt ei: Ubi sunt viri qui introierunt ad te nocte? educ illos huc, ut cognoscamus eos.

verses.textEn: Lot went out to them, and blocking the door behind him, he said:
verses.textLa: Egressus ad eos Lot, post tergum occludens ostium, ait:

verses.textEn: “Do not, I ask you, my brothers, do not be willing to commit this evil.
verses.textLa: Nolite, quæso, fratres mei, nolite malum hoc facere.

verses.textEn: I have two daughters who as yet have not known man. I will bring them out to you; abuse them as it pleases you, provided that you do no evil to these men, because they have entered under the shadow of my roof.”
verses.textLa: Habeo duas filias, quæ necdum cognoverunt virum: educam eas ad vos, et abutimini eis sicut vobis placuerit, dummodo viris istis nihil mali faciatis, quia ingressi sunt sub umbra culminis mei.
verses.notes:
In this passage, Sacred Scripture plainly teaches that homosexual acts are much more offensive to God than even the worst heterosexual acts.
 Modern society, like Lot, permits all manner of sexual offenses to be committed within heterosexual relations, yet some persons, like those of Sodom, insist on committing the greater offense of homosexual acts.

verses.textEn: But they said, “Move away from there.” And again: “You have entered,” they said, “as a stranger; should you then judge? Therefore, we will afflict you yourself more than them.” And they acted very violently against Lot. And they were now at the point of breaking open the doors.
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt: Recede illuc. Et rursus: Ingressus es, inquiunt, ut advena; numquid ut iudices? te ergo ipsum magis quam hos affligemus. Vimque faciebant Lot vehementissime: iamque prope erat ut effringerent fores.

verses.textEn: And behold, the men put out their hand, and they pulled Lot in to them, and they closed the door.
verses.textLa: Et ecce miserunt manum viri, et introduxerunt ad se Lot, clauseruntque ostium:

verses.textEn: And they struck those who were outside with blindness, from the least to the greatest, so that they were not able to find the door.
verses.textLa: et eos, qui foris erant, percusserunt cæcitate a minimo usque ad maximum, ita ut ostium invenire non possent.

verses.textEn: Then they said to Lot: “Do you have here anyone of yours? All who are yours, sons-in-law, or sons, or daughters, bring them out of this city.
verses.textLa: Dixerunt autem ad Lot: Habes hic quempiam tuorum? generum, aut filios, aut filias, omnes, qui tui sunt, educ de urbe hac:

verses.textEn: For we will eliminate this place, because the outcry among them has increased before the Lord, who sent us to destroy them.”
verses.textLa: delebimus enim locum istum, eo quod increverit clamor eorum coram Domino, qui misit nos ut perdamus illos.
verses.notes: The genitive case is not always to be translated as possession.

verses.textEn: And so Lot, going out, spoke to his sons-in-law, who were going to receive his daughters, and he said: “Rise up. Depart from this place. For the Lord will destroy this city.” And it seemed to them that he was speaking playfully.
verses.textLa: Egressus itaque Lot, locutus est ad generos suos qui accepturi erant filias eius, et dixit: Surgite, egredimini de loco isto: quia delebit Dominus civitatem hanc. Et visus est eis quasi ludens loqui.

verses.textEn: And when it was morning, the Angels compelled him, saying, “Arise, take your wife, and the two daughters that you have, lest you also should perish amid the wickedness of the city.”
verses.textLa: Cumque esset mane, cogebant eum Angeli, dicentes: Surge, tolle uxorem tuam, et duas filias quas habes: ne et tu pariter pereas in scelere civitatis.

verses.textEn: And, since he ignored them, they took his hand, and the hand of his wife, as well as that of his two daughters, because the Lord was sparing him.
verses.textLa: Dissimulante illo, apprehenderunt manum eius, et manum uxoris, ac duarum filiarum eius, eo quod parceret Dominus illi.

verses.textEn: And they brought him out, and placed him beyond the city. And there they spoke to him, saying: “Save your life. Do not look back. Neither should you stay in the entire surrounding region. But save yourself in the mountain, lest you also should perish.”
verses.textLa: Eduxeruntque eum, et posuerunt extra civitatem: ibique locuti sunt ad eum, dicentes: Salva animam tuam: noli respicere post tergum, nec stes in omni circa regione: sed in monte salvum te fac, ne et tu simul pereas.

verses.textEn: And Lot said to them: “I beg you, my lord,
verses.textLa: Dixitque Lot ad eos: Quæso domine mi,

verses.textEn: though your servant has found grace before you, and you have magnified your mercy, which you have shown to me in saving my life, I cannot be saved on the mountain, lest perhaps some misfortune take hold of me and I die.
verses.textLa: quia invenit servus tuus gratiam coram te, et magnificasti misericordiam tuam quam fecisti mecum, ut salvares animam meam, nec possum in monte salvari, ne forte apprehendat me malum, et moriar:

verses.textEn: There is a certain city nearby, to which I can flee; it is a little one, and I will be saved in it. Is it not a modest one, and will not my soul live?”
verses.textLa: Est civitas hæc iuxta, ad quam possum fugere, parva, et salvabor in ea: numquid non modica est, et vivet anima mea?

verses.textEn: And he said to him: “Behold, even now, I have heard your petitions about this, not to overturn the city on behalf of which you have spoken.
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad eum: Ecce etiam in hoc suscepi preces tuas, ut non subvertam urbem pro qua locutus es.

verses.textEn: Hurry and be saved there. For I cannot do anything until you enter there.” For this reason, the name of that city is called Zoar.
verses.textLa: Festina, et salvare ibi: quia non potero facere quidquam donec ingrediaris illuc. Idcirco vocatum est nomen urbis illius Segor.

verses.textEn: The sun had risen over the land, and Lot had entered into Zoar.
verses.textLa: Sol egressus est super terram, et Lot ingressus est Segor.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the Lord rained upon Sodom and Gomorrah sulphur and fire, from the Lord, out of heaven.
verses.textLa: Igitur Dominus pluit super Sodomam et Gomorrham sulphur et ignem a Domino de cælo:

verses.textEn: And he overturned these cities, and all the surrounding region: all the inhabitants of the cities, and everything that springs from the land.
verses.textLa: et subvertit civitates has, et omnem circa regionem, universos habitatores urbium, et cuncta terræ virentia.

verses.textEn: And his wife, looking behind herself, was turned into a statue of salt.
verses.textLa: Respiciensque uxor eius post se, versa est in statuam salis.

verses.textEn: Then Abraham, rising up in the morning, in the place where he had stood before with the Lord,
verses.textLa: Abraham autem consurgens mane, ubi steterat prius cum Domino,

verses.textEn: looked out toward Sodom and Gomorrah, and the entire land of that region. And he saw embers rising up from the land like smoke from a furnace.
verses.textLa: intuitus est Sodomam et Gomorrham, et universam terram regionis illius: viditque ascendentem favillam de terra quasi fornacis fumum.

verses.textEn: For when God overthrew the cities of that region, remembering Abraham, he freed Lot from the overthrow of the cities, in which he had dwelt.
verses.textLa: Cum enim subverteret Deus civitates regionis illius, recordatus Abrahæ, liberavit Lot de subversione urbium in quibus habitaverat.

verses.textEn: And Lot ascended from Zoar, and he stayed on the mountain, and likewise his two daughters with him, (for he was afraid to stay in Zoar) and he dwelt in a cave, he and his two daughters with him.
verses.textLa: Ascenditque Lot de Segor, et mansit in monte, duæ quoque filiæ eius cum eo (timuerat enim manere in Segor) et mansit in spelunca ipse, et duæ filiæ eius cum eo.

verses.textEn: And the elder said to the younger: “Our father is old, and no man remains in the land who can enter to us according to the custom of the whole world.
verses.textLa: Dixitque maior ad minorem: Pater noster senex est, et nullus virorum remansit in terra qui possit ingredi ad nos iuxta morem universæ terræ.

verses.textEn: Come, let us inebriate him with wine, and let us sleep with him, so that we may be able to preserve offspring from our father.”
verses.textLa: Veni, inebriemus eum vino, dormiamusque cum eo, ut servare possimus ex patre nostro semen.

verses.textEn: And so they gave their father wine to drink that night. And the elder went in, and she slept with her father. But he did not perceive it, neither when his daughter lay down, nor when she rose up.
verses.textLa: Dederunt itaque patri suo bibere vinum nocte illa: Et ingressa est maior, dormivitque cum patre: at ille non sensit, nec quando accubuit filia, nec quando surrexit.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the next day, the elder said to the younger: “Behold, yesterday I slept with my father, let us give him wine to drink yet again this night, and you will sleep with him, so that we may save offspring from our father.”
verses.textLa: Altera quoque die dixit maior ad minorem: Ecce dormivi heri cum patre meo, demus ei bibere vinum etiam hac nocte, et dormies cum eo, ut salvemus semen de patre nostro.

verses.textEn: And then they gave their father wine to drink that night also, and the younger daughter went in, and slept with him. And not even then did he perceive when she lay down, or when she rose up.
verses.textLa: Dederunt etiam et illa nocte patri suo bibere vinum, ingressaque minor filia, dormivit cum eo: et ne tunc quidem sensit quando concubuerit, vel quando illa surrexerit.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the two daughters of Lot conceived by their father.
verses.textLa: Conceperunt ergo duæ filiæ Lot de patre suo.

verses.textEn: And the elder gave birth to a son, and she called his name Moab. He is the father of the Moabites, even to the present day.
verses.textLa: Peperitque maior filium, et vocavit nomen eius Moab: ipse est pater Moabitarum usque in præsentem diem.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the younger gave birth to a son, and she called his name Ammon, that is, ‘the son of my people.’ He is the father of the Ammonites, even today.
verses.textLa: Minor quoque peperit filium, et vocavit nomen eius Ammon, id est, filius populi mei: ipse est pater Ammonitarum usque hodie.

verses.textEn: Abraham advanced from there into the southern land, and he lived between Kadesh and Shur. And he sojourned in Gerar.
verses.textLa: Profectus inde Abraham in terram australem, habitavit inter Cades, et Sur: et peregrinatus est in Geraris.

verses.textEn: And he said about his wife Sarah: “She is my sister.” Therefore, Abimelech, the king of Gerar, sent for her and took her.
verses.textLa: Dixitque de Sara uxore suo, Soror mea est. Misit ergo Abimelech rex Geraræ, et tulit eam.

verses.textEn: Then God came to Abimelech through a dream in the night, and he said to him: “Lo, you shall die because of the woman that you have taken. For she has a husband.”
verses.textLa: Venit autem Deus ad Abimelech per somnium nocte, et ait illi: En morieris propter mulierem, quam tulisti: habet enim virum.

verses.textEn: In truth, Abimelech had not touched her, and so he said: “Lord, would you put to death a people, ignorant and just?
verses.textLa: Abimelech vero non tetigerat eam, et ait: Domine, num gentem ignorantem et iustam interficies?

verses.textEn: Did he not say to me, ‘She is my sister,’ and did she not say, ‘He is my brother?’ In the sincerity of my heart and the purity of my hands, I have done this.”
verses.textLa: Nonne ipse dixit mihi: Soror mea est: et ipsa ait: Frater meus est? In simplictate cordis mei, et munditia manuum mearum feci hoc.

verses.textEn: And God said to him: “And I know that you have acted with a sincere heart. And therefore I kept you from sinning against me, and I did not release you to touch her.
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad eum Deus: Et ego scio quod simplici corde feceris: et ideo custodivi te ne peccares in me, et non dimisi ut tangeres eam.

verses.textEn: Now therefore, return his wife to the man, for he is a prophet. And he will pray for you, and you will live. But if you are not willing to return her, know this: you shall die a death, you and all that is yours.”
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo redde viro suo uxorem, quia propheta est: et orabit pro te, et vives: si autem nolueris reddere, scito quod morte morieris tu, et omnia quæ tua sunt.
verses.notes: The expression ‘morte morieris’ is repetitive because the king would die in two ways, by a mortal sin and by losing his mortal life.

verses.textEn: And immediately Abimelech, rising up in the night, called all his servants. And he spoke all these words in their hearing, and all the men were very afraid.
verses.textLa: Statimque de nocte consurgens Abimelech, vocavit omnes servos suos: et locutus est universa verba hæc in auribus eorum, timueruntque omnes viri valde.

verses.textEn: Then Abimelech called also for Abraham, and he said to him: “What have you done to us? How have we sinned against you, so that you would bring so great a sin upon me and upon my kingdom? You have done to us what you ought not to have done.”
verses.textLa: Vocavit autem Abimelech etiam Abraham, et dixit ei: Quid fecisti nobis? Quid peccavimus in te, quia induxisti super me et super regnum meum peccatum grande? Quæ non debuisti facere, fecisti nobis.

verses.textEn: And remonstrating him again, he said, “What did you see, so that you would do this?”
verses.textLa: Rursumque expostulans, ait: Quid vidisti, ut hoc faceres?

verses.textEn: Abraham responded: “I thought to myself, saying: Perhaps there is no fear of God in this place. And they will put me to death because of my wife.
verses.textLa: Respondit Abraham: Cogitavi mecum, dicens: Forsitan non est timor Dei in loco isto: et interficient me propter uxorem meam:

verses.textEn: Yet, in another way, she is also truly my sister, the daughter of my father, and not the daughter of my mother, and I took her as a wife.
verses.textLa: alias autem et vere soror mea est, filia patris mei, et non filia matris meæ, et duxi eam in uxorem.

verses.textEn: Then, after God led me out of my father’s house, I said to her: ‘You will show this mercy to me. In every place, to which we will travel, you will say that I am your brother.’ ”
verses.textLa: Postquam autem eduxit me Deus de domo patris mei, dixi ad eam: Hanc misericordiam facies mecum: In omni loco, ad quem ingrediemur, dices quod frater tuus sim.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Abimelech took sheep and oxen, and men servants and women servants, and he gave them to Abraham. And he returned his wife Sarah to him.
verses.textLa: Tulit igitur Abimelech oves et boves, et servos et ancillas, et dedit Abraham: reddiditque illi Saram uxorem suam,

verses.textEn: And he said, “The land is in your sight. Dwell wherever it will please you.”
verses.textLa: et ait: Terra coram vobis est, ubicumque tibi placuerit habita.

verses.textEn: Then to Sarah he said: “Behold, I have given your brother one thousand silver coins. This will be for you as a veil for your eyes, to all who are with you and wherever you will travel. And so, remember that you were taken.”
verses.textLa: Saræ autem dixit: Ecce mille argenteos dedi fratri tuo, hoc erit tibi in velamen oculorum ad omnes qui tecum sunt, et quocumque perrexeris: mementoque te deprehensam.

verses.textEn: Then when Abraham prayed, God healed Abimelech and his wife, and his handmaids, and they gave birth.
verses.textLa: Orante autem Abraham, sanavit Deus Abimelech et uxorem, ancillasque eius, et pepererunt:

verses.textEn: For the Lord had closed every womb of the house of Abimelech, because of Sarah, the wife of Abraham.
verses.textLa: concluserat enim Dominus omnem vulvam domus Abimelech propter Saram uxorem Abrahæ.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord visited Sarah, just as he had promised; and he fulfilled what he had spoken.
verses.textLa: Visitavit autem Dominus Saram, sicut promiserat: et implevit quæ locutus est.

verses.textEn: And she conceived and gave birth to a son in her old age, at the time that God had foretold to her.
verses.textLa: Concepitque et peperit filium in senectute sua, tempore quo prædixerat ei Deus.

verses.textEn: And Abraham called the name of his son, whom Sarah bore for him, Isaac.
verses.textLa: Vocavitque Abraham nomen filii sui, quem genuit ei Sara, Isaac:

verses.textEn: And he circumcised him on the eighth day, just as God had instructed him,
verses.textLa: et circumcidit eum octavo die, sicut præceperat ei Deus,

verses.textEn: when he was one hundred years old. Indeed, at this stage of his father’s life, Isaac was born.
verses.textLa: cum centum esset annorum: hac quippe ætate patris, natus est Isaac.

verses.textEn: And Sarah said: “God has brought laughter to me. Whoever will hear of it will laugh with me.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Sara: Risum fecit mihi Deus: quicumque audierit, corridebit mihi.

verses.textEn: And again, she said: “Hearing this, who would believe Abraham, that Sarah breast-fed a son, to whom she gave birth, despite being elderly?”
verses.textLa: Rursumque ait: Quis auditurus crederet Abraham quod Sara lactaret filium, quem peperit et iam seni?

verses.textEn: And the boy grew and was weaned. And Abraham made a great feast on the day of his weaning.
verses.textLa: Crevit igitur puer, et ablactatus est: fecitque Abraham grande convivium in die ablactationis eius.

verses.textEn: And when Sarah had seen the son of Hagar the Egyptian playing with her son Isaac, she said to Abraham:
verses.textLa: Cumque vidisset Sara filium Agar Ægyptiæ ludentem cum Isaac filio suo, dixit ad Abraham:

verses.textEn: “Cast out this woman servant and her son. For the son of a woman servant will not be heir with my son Isaac.”
verses.textLa: Eiice ancillam hanc, et filium eius: non enim erit heres filius ancillæ cum filio meo Isaac.

verses.textEn: Abraham took this grievously, for the sake of his son.
verses.textLa: Dure accepit hoc Abraham pro filio suo.

verses.textEn: And God said to him: “Let it not seem harsh to you concerning the boy and your woman servant. In all that Sarah has said to you, listen to her voice. For your offspring will be invoked in Isaac.
verses.textLa: Cui dixit Deus: Non tibi videatur asperum super puero, et super ancilla tua: omnia quæ dixerit tibi Sara, audi vocem eius: quia in Isaac vocabitur tibi semen.

verses.textEn: Yet I will also make the son of the woman servant into a great nation, for he is your offspring.”
verses.textLa: Sed et filium ancillæ faciam in gentem magnam, quia semen tuum est.

verses.textEn: And so Abraham arose in the morning, and taking bread and a skin of water, he placed it upon her shoulder, and he handed over the boy, and he released her. And when she had departed, she wandered in the wilderness of Beersheba.
verses.textLa: Surrexit itaque Abraham mane, et tollens panem et utrem aquæ, imposuit scapulæ eius, tradiditque puerum, et dimisit eam. Quæ cum abiisset, errabat in solitudine Bersabee.

verses.textEn: And when the water in the skin had been consumed, she set aside the boy, under one of the trees that were there.
verses.textLa: Cumque consumpta esset aqua in utre, abiecit puerum subter unam arborum, quæ ibi erant.

verses.textEn: And she moved away and sat in a distant area, as far as a bow can reach. For she said, “I shall not see the boy die.” And so, sitting opposite her, he lifted up his voice and wept.
verses.textLa: Et abiit, seditque e regione procul quantum potest arcus iacere. Dixit enim: Non videbo morientem puerum: et sedens contra, levavit vocem suam et flevit.

verses.textEn: But God heard the voice of the boy. And an Angel of God called to Hagar from heaven, saying: “What are you doing, Hagar? Do not be afraid. For God has heeded the voice of the boy, from the place where he is.
verses.textLa: Exaudivit autem Deus vocem pueri: vocavitque Angelus Dei Agar de cælo, dicens: Quid agis Agar? noli timere: exaudivit enim Deus vocem pueri de loco in quo est.

verses.textEn: Rise up. Take the boy and hold him by the hand. For I will make of him a great nation.”
verses.textLa: Surge, tolle puerum, et tene manum illius: quia in gentem magnam faciam eum.
