verses.textEn: And God opened her eyes. And seeing a well of water, she went and filled the skin, and she gave the boy to drink.
verses.textLa: Aperuitque oculos eius Deus: quæ videns puteum aquæ, abiit, et implevit utrem, deditque puero bibere.

verses.textEn: And God was with him. And he grew, and he stayed in the wilderness, and he became a young man, an archer.
verses.textLa: Et fuit cum eo: qui crevit, et moratus est in solitudine, factusque est iuvenis sagittarius.

verses.textEn: And he lived in the desert of Paran, and his mother took a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Habitavitque in deserto Pharan, et accepit illi mater sua uxorem de terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: At the same time, Abimelech and Phicol, the leader of his army, said to Abraham: “God is with you in everything that you do.
verses.textLa: Eodem tempore dixit Abimelech, et Phicol princeps exercitus eius ad Abraham: Deus tecum est in universis quæ agis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, swear by God that you will do no harm to me, and to my posterity, and to my stock. But according to the mercy that I have done to you, you will do to me and to the land, to which you have turned as a newcomer.”
verses.textLa: Iura ergo per Deum, ne noceas mihi, et posteris meis, stirpique meæ: sed iuxta misericordiam, quam feci tibi, facies mihi, et terræ in qua versatus es advena.

verses.textEn: And Abraham said, “I will swear.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Abraham: Ego iurabo.

verses.textEn: And he reproved Abimelech because of a well of water, which his servants had taken away by force.
verses.textLa: Et increpavit Abimelech propter puteum aquæ quem vi abstulerunt servi eius.

verses.textEn: And Abimelech responded, “I do not know who did this thing, but you also did not reveal it to me, nor have I heard of it, before today.”
verses.textLa: Responditque Abimelech: Nescivi quis fecerit hanc rem: sed et tu non indicasti mihi, et ego non audivi præter hodie.

verses.textEn: And so Abraham took sheep and oxen, and he gave them to Abimelech. And both of them struck a pact.
verses.textLa: Tulit itaque Abraham oves et boves, et dedit Abimelech: percusseruntque ambo fœdus.

verses.textEn: And Abraham set aside seven female lambs from the flock.
verses.textLa: Et statuit Abraham septem agnas gregis seorsum.

verses.textEn: Abimelech said to him, “What purpose have these seven female lambs, which you have caused to stand separately?”
verses.textLa: Cui dixit Abimelech: Quid sibi volunt septem agnæ istæ, quas stare fecisti seorsum?

verses.textEn: But he said, “You will receive seven female lambs from my hand, so that they may be a testimony for me, that I dug this well.”
verses.textLa: At ille: Septem, inquit, agnas accipies de manu mea: ut sint mihi in testimonium, quoniam ego fodi puteum istum.

verses.textEn: For this reason, that place was called Beersheba, because there both of them did swear.
verses.textLa: Idcirco vocatus est locus ille Bersabee: quia ibi uterque iuravit.

verses.textEn: And they initiated a pact on behalf of the well of oath.
verses.textLa: Et inierunt fœdus pro puteo iuramenti.

verses.textEn: Then Abimelech and Phicol, the leader of his army, rose up, and they returned to the land of the Palestinians. In truth, Abraham planted a grove in Beersheba, and there he called upon the name of the Lord God Eternal.
verses.textLa: Surrexit autem Abimelech, et Phicol princeps exercitus eius, reversique sunt in terram Palæstinorum. Abraham vero plantavit nemus in Bersabee, et invocavit ibi nomen Domini Dei æterni.

verses.textEn: And he was a settler in the land of the Palestinians for many days.
verses.textLa: Et fuit colonus terræ Palæstinorum diebus multis.

verses.textEn: After these things occurred, God tested Abraham, and he said to him, “Abraham, Abraham.” And he answered, “Here I am.”
verses.textLa: Quæ postquam gesta sunt, tentavit Deus Abraham, et dixit ad eum: Abraham, Abraham. At ille respondit: Adsum.

verses.textEn: He said to him: “Take your only begotten son Isaac, whom you love, and go into the land of vision. And there you shall offer him as a holocaust upon one of the mountains, which I will show to you.”
verses.textLa: Ait illi: Tolle filium tuum unigenitum, quem diligis, Isaac, et vade in terram visionis: atque ibi offeres eum in holocaustum super unum montium quem monstravero tibi.

verses.textEn: And so Abraham, getting up in the night, harnessed his donkey, taking with him two youths, and his son Isaac. And when he had cut wood for the holocaust, he traveled toward the place, as God had instructed him.
verses.textLa: Igitur Abraham de nocte consurgens, stravit asinum suum: ducens secum duos iuvenes, et Isaac filium suum: cumque concidisset ligna in holocaustum, abiit ad locum quem præceperat ei Deus.

verses.textEn: Then, on the third day, lifting up his eyes, he saw the place at a distance.
verses.textLa: Die autem tertio, elevatis oculis, vidit locum procul:

verses.textEn: And he said to his servants: “Wait here with the donkey. I and the boy will hurry further ahead to that place. After we have worshipped, will return to you.”
verses.textLa: dixitque ad pueros suos: Expectate hic cum asino: ego et puer illuc usque properantes, postquam adoraverimus, revertemur ad vos.

verses.textEn: He also took the wood for the holocaust, and he imposed it upon his son Isaac. And he himself carried in his hands fire and a sword. And as the two continued on together,
verses.textLa: Tulit quoque ligna holocausti, et imposuit super Isaac filium suum: ipse vero portabat in manibus ignem et gladium. Cumque duo pergerent simul,

verses.textEn: Isaac said to his father, “My father.” And he answered, “What do you want, son?” “Behold,” he said, “fire and wood. Where is the victim for the holocaust?”
verses.textLa: dixit Isaac patri suo: Pater mi. At ille respondit: Quid vis fili? Ecce, inquit, ignis et ligna: ubi est victima holocausti?

verses.textEn: But Abraham said, “God himself will provide the victim for the holocaust, my son.” Thus they continued on together.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Abraham: Deus providebit sibi victimam holocausti, fili mi. Pergebant ergo pariter:

verses.textEn: And they came to the place that God had shown to him. There he built an altar, and he set the wood in order upon it. And when he had bound his son Isaac, he laid him on the altar upon the pile of wood.
verses.textLa: et venerunt ad locum quem ostenderat ei Deus, in quo ædificavit altare, et desuper ligna composuit: cumque alligasset Isaac filium suum, posuit eum in altare super struem lignorum.

verses.textEn: And he reached out his hand and took hold of the sword, in order to sacrifice his son.
verses.textLa: Extenditque manum, et arripuit gladium, ut immolaret filium suum.

verses.textEn: And behold, an Angel of the Lord called out from heaven, saying, “Abraham, Abraham.” And he answered, “Here I am.”
verses.textLa: Et ecce Angelus Domini de cælo clamavit, dicens: Abraham, Abraham. Qui respondit: Adsum.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, “Do not extend your hand over the boy, and do not do anything to him. Now I know that you fear God, since you have not spared your only begotten son for my sake.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ei: Non extendas manum tuam super puerum, neque facias illi quidquam: nunc cognovi quod times Deum, et non pepercisti unigenito filio tuo propter me.

verses.textEn: Abraham lifted up his eyes, and he saw behind his back a ram among the thorns, caught by the horns, which he took and offered as a holocaust, instead of his son.
verses.textLa: Levavit Abraham oculos suos, viditque post tergum arietem inter vepres hærentem cornibus, quem assumens obtulit holocaustum pro filio.

verses.textEn: And he called the name of that place: ‘The Lord Sees.’ Thus, even to this day, it is said: ‘On the mountain, the Lord will see.’
verses.textLa: Appellavitque nomen loci illius, Dominus videt. Unde usque hodie dicitur: In monte Dominus videbit.

verses.textEn: Then the Angel of the Lord called out to Abraham a second time from heaven, saying:
verses.textLa: Vocavit autem Angelus Domini Abraham secundo de cælo, dicens:.

verses.textEn: “By my own self, I have sworn, says the Lord. Because you have done this thing, and have not spared your only begotten son for my sake,
verses.textLa: Per memetipsum iuravi, dicit Dominus: quia fecisti hanc rem, et non pepercisti filio tuo unigenito propter me:

verses.textEn: I will bless you, and I will multiply your offspring like the stars of heaven, and like the sand which is on the seashore. Your offspring will possess the gates of their enemies.
verses.textLa: benedicam tibi, et multiplicabo semen tuum sicut stellas cæli, et velut arenam quæ est in littore maris: possidebit semen tuum portas inimicorum suorum,

verses.textEn: And in your offspring, all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you obeyed my voice.”
verses.textLa: et benedicentur in semine tuo omnes gentes terræ, quia obedisti voci meæ.

verses.textEn: Abraham returned to his servants, and they went to Beersheba together, and he lived there.
verses.textLa: Reversus est Abraham ad pueros suos, abieruntque Bersabee simul, et habitavit ibi.

verses.textEn: After these things occurred, it was reported to Abraham that Milcah, likewise, had borne sons for his brother Nahor:
verses.textLa: His ita gestis, nunciatum est Abrahæ quod Melcha quoque genuisset filios Nachor fratri suo,

verses.textEn: Uz, the firstborn, and Buz, his brother, and Kemuel, the father of the Syrians,
verses.textLa: Hus primogenitum, et Buz fratrem eius, et Camuel patrem Syrorum,

verses.textEn: and Chesed, and Hazo, likewise Pildash, and Jidlaph,
verses.textLa: et Cased, et Azau, Pheldas quoque et Iedlaph,

verses.textEn: as well as Bethuel, of whom was born Rebekah. These eight Milcah bore for Nahor, the brother of Abraham.
verses.textLa: ac Bathuel, de quo nata est Rebecca: octo istos genuit Melcha, Nachor fratri Abrahæ.
verses.notes: The name Bethuel is male; the expression ‘de quo nata est’ does not imply that Bethuel is female. The verb merely indicates that he fathered Rebecca, it does not refer specifically to being pregnant nor to giving birth.

verses.textEn: In truth, his concubine, named Reumah, bore Tebah, and Gaham, and Tahash, and Maacah.
verses.textLa: Concubina vero illius, nomine Roma, peperit Tabee, et Gaham, et Tahas, et Maacha.

verses.textEn: Now Sarah lived for one hundred and twenty-seven years.
verses.textLa: Vixit autem Sara centum viginti septem annis.

verses.textEn: And she died in the city of Arba, which is Hebron, in the land of Canaan. And Abraham came to mourn and weep for her.
verses.textLa: Et mortua est in civitate Arbee, quæ est Hebron, in terra Chanaan: venitque Abraham ut plangeret, et fleret eam.

verses.textEn: And when he had risen up from the funeral duties, he spoke to the sons of Heth, saying:
verses.textLa: Cumque surrexisset ab officio funeris, locutus est ad filios Heth, dicens:

verses.textEn: “I am a newcomer and a sojourner among you. Give me the right of a sepulcher among you, so that I may bury my dead.”
verses.textLa: Advena sum et peregrinus apud vos: date mihi ius sepulchri vobiscum, ut sepeliam mortuum meum.

verses.textEn: The sons of Heth responded by saying:
verses.textLa: Responderunt filii Heth, dicentes:

verses.textEn: “Hear us, O lord, you are a leader of God among us. Bury your dead in our chosen sepulchers. And no man shall be able to prohibit you from burying your dead within his memorial.”
verses.textLa: Audi nos domine, princeps Dei es apud nos: in electis sepulchris nostris sepeli mortuum tuum: nullusque te prohibere poterit quin in monumento eius sepelias mortuum tuum.

verses.textEn: Abraham arose, and he reverenced the people of the land, namely, the sons of Heth.
verses.textLa: Surrexit Abraham, et adoravit populum terræ, filios videlicet Heth:

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “If it pleases your soul that I should bury my dead, hear me, and intercede on my behalf with Ephron, the son of Zohar,
verses.textLa: dixitque ad eos: Si placet animæ vestræ ut sepeliam mortuum meum, audite me, et intercedite pro me apud Ephron filium Seor:

verses.textEn: so that he may give me the double cave, which he has at the far end of his field. He may transfer it to me for as much money as it is worth in your sight, for the possession of a sepulcher.”
verses.textLa: ut det mihi speluncam duplicem, quam habet in extrema parte agri sui: pecunia digna tradat eam mihi coram vobis in possessionem sepulchri.

verses.textEn: Now Ephron dwelt in the midst of the sons of Heth. And Ephron responded to Abraham in the hearing of everyone who was entering at the gate of his city, saying:
verses.textLa: Habitabat autem Ephron in medio filiorum Heth. Responditque Ephron ad Abraham cunctis audientibus qui ingrediebantur portam civitatis illius, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Let it never be so, my lord, but you should pay greater heed to what I say. The field I will transfer to you, and the cave that is in it. In the presence of the sons of my people, bury your dead.”
verses.textLa: Nequaquam ita fiat, domine mi, sed tu magis ausculta quod loquor: Agrum trado tibi, et speluncam, quæ in eo est, præsentibus filiis populi mei, sepeli mortuum tuum.

verses.textEn: Abraham reverenced in the sight of the people of the land.
verses.textLa: Adoravit Abraham coram populo terræ.

verses.textEn: And he spoke to Ephron, standing in the midst of the people: “I ask you to hear me. I will give you money for the field. Take it, and so I will bury my dead in it.”
verses.textLa: Et locutus est ad Ephron circumstante plebe: Quæso, ut audias me: Dabo pecuniam pro agro: suscipe eam, et sic sepeliam mortuum meum in eo.

verses.textEn: And Ephron responded: “My lord, hear me.
verses.textLa: Responditque Ephron: Domine mi, audi me:

verses.textEn: The land that you request is worth four hundred shekels of silver. This is the price between me and you. But how much is this? Bury your dead.”
verses.textLa: Terra, quam postulas, quadringentis siclis argenti valet: istud est pretium inter me et te: sed quantum est hoc? sepeli mortuum tuum.

verses.textEn: And when Abraham had heard this, he weighed out the money that Ephron had requested, in the hearing of the sons of Heth, four hundred shekels of silver, of the approved public currency.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset Abraham, appendit pecuniam, quam Ephron postulaverat, audientibus filiis Heth, quadringentos siclos argenti probatæ monetæ publicæ.

verses.textEn: And having confirmed that the field, in which there was a double cave overlooking Mamre, formerly belonged to Ephron, both it and the sepulcher, and all its trees, with all its surrounding limits,
verses.textLa: Confirmatusque est ager quondam Ephronis, in quo erat spelunca duplex, respiciens Mambre, tam ipse, quam spelunca, et omnes arbores eius in cunctis terminis eius per circuitum,

verses.textEn: Abraham took it as a possession, in the sight of the sons of Heth and of everyone who was entering at the gate of his city.
verses.textLa: Abrahæ in possessionem, videntibus filiis Heth, et cunctis qui intrabant portam civitatis illius.

verses.textEn: So then, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the double cave of the field that overlooked Mamre. This is Hebron in the land of Canaan.
verses.textLa: Atque ita sepelivit Abraham Saram uxorem suam in spelunca agri duplici, quæ respiciebat Mambre. Hæc est Hebron in terra Chanaan.

verses.textEn: And the field was confirmed to Abraham, with the cave that was in it, as a memorial possession before the sons of Heth.
verses.textLa: Et confirmatus est ager, et antrum, quod erat in eo, Abrahæ in possessionem monumenti a filiis Heth.

verses.textEn: Now Abraham was old and of many days. And the Lord had blessed him in all things.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Abraham senex, dierumque multorum: et Dominus in cunctis benedixerat ei.

verses.textEn: And he said to the elder servant of his house, who was in charge of all that he had: “Place your hand under my thigh,
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad servum seniorem domus suæ, qui præerat omnibus quæ habebat: Pone manum tuam subter femur meum,

verses.textEn: so that I may make you swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and earth, that you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I live.
verses.textLa: ut adiurem te per Dominum, Deum cæli et terræ, ut non accipias uxorem filio meo de filiabus Chananæorum, inter quos habito:

verses.textEn: But that you will proceed to my land and kindred, and from there take a wife for my son Isaac.”
verses.textLa: sed ad terram et cognationem meam proficiscaris, et inde accipias uxorem filio meo Isaac.

verses.textEn: The servant responded, “If the woman is not willing to come with me into this land, must I lead your son back to the place from which you departed?”
verses.textLa: Respondit servus: Si noluerit mulier venire mecum in terram hanc, numquid reducere debeo filium tuum ad locum, de quo egressus es?

verses.textEn: And Abraham said: “Beware that you never lead my son back to that place.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Abraham: Cave nequando reducas filium meum illuc.

verses.textEn: The Lord God of heaven, who took me from my father’s house, and from the land of my nativity, who spoke to me and swore to me, saying, ‘To your offspring I will give this land,’ himself will send his Angel before you, and you will take from there a wife for my son.
verses.textLa: Dominus Deus cæli, qui tulit me de domo patris mei, et de terra nativitatis meæ, qui locutus est mihi, et iuravit mihi, dicens: Semini tuo dabo terram hanc: ipse mittet Angelum suum coram te, et accipies inde uxorem filio meo:

verses.textEn: But if the woman is not willing to follow you, you will not be held by the oath. Only do not lead my son back to that place.”
verses.textLa: sin autem mulier noluerit sequi te, non teneberis iuramento: filium meum tantum ne reducas illuc.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the servant placed his hand under the thigh of Abraham, his lord, and he swore to him on his word.
verses.textLa: Posuit ergo servus manum sub femore Abraham domini sui, et iuravit illi super sermone hoc.

verses.textEn: And he took ten camels from his lord’s herd, and he went forth, carrying with him things from all of his goods. And he set out, and continued on, to the city of Nahor, in Mesopotamia.
verses.textLa: Tulitque decem camelos de grege domini sui, et abiit, ex omnibus bonis eius portans secum, profectusque perrexit in Mesopotamiam ad urbem Nachor.

verses.textEn: And when he had made the camels lie down outside of the town, near a well of water, in the evening, at the time when women are accustomed to go out to draw water, he said:
verses.textLa: Cumque camelos fecisset accumbere extra oppidum iuxta puteum aquæ vespere, tempore quo solent mulieres egredi ad hauriendam aquam, dixit:

verses.textEn: “O Lord, the God of my lord Abraham, meet with me today, I beg you, and show mercy to my lord Abraham.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus domini mei Abraham, occurre, obsecro, mihi hodie, et fac misericordiam cum domino meo Abraham.

verses.textEn: Behold, I stand near the fountain of water, and the daughters of the inhabitants of this city will go forth to draw water.
verses.textLa: Ecce ego sto prope fontem aquæ, et filiæ habitatorum huius civitatis egredientur ad hauriendam aquam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the girl to whom I will say, ‘Tip your pitcher, so that I may drink,’ and she will respond, ‘Drink. In fact, I will give your camels a drink also,’ the same one is she whom you have prepared for your servant Isaac. And by this, I will understand that you have shown mercy to my lord.”
verses.textLa: Igitur puella, cui ego dixero: Inclina hydriam tuam ut bibam: et illa responderit, Bibe, quin et camelis tuis dabo potum: ipsa est, quam præparasti servo tuo Isaac: et per hoc intelligam quod feceris misericordiam cum domino meo.

verses.textEn: But he had not yet completed these words within himself, when, behold, Rebekah went out, the daughter of Bethuel, son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, the brother of Abraham, having a pitcher on her shoulder.
verses.textLa: Necdum intra se verba compleverat, et ecce Rebecca egrediebatur, filia Bathuel, filii Melchæ uxoris Nachor fratris Abraham, habens hydriam in scapula sua:

verses.textEn: She was an exceedingly elegant girl, and a most beautiful virgin, and unknown by man. And she descended to the spring, and she filled her pitcher, and then was returning.
verses.textLa: puella decora nimis, virgoque pulcherrima, et incognita viro: descenderat autem ad fontem, et impleverat hydriam, ac revertebatur.

verses.textEn: And the servant ran to meet her, and he said, “Provide me with a little water to drink from your pitcher.”
verses.textLa: Occurritque ei servus, et ait: Pauxillum aquæ mihi ad bibendum præbe de hydria tua.

verses.textEn: And she responded, “Drink, my lord.” And she quickly brought down the pitcher on her arm, and she gave him a drink.
verses.textLa: Quæ respondit: Bibe domine mi. Celeriterque deposuit hydriam super ulnam suam, et dedit ei potum.

verses.textEn: And after he drank, she added, “In fact, I will draw water for your camels also, until they all drink.”
verses.textLa: Cumque ille bibisset, adiecit: Quin et camelis tuis hauriam aquam, donec cuncti bibant.

verses.textEn: And pouring out the pitcher into the troughs, she ran back to the well to draw water; and having drawn, she gave it to all the camels.
verses.textLa: Effundensque hydriam in canalibus, recurrit ad puteum ut hauriret aquam: et haustam omnibus camelis dedit.

verses.textEn: But he was contemplating her silently, wanting to know whether the Lord had caused his journey to prosper or not
verses.textLa: Ipse autem contemplabatur eam tacitus, scire volens utrum prosperum iter suum fecisset Dominus, an non.

verses.textEn: Then, after the camels drank, the man took out gold earrings, weighing two shekels, and the same number of bracelets, ten shekels in weight.
verses.textLa: Postquam autem biberunt cameli, protulit vir inaures aureas, appendentes siclos duos, et armillas totidem pondo siclorum decem.

verses.textEn: And he said to her: “Whose daughter are you? Tell me, is there any place in your father’s house to lodge?”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad eam: Cuius es filia? indica mihi: est in domo patris tui locus ad manendum?

verses.textEn: She responded, “I am the daughter of Bethuel, the son of Milcah, to whom she gave birth for Nahor.”
verses.textLa: Quæ respondit: Filia sum Bathuelis, filii Melchæ, quem peperit ipsi Nachor.

verses.textEn: And she continued, saying, “There is very much straw and hay with us, and a spacious place to stay.”
verses.textLa: Et addidit, dicens: Palearum quoque et fœni plurimum est apud nos, et locus spatiosus ad manendum.

verses.textEn: The man bowed himself down, and he adored the Lord,
verses.textLa: Inclinavit se homo, et adoravit Dominum,

verses.textEn: saying, “Blessed be the Lord, the God of my lord Abraham, who has not taken away his mercy and truth from my lord, and who has led me on a direct journey to the house of the brother of my lord.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Benedictus Dominus Deus domini mei Abraham, qui non abstulit misericordiam et veritatem suam a domino meo, et recto itinere me perduxit in domum fratris domini mei.

verses.textEn: And so the girl ran, and she reported all that she had heard in the house of her mother.
verses.textLa: Cucurrit itaque puella, et nunciavit in domum matris suæ omnia quæ audierat.

verses.textEn: Now Rebekah had a brother, named Laban, who went out quickly to the man, where the spring was.
verses.textLa: Habebat autem Rebecca fratrem nomine Laban, qui festinus egressus est ad hominem, ubi erat fons.

verses.textEn: And when he had seen the earrings and bracelets in his sister’s hands, and he had heard all the words being repeated, “This is what the man spoke to me,” he came to the man who stood by the camels and near the spring of water,
verses.textLa: Cumque vidisset inaures et armillas in manibus sororis suæ, et audisset cuncta verba referentis: Hæc locutus est mihi homo: venit ad virum, qui stabat iuxta camelos, et prope fontem aquæ:

verses.textEn: and he said to him: “Enter, O blessed of the Lord. Why do you stand outside? I have prepared the house, and a place for the camels.”
verses.textLa: dixitque ad eum: Ingredere, benedicte Domini: cur foris stas? præparavi domum, et locum camelis.

verses.textEn: And he brought him into his guest quarters. And he unharnessed the camels, and he distributed straw and hay, and water to wash his feet and that of the men who arrived with him.
verses.textLa: Et introduxit eum in hospitium: ac destravit camelos, deditque paleas et fœnum, et aquam ad lavandos pedes eius, et virorum qui venerant cum eo.

verses.textEn: And bread was set out in his sight. But he said, “I will not eat, until I have spoken my words.” He answered him, “Speak.”
verses.textLa: Et appositus est in conspectu eius panis. Qui ait: Non comedam, donec loquar sermones meos. Respondit ei: Loquere.

verses.textEn: Then he said: “I am the servant of Abraham.
verses.textLa: At ille: Servus, inquit, Abraham sum:

verses.textEn: And the Lord has blessed my lord greatly, and he has become great. And he has given him sheep and oxen, silver and gold, men servants and women servants, camels and donkeys.
verses.textLa: et Dominus benedixit domino meo valde, magnificatusque est: et dedit ei oves et boves, argentum et aurum, servos et ancillas, camelos et asinos.

verses.textEn: And Sarah, the wife of my lord, has given birth to a son for my lord in her old age, and he has given him all that he had.
verses.textLa: Et peperit Sara uxor domini mei filium domino meo in senectute sua, deditque illi omnia quæ habuerat.

verses.textEn: And my lord made me swear, saying: ‘You shall not take a wife for my son from the Canaanites, in whose land I dwell.
verses.textLa: Et adiuravit me dominus meus, dicens: Non accipies uxorem filio meo de filiabus Chananæorum, in quorum terra habito:

verses.textEn: But you shall travel to my father’s house, and you shall take a wife of my own kindred for my son.’
verses.textLa: sed ad domum patris mei perges, et de cognatione mea accipies uxorem filio meo:

verses.textEn: But truly, I answered my lord, ‘What if the woman is not willing to come with me?’
verses.textLa: ego vero respondi domino meo: Quid si noluerit venire mecum mulier?

verses.textEn: ‘The Lord,’ he said, ‘in whose sight I walk, will send his Angel with you, and he will direct your way. And you shall take a wife for my son from my own kindred and from my father’s house.
verses.textLa: Dominus, ait, in cuius conspectu ambulo, mittet Angelum suum tecum, et diriget viam tuam: accipiesque uxorem filio meo de cognatione mea, et de domo patris mei.

verses.textEn: But you will be innocent of my curse, if, when you will arrive at my close relatives, they will not grant this to you.’
verses.textLa: Innocens eris a maledictione mea, cum veneris ad propinquos meos, et non dederint tibi.

verses.textEn: And so, today I arrived at the well of water, and I said: ‘O Lord, the God of my lord Abraham, if you have directed my way, in which I now walk,
verses.textLa: Veni ergo hodie ad fontem aquæ, et dixi: Domine Deus domini mei Abraham, si direxisti viam meam, in qua nunc ambulo,

verses.textEn: behold, I stand next to the well of water, and the virgin, who will go forth to draw water, will hear from me, “Give me a little water to drink from your pitcher.”
verses.textLa: ecce sto iuxta fontem aquæ, et virgo, quæ egredietur ad hauriendam aquam, audierit a me: Da mihi pauxillum aquæ ad bibendum ex hydria tua:

verses.textEn: And she will say to me, “You drink, and I will also draw for your camels.” Let the same be the woman, whom the Lord has prepared for the son of my lord.’
verses.textLa: et dixerit mihi: Et tu bibe, et camelis tuis hauriam: ipsa est mulier quam præparavit Dominus filio domini mei.

verses.textEn: And while I thought over these things silently within myself, Rebekah appeared, arriving with a pitcher, which she carried on her shoulder. And she descended to the spring and drew water. And I said to her, ‘Give me a little to drink.’
verses.textLa: Dumque hæc tacitus mecum volverem, apparuit Rebecca veniens cum hydria, quam portabat in scapula: descenditque ad fontem, et hausit aquam. Et aio ad eam: Da mihi paululum bibere.

verses.textEn: And she quickly let down the pitcher from her arm, and said to me, ‘You drink, and to your camels I will also distribute drinking water.’ I drank, and she watered the camels.
verses.textLa: Quæ festinans deposuit hydriam de humero, et dixit mihi: Et tu bibe, et camelis tuis tribuam potum. Bibi, et adaquavit camelos.

verses.textEn: And I questioned her, saying, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ And she responded, ‘I am the daughter of Bethuel, the son of Nahor, whom Milcah bore to him.’ And so, I hung the earrings on her, to adorn her face, and I put the bracelets on her hands.
verses.textLa: Interrogavique eam, et dixi: Cuius es filia? Quæ respondit: Filia Bathuelis sum, filii Nachor, quem peperit ei Melcha. Suspendi itaque inaures ad ornandam faciem eius, et armillas posui in manibus eius.
verses.notes: God gives us this same story twice, the second time in the servant’s recount of the events. Now both accounts are infallible Sacred Scripture, yet they differ somewhat in the wording of the quotations and in the words used to describe the events. This passage teaches us that quotations are not exact word-for-word recounts of what was said, but are a way of describing events and the attitudes of different persons.

verses.textEn: And falling prostrate, I adored the Lord, blessing the Lord, the God of my lord Abraham, who has led me along the straight path so as to take the daughter of my lord’s brother to his son.
verses.textLa: Pronusque adoravi Dominum, benedicens Domino Deo domini mei Abraham, qui perduxit me recto itinere, ut sumerem filiam fratris domini mei filio eius.

verses.textEn: For this reason, if you would act according to mercy and truth with my lord, tell me so. But if it pleases you otherwise, say that to me also, so that I may go either to the right, or to the left.”
verses.textLa: Quam ob rem si facitis misericordiam et veritatem cum domino meo, indicate mihi: sin autem aliud placet, et hoc dicite mihi, ut vadam ad dextram, sive ad sinistram.

verses.textEn: And Laban and Bethuel responded: “A word has proceeded from the Lord. We are not able to speak anything else to you, beyond what pleases him.
verses.textLa: Responderuntque Laban et Bathuel: A Domino egressus est sermo: non possumus extra placitum eius quidquam aliud loqui tecum.

verses.textEn: Lo, Rebekah is in your sight. Take her and continue on, and let her be the wife of the son of your lord, just as the Lord has spoken.”
verses.textLa: En Rebecca coram te est, tolle eam, et proficiscere, et sit uxor filii domini tui, sicut locutus est Dominus.

verses.textEn: When Abraham’s servant had heard this, falling down to the ground, he adored the Lord.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset puer Abraham, procidens adoravit in terram Dominum.

verses.textEn: And bringing forth vessels of silver and gold, as well as garments, he gave them to Rebekah as a tribute. Likewise, he offered gifts to her brothers and her mother.
verses.textLa: Prolatisque vasis argenteis, et aureis, ac vestibus, dedit ea Rebecca pro munere: fratribus quoque eius, et matri dona obtulit.

verses.textEn: And a banquet began, and they feasted and drank together, and they lodged there. And rising up in the morning, the servant said, “Release me, so that I may go to my lord.”
verses.textLa: Inito convivio, vescentes pariter et bibentes manserunt ibi. Surgens autem mane, locutus est puer: Dimitte me, ut vadam ad dominum meum.

verses.textEn: And her brothers and mother responded, “Let the girl remain for at least ten days with us, and after that, she will continue on.”
verses.textLa: Responderuntque fratres eius, et mater: Maneat puella saltem decem dies apud nos, et postea proficiscetur.

verses.textEn: “Do not be willing,” he said, “to delay me, for the Lord has directed my way. Release me, so that I may journey to my lord.”
verses.textLa: Nolite, ait, me retinere, quia Dominus direxit viam meam: dimittite me ut pergam ad dominum meum.

verses.textEn: And they said, “Let us call the girl, and ask her will.”
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt: Vocemus puellam, et quæramus ipsius voluntatem.

verses.textEn: And when, having been called, she arrived, they wanted to know, “Will you go with this man?” And she said, “I will go.”
verses.textLa: Cumque vocata venisset, sciscitati sunt: Vis ire cum homine isto? Quæ ait: Vadam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they released her and her nurse, and the servant of Abraham and his companions,
verses.textLa: Dimiserunt ergo eam, et nutricem illius, servumque Abraham, et comites eius,

verses.textEn: wishing prosperity for their sister, by saying: “You are our sister. May you increase to thousands of thousands. And may your offspring possess the gates of their enemies.”
verses.textLa: imprecantes prospera sorori suæ, atque dicentes: Soror nostra es, crescas in mille millia, et possideat semen tuum portas inimicorum suorum.

verses.textEn: And so, Rebekah and her maids, riding upon camels, followed the man, who quickly returned to his lord.
verses.textLa: Igitur Rebecca, et puellæ illius, ascensis camelis, secutæ sunt virum: qui festinus revertebatur ad dominum suum:

verses.textEn: Then, at the same time, Isaac was walking along the way that leads to the well, whose name is: ‘of the One who lives and who sees.’ For he dwelt in the southern land.
verses.textLa: eo autem tempore deambulabat Isaac per viam quæ ducit ad Puteum, cuius nomen est Viventis, et videntis: habitabat enim in terra australi:

verses.textEn: And he had gone out to meditate in the field, as daylight was now declining. And when he had lifted up his eyes, he saw camels advancing from afar.
verses.textLa: et egressus fuerat ad meditandum in agro, inclinata iam die: cumque elevasset oculos, vidit camelos venientes procul.

verses.textEn: Likewise, Rebekah, having seen Isaac, descended from the camel.
verses.textLa: Rebecca quoque, conspecto Isaac, descendit de camelo,

verses.textEn: And she said to the servant, “Who is that man who advances to meet us through the field?” And he said to her, “That is my lord.” And so, quickly taking up her cloak, she covered herself.
verses.textLa: et ait ad puerum: Quis est ille homo qui venit per agrum in occursum nobis? Dixitque ei: Ipse est dominus meus. At illa tollens cito pallium, operuit se.

verses.textEn: Then the servant explained to Isaac all that he had done.
verses.textLa: Servus autem cuncta, quæ gesserat, narravit Isaac.

verses.textEn: And he led her into the tent of Sarah his mother, and he accepted her as wife. And he loved her so very much, that it tempered the sorrow which befell him at his mother’s death.
verses.textLa: Qui introduxit eam in tabernaculum Saræ matris suæ, et accepit eam uxorem: et in tantum dilexit eam, ut dolorem, qui ex morte matris eius acciderat, temperaret.

verses.textEn: In truth, Abraham took another wife, named Keturah.
verses.textLa: Abraham vero aliam duxit uxorem nomine Ceturam:

verses.textEn: And she bore to him Zimran, and Jokshan, and Medan, and Midian, and Ishbak, and Shuah.
verses.textLa: quæ peperit ei Zamran et Iecsan, et Madam, et Madian, et Iesboc, et Sue.

verses.textEn: Likewise, Jokshan conceived Sheba and Dedan. The sons of Dedan were Asshurim, and Letushim, and Leummim.
verses.textLa: Iecsan quoque genuit Saba, et Dadan. Filii Dadan fuerunt Assurim, et Latusim, et Loomin.

verses.textEn: And truly, from Midian was born Ephah, and Epher, and Hanoch, and Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the sons of Keturah.
verses.textLa: At vero ex Madian ortus est Epha, et Opher, et Henoch, et Abida, et Eldaa: omnes hi filii Ceturæ.

verses.textEn: And Abraham gave everything that he possessed to Isaac.
verses.textLa: Deditque Abraham cuncta quæ possederat, Isaac:

verses.textEn: But to the sons of the concubines he gave generous gifts, and he separated them from his son Isaac, while he still lived, toward the eastern region.
verses.textLa: filiis autem concubinarum largitus est munera, et separavit eos ab Isaac filio suo, dum adhuc ipse viveret, ad plagam orientalem.

verses.textEn: Now the days of Abraham’s life were one hundred and seventy-five years.
verses.textLa: Fuerunt autem dies vitæ Abrahæ, centum septuaginta quinque anni.

verses.textEn: And declining, he died in a good old age, and at an advanced stage of life, and full of days. And he was gathered to his people.
verses.textLa: Et deficiens mortuus est in senectute bona, provectæque ætatis, et plenus dierum: congregatusque est ad populum suum.
verses.notes: The word ‘declining’ indicates that he died of natural causes and of old age.

verses.textEn: And his sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the double cave, which was situated in the field of Ephron, of the son of Zohar the Hittite, across from the region of Mamre,
verses.textLa: Et sepelierunt eum Isaac et Ismael filii sui in spelunca duplici, quæ sita est in agro Ephron filii Seor Hethæi, e regione Mambre,

verses.textEn: which he had bought from the sons of Heth. There he was buried, with his wife Sarah.
verses.textLa: quem emerat a filiis Heth: ibi sepultus est ipse, et Sara uxor eius.
verses.notes: Here is an example of the word ‘et’ translated as ‘with,’ rather than ‘and.’

verses.textEn: And after his passing, God blessed his son Isaac, who lived near the well named ‘of the One who lives and who sees.’
verses.textLa: Et post obitum illius benedixit Deus Isaac filio eius, qui habitabat iuxta puteum nomine Viventis et videntis.
verses.notes: The words ‘viventis’ and ‘videntis’ are participles (‘living’ and ‘seeing’). However, participles in Latin are often used as nouns, to refer to the person or persons to whom the action of the verb is attributed.

verses.textEn: These are the generations of Ishmael, the son of Abraham, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s servant, bore to him.
verses.textLa: Hæ sunt generationes Ismael filii Abrahæ, quem peperit ei Agar Ægyptia, famula Saræ: et

verses.textEn: And these are the names of his sons according to their language and generations. The firstborn of Ishmael was Nebaioth, then Kedar, and Adbeel, and Mibsam,
verses.textLa: hæc nomina filiorum eius in vocabulis et generationibus suis. Primogenitus Ismaelis Nabaioth, deinde Cedar, et Adbeel, et Mabsam,

verses.textEn: likewise Mishma, and Dumah, and Massa,
verses.textLa: Masma quoque, et Duma, et Massa,

verses.textEn: Hadad, and Tema, and Jetur, and Naphish, and Kedemah.
verses.textLa: Hadar, et Thema, et Iethur, et Naphis, et Cedma.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of Ishmael. And these are their names throughout their fortresses and towns: the twelve princes of their tribes.
verses.textLa: Isti sunt filii Ismaelis: et hæc nomina per castella et oppida eorum, duodecim principes tribuum suarum.

verses.textEn: And the years of the life of Ishmael that passed were one hundred and thirty-seven. And declining, he died and was placed with his people.
verses.textLa: Et facti sunt anni vitæ Ismaelis centum triginta septem, deficiensque mortuus est, et appositus ad populum suum.

verses.textEn: Now he had lived from Havilah as far as Shur, which overlooks Egypt as it approaches the Assyrians. He passed away in the sight of all his brothers.
verses.textLa: Habitavit autem ab Hevila usque Sur, quæ respicit Ægyptum introeuntibus Assyrios. Coram cunctis fratribus suis obiit.

verses.textEn: Likewise, these are the generations of Isaac, the son of Abraham. Abraham conceived Isaac,
verses.textLa: Hæ quoque sunt generationes Isaac filii Abraham: Abraham genuit Isaac:

verses.textEn: who, when he was forty years old, took Rebekah, the sister of Laban, the daughter of Bethuel the Syrian from Mesopotamia, as a wife.
verses.textLa: qui cum quadraginta esset annorum, duxit uxorem Rebeccam filiam Bathuelis Syri de Mesopotamia, sororem Laban.

verses.textEn: And Isaac beseeched the Lord on behalf of his wife, because she was barren. And he heard him, and he gave conception to Rebekah.
verses.textLa: Deprecatusque est Isaac Dominum pro uxore sua, eo quod esset sterilis: qui exaudivit eum, et dedit conceptum Rebeccæ.

verses.textEn: But the little ones struggled in her womb. So she said, “If it was to be so with me, what need was there to conceive?” And she went to consult the Lord.
verses.textLa: Sed collidebantur in utero eius parvuli; quæ ait: Si sic mihi futurum erat, quid necesse fuit concipere? Perrexitque ut consuleret Dominum.

verses.textEn: And responding, he said, “Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples will be divided out of your womb, and one people will overcome the other people, and the elder will serve the younger.”
verses.textLa: Qui respondens, ait: Duæ gentes sunt in utero tuo, et duo populi ex ventre tuo dividentur, populusque populum superabit, et maior serviet minori.

verses.textEn: Now the time had arrived to give birth, and behold, twins were discovered in her womb.
verses.textLa: Iam tempus pariendi advenerat, et ecce gemini in utero eius reperti sunt.

verses.textEn: He who departed first was red, and entirely hairy like a pelt; and his name was called Esau. At once the other departed and he held his brother’s foot in his hand; and because of this he was called Jacob.
verses.textLa: Qui prior egressus est, rufus erat, et totus in morem pellis hispidus: vocatumque est nomen eius Esau. Protinus alter egrediens, plantam fratris tenebat manu: et idcirco appellavit eum Iacob.

verses.textEn: Isaac was sixty years old when the little ones were born to him.
verses.textLa: Sexagenarius erat Isaac quando nati sunt ei parvuli.

verses.textEn: And as adults, Esau became a knowledgeable hunter and a man of agriculture, but Jacob, a simple man, dwelt in tents.
verses.textLa: Quibus adultis, factus est Esau vir gnarus venandi, et homo agricola: Iacob autem vir simplex habitabat in tabernaculis.

verses.textEn: Isaac was fond of Esau, because he was fed from his hunting; and Rebekah loved Jacob.
verses.textLa: Isaac amabat Esau, eo quod de venationibus illius vesceretur: et Rebecca diligebat Iacob.

verses.textEn: Then Jacob boiled a small meal. Esau, when he had arrived weary from the field,
verses.textLa: Coxit autem Iacob pulmentum: ad quem cum venisset Esau de agro lassus,

verses.textEn: said to him, “Give me this red stew, for I am very tired.” For this reason, his name was called Edom.
verses.textLa: ait: Da mihi de coctione hac rufa, quia oppido lassus sum. Quam ob causam vocatum est nomen eius Edom.

verses.textEn: Jacob said to him, “Sell me your right of the firstborn.”
verses.textLa: Cui dixit Iacob: Vende mihi primogenita tua.

verses.textEn: He answered, “Lo, I am dying, what will the right of the firstborn provide for me?”
verses.textLa: Ille respondit: En morior, quid mihi proderunt primogenita?

verses.textEn: Jacob said, “So then, swear to me.” Esau swore to him, and he sold his right of the firstborn.
verses.textLa: Ait Iacob: Iura ergo mihi. Iuravit ei Esau, et vendidit primogenita.

verses.textEn: And so, taking bread and the food of lentils, he ate, and he drank, and he went away, giving little weight to having sold the right of the firstborn.
verses.textLa: Et sic accepto pane et lentis edulio, comedit, et bibit, et abiit; parvipendens quod primogenita vendidisset.

verses.textEn: Then, when a famine arose over the land, after that barrenness which had happened in the days of Abraham, Isaac went to Abimelech, king of the Palestinians, in Gerar.
verses.textLa: Orta autem fame super terram post eam sterilitatem, quæ acciderat in diebus Abraham, abiit Isaac ad Abimelech regem Palæstinorum in Gerara.

verses.textEn: And the Lord appeared to him, and he said: “Do not descend into Egypt, but rest in the land that I will tell you,
verses.textLa: Apparuitque ei Dominus, et ait: Ne descendas in Ægyptum, sed quiesce in terra, quam dixero tibi.

verses.textEn: and sojourn in it, and I will be with you, and I will bless you. For to you and to your offspring I will give all these regions, completing the oath that I promised to Abraham your father.
verses.textLa: Et peregrinare in ea, eroque tecum, et benedicam tibi: tibi enim et semini tuo dabo universas regiones has, complens iuramentum quod spopondi Abraham patri tuo.

verses.textEn: And I will multiply your offspring like the stars of heaven. And I will give to your posterity all these regions. And in your offspring all the nations of the earth will be blessed,
verses.textLa: Et multiplicabo semen tuum sicut stellas cæli: daboque posteris tuis universas regiones has: et benedicentur in semine tuo omnes gentes terræ,

verses.textEn: because Abraham obeyed my voice, and kept my precepts and commandments, and observed the ceremonies and the laws.”
verses.textLa: eo quod obedierit Abraham voci meæ, et custodierit præcepta et mandata mea, et ceremonias legesque servaverit.

verses.textEn: And so Isaac remained in Gerar.
verses.textLa: Mansit itaque Isaac in Geraris.

verses.textEn: And when he was questioned by the men of that place about his wife, he answered, “She is my sister.” For he was afraid to confess her to be his mate, thinking that perhaps they would put him to death because of her beauty.
verses.textLa: Qui cum interrogaretur a viris loci illius super uxore sua, respondit: Soror mea est. Timuerat enim confiteri quod sibi esset sociata coniugio, reputans ne forte interficerent eum propter illius pulchritudinem.

verses.textEn: And when very many days had passed, and he had remained in the same place, Abimelech, king of the Palestinians, gazing through a window, saw him being playful with Rebekah, his wife.
verses.textLa: Cumque pertransissent dies plurimi, et ibidem moraretur, prospiciens Abimelech rex Palæstinorum per fenestram, vidit eum iocantem cum Rebecca uxore sua.

verses.textEn: And summoning him, he said: “It is clear that she is your wife. Why did you falsely claim her to be your sister?” He answered, “I was afraid, lest I might die because of her.”
verses.textLa: Et accersito eo, ait: Perspicuum est quod uxor tua sit: cur mentitus es eam sororem tuam esse? Respondit: Timui ne morerer propter eam.

verses.textEn: And Abimelech said: “Why have you burdened us? Someone from the people could have lain with your wife, and you would have brought a great sin upon us.” And he instructed all the people, saying,
verses.textLa: Dixitque Abimelech: Quare imposuisti nobis? potuit coire quispiam de populo cum uxore tua, et induxeras super nos grande peccatum. Præcepitque omni populo, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Whoever will touch the wife of this man will die a death.”
verses.textLa: Qui tetigerit hominis huius uxorem, morte morietur.

verses.textEn: Then Isaac sowed in that land, and he found, in that same year, one hundredfold. And the Lord blessed him.
verses.textLa: Sevit autem Isaac in terra illa, et invenit in ipso anno centuplum: benedixitque ei Dominus.

verses.textEn: And the man was enriched, and he continued prospering as well as increasing, until he became very great.
verses.textLa: Et locupletatus est homo, et ibat proficiens atque succrescens, donec magnus vehementer effectus est:

verses.textEn: Likewise, he had possessions of sheep and of herds, and a very large family. Because of this, the Palestinians envied him,
verses.textLa: habuit quoque possessiones ovium et armentorum, et familiæ plurimum. Ob hoc invidentes ei Palæstini,

verses.textEn: so, at that time, they obstructed all the wells that the servants of his father Abraham had dug, filling them with soil.
verses.textLa: omnes puteos, quos foderant servi patris illius Abraham, illo tempore obstruxerunt, implentes humo:

verses.textEn: It reached a point where Abimelech himself said to Isaac, “Move away from us, for you have become very much more powerful than we.”
verses.textLa: in tantum, ut ipse Abimelech diceret ad Isaac: Recede a nobis, quoniam potentior nobis factus es valde.

verses.textEn: And departing, he then went toward the torrent of Gerar, and he dwelt there.
verses.textLa: Et ille discedens, ut veniret ad torrentem Geraræ, habitaretque ibi:

verses.textEn: Again, he dug up other wells, which the servants of his father Abraham had dug, and which, after his death, the Philistines had formerly obstructed. And he called them by the same names that his father had called them before.
verses.textLa: rursum fodit alios puteos, quos foderant servi patris sui Abraham, et quos, illo mortuo, olim obstruxerant Philisthiim: appellavitque eos eisdem nominibus quibus ante pater vocaverat.

verses.textEn: And they dug in the torrent, and they found living water.
verses.textLa: Foderuntque in torrente, et repererunt aquam vivam.
verses.notes: The expression ‘aquam vivam’ has a dual meaning. It refers to water that continually pours forth (perhaps similar to an artesian well). It also has a spiritual meaning, as found in the Gospels. The torrent is a wadi, in other words, a dry stream bed that is a rushing torrent in the rainy season (perhaps only one or two months a year). The word torrentem in Latin can refer to something that is hot and dry, or to a rushing stream.

verses.textEn: But in that place also the shepherds of Gerar argued against the shepherds of Isaac, by saying, “It is our water.” For this reason, he called the name of the well, because of what had happened, ‘Calumny.’
verses.textLa: Sed et ibi iurgium fuit pastorum Geraræ adversus pastores Isaac, dicentium: Nostra est aqua. Quam ob rem nomen putei ex eo, quod acciderat, vocavit Calumniam.

verses.textEn: Then they dug up yet another one. And over that one also they fought, and he called it, ‘Enmity.’
verses.textLa: Foderunt autem et alium: et pro illo quoque rixati sunt, appellavitque eum, Inimicitias.

verses.textEn: Advancing from there, he dug another well, over which they did not contend. And so he called its name, ‘Latitude,’ saying, “Now the Lord has expanded us and caused us to increase across the land.”
verses.textLa: Profectus inde fodit alium puteum, pro quo non contenderunt: itaque vocavit nomen eius, Latitudo, dicens: Nunc dilatavit nos Dominus, et fecit crescere super terram.

verses.textEn: Then he ascended from that place into Beersheba,
verses.textLa: Ascendit autem ex illo loco in Bersabee,

verses.textEn: where the Lord appeared to him on the same night, saying: “I am the God of Abraham your father. Do not be afraid, for I am with you. I will bless you, and I will multiply your offspring because of my servant Abraham.”
verses.textLa: ubi apparuit ei Dominus in ipsa nocte, dicens: Ego sum Deus Abraham patris tui, noli timere, quia ego tecum sum: benedicam tibi, et multiplicabo semen tuum propter servum meum Abraham.

verses.textEn: And so he built an altar there. And he invoked the name of the Lord, and he stretched out his tent. And he instructed his servants to dig a well.
verses.textLa: Itaque ædificavit ibi altare: et invocato nomine Domini, extendit tabernaculum: præcepitque servis suis ut foderunt puteum.

verses.textEn: When Abimelech, and Ahuzzath, his friend, and Phicol, the leader of the military, had arrived from Gerar to that place,
verses.textLa: Ad quem locum cum venissent de Geraris Abimelech, et Ochozath amicus illius, et Phicol dux militum,

verses.textEn: Isaac said to them, “Why have you come to me, a man whom you hate, and whom you have expelled from among you?”
verses.textLa: locutus est eis Isaac: Quid venistis ad me hominem quem odistis, et expulistis a vobis?

verses.textEn: And they responded: “We saw that the Lord is with you, and therefore we said: Let there be an oath between us, and let us initiate a pact,
verses.textLa: Qui responderunt: Vidimus tecum esse Dominum, et idcirco nos diximus: Sit iuramentum inter nos, et ineamus fœdus,

verses.textEn: so that you may not do us any kind of harm, just as we have touched nothing of yours, and have not caused any injury to you, but with peace we released you, augmented by the blessing of the Lord.”
verses.textLa: ut non facias nobis quidquam mali, sicut et nos nihil tuorum attigimus, nec fecimus quod te læderet: sed cum pace dimisimus auctum benedictione Domini.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he made them a feast, and after the food and drink,
verses.textLa: Fecit ergo eis convivium, et post cibum et potum

verses.textEn: arising in the morning, they swore to one another. And Isaac sent them away peacefully to their own place.
verses.textLa: surgentes mane, iuraverunt sibi mutuo: dimisitque eos Isaac pacifice in locum suum.

verses.textEn: Then, behold, on the same day the servants of Isaac came, reporting to him about a well which they had dug, and saying: “We have found water.”
verses.textLa: Ecce autem venerunt in ipso die servi Isaac annunciantes ei de puteo, quem foderant, atque dicentes: Invenimus aquam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he called it, ‘Abundance.’ And the name of the city was established as ‘Beersheba,’ even to the present day.
verses.textLa: Unde appellavit eum, Abundantiam: et nomen urbi impositum est Bersabee, usque in præsentem diem.

verses.textEn: In truth, at forty years of age, Esau took wives: Judith, the daughter of Beeri, the Hittite, and Basemath, the daughter of Elon, of the same place.
verses.textLa: Esau vero quadragenarius duxit uxores, Iudith filiam Beeri Hethæi, et Basemath filiam Elon eiusdem loci:

verses.textEn: And they both offended the mind of Isaac and Rebekah.
verses.textLa: quæ ambæ offenderant animum Isaac et Rebeccæ.

verses.textEn: Now Isaac was old, and his eyes were cloudy, and so he was not able to see. And he called his elder son Esau, and he said to him, “My son?” And he responded, “Here I am.”
verses.textLa: Senuit autem Isaac, et caligaverunt oculi eius, et videre non poterat: vocavitque Esau filium suum maiorem, et dixit ei: Fili mi? Qui respondit: Adsum.
verses.notes: Isaac apparently had cataracts, which can severely hamper one’s vision, just as described in this passage.

verses.textEn: His father said to him: “You see that I am old, and I do not know the day of my death.
verses.textLa: Cui pater: Vides, inquit, quod senuerim, et ignorem diem mortis meæ.

verses.textEn: Take your weapons, the quiver and the bow, and go out. And when you have taken something by hunting,
verses.textLa: Sume arma tua, pharetram, et arcum, et egredere foras: cumque venatu aliquid apprehenderis,

verses.textEn: make from it a small meal for me, just as you know I like, and bring it, so that I may eat and my soul may bless you before I die.”
verses.textLa: fac mihi inde pulmentum sicut velle me nosti, et affer ut comedam: et benedicat tibi anima mea antequam moriar.

verses.textEn: And when Rebekah had heard this, and he had gone out into the field to fulfill his father’s order,
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset Rebecca, et ille abiisset in agrum ut iussionem patris impleret,

verses.textEn: she said to her son Jacob: “I heard your father speaking with your brother Esau, and saying to him,
verses.textLa: dixit filio suo Iacob: Audivi patrem tuum loquentem cum Esau fratre tuo, et dicentem ei:

verses.textEn: ‘Bring to me from your hunting, and make me foods, so that I may eat and bless you in the sight of the Lord before I die.’
verses.textLa: Affer mihi de venatione tua, et fac cibos ut comedam, et benedicam tibi coram Domino antequam moriar.

verses.textEn: Therefore, now my son, agree to my counsel,
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo fili mi, acquiesce consiliis meis:

verses.textEn: and go straight to the flock, and bring me two of the best young goats, so that from them I may make meat for your father, such as he willingly eats.
verses.textLa: et pergens ad gregem, affer mihi duos hœdos optimos, ut faciam ex eis escas patri tuo, quibus libenter vescitur:

verses.textEn: Then, when you have brought these in and he has eaten, he may bless you before he dies.”
verses.textLa: quas cum intuleris, et comederit, benedicat tibi priusquam moriatur.

verses.textEn: He answered her: “You know that my brother Esau is a hairy man, and I am smooth.
verses.textLa: Cui ille respondit: Nosti quod Esau frater meus homo pilosus sit, et ego lenis:

verses.textEn: If my father should lay hands on me and perceive it, I am afraid lest he think me willing to mock him, and I will bring a curse upon myself, instead of a blessing.”
verses.textLa: si attrectaverit me pater meus, et senserit, timeo ne putet me sibi voluisse illudere, et inducam super me maledictionem pro benedictione.

verses.textEn: And his mother said to him: “Let this curse be upon me, my son. Yet listen to my voice, and go directly to bring what I said.”
verses.textLa: Ad quem mater: In me sit, ait, ista maledictio, fili mi: tantum audi vocem meam, et pergens affer quæ dixi.

verses.textEn: He went out, and he brought, and he gave to his mother. She prepared the meats, just as she knew his father liked.
verses.textLa: Abiit, et attulit, deditque matri. Paravit illa cibos, sicut velle noverat patrem illius.

verses.textEn: And she clothed him with the very fine garments of Esau, which she had at home with her.
verses.textLa: Et vestibus Esau valde bonis, quas apud se habebat domi, induit eum:

verses.textEn: And she encircled his hands with little pelts from the young goats, and she covered his bare neck.
verses.textLa: pelliculasque hœdorum circumdedit manibus, et colli nuda protexit.

verses.textEn: And she gave him the small meal, and she handed him the bread that she had baked.
verses.textLa: Deditque pulmentum, et panes, quos coxerat, tradidit.

verses.textEn: When he had carried these in, he said, “My father?” And he answered, “I’m listening. Who are you, my son?”
verses.textLa: Quibus illatis, dixit: Pater mi? At ille respondit: Audio. Quis es tu fili mi?

verses.textEn: And Jacob said: “I am Esau, your firstborn. I have done as you instructed me. Arise; sit and eat from my hunting, so that your soul may bless me.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Iacob: Ego sum primogenitus tuus Esau: feci sicut præcepisti mihi: surge, sede, et comede de venatione mea, ut benedicat mihi anima tua.

verses.textEn: And again Isaac said to his son, “How were you able to find it so quickly, my son?” He answered, “It was the will of God, so that what I sought met with me quickly.”
verses.textLa: Rursumque Isaac ad filium suum: Quo modo, inquit, tam cito invenire potuisti, fili mi? Qui respondit: Voluntas Dei fuit ut cito occurreret mihi quod volebam:

verses.textEn: And Isaac said, “Come here, so that I may touch you, my son, and may prove whether you are my son Esau, or not.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Isaac: Accede huc, ut tangam te fili mi, et probem utrum tu sis filius meus Esau, an non.

verses.textEn: He approached his father, and when he had felt him, Isaac said: “The voice indeed is the voice of Jacob. But the hands are the hands of Esau.”
verses.textLa: Accessit ille ad patrem, et palpato eo, dixit Isaac: Vox quidem, vox Iacob est: sed manus, manus sunt Esau.

verses.textEn: And he did not recognize him, because his hairy hands made him seem similar to the elder one. Therefore, blessing him,
verses.textLa: Et non cognovit eum, quia pilosæ manus similitudinem maioris expresserant. Benedicens ergo illi,

verses.textEn: he said, “Are you my son Esau?” He answered, “I am.”
verses.textLa: ait: Tu es filius meus Esau? Respondit: Ego sum.

verses.textEn: Then he said, “Bring me the foods from your hunting, my son, so that my soul may bless you.” And when he had eaten what was offered, he also brought forth wine for him. And after he finished it,
verses.textLa: At ille: Affer mihi, inquit, cibos de venatione tua, fili mi, ut benedicat tibi anima mea. Quos cum oblatos comedisset, obtulit ei etiam vinum. Quo hausto,

verses.textEn: he said to him, “Come to me and give me a kiss, my son.”
verses.textLa: dixit ad eum: Accede ad me, et da mihi osculum, fili mi.

verses.textEn: He approached and kissed him. And immediately he perceived the fragrance of his garments. And so, blessing him, he said: “Behold, the smell of my son is like the smell of a plentiful field, which the Lord has blessed.
verses.textLa: Accessit, et osculatus est eum. Statimque ut sensit vestimentorum illius fragrantiam, benedicens illi, ait: Ecce odor filii mei sicut odor agri pleni, cui benedixit Dominus.

verses.textEn: May God give to you, from the dew of heaven and from the fatness of the earth, an abundance of grain and wine.
verses.textLa: Det tibi Deus de rore cæli, et de pinguedine terræ abundantiam frumenti et vini.

verses.textEn: And may the peoples serve you, and may the tribes reverence you. May you be the lord of your brothers, and may your mother’s sons bow down before you. Whoever curses you, may he be cursed, and whoever blesses you, may he be filled with blessings.”
verses.textLa: Et serviant tibi populi, et adorent te tribus: esto dominus fratrum tuorum, et incurventur ante te filii matris tuæ. Qui maledixerit tibi, sit ille maledictus: et qui benedixerit tibi, benedictionibus repleatur.

verses.textEn: Scarcely had Isaac completed his words, and Jacob departed, when Esau arrived.
verses.textLa: Vix Isaac sermonem impleverat: et egresso Iacob foras, venit Esau,

verses.textEn: And he brought his father foods cooked from his hunting, saying, “Arise, my father, and eat from your son’s hunting, so that your soul may bless me.”
verses.textLa: coctosque de venatione cibos intulit patri, dicens: Surge pater mi, et comede de venatione filii tui: ut benedicat mihi anima tua.

verses.textEn: And Isaac said to him, “But who are you?” And he answered, “I am your firstborn son, Esau.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque illi Isaac: Quis enim es tu? Qui respondit: Ego sum filius tuus primogenitus Esau.

verses.textEn: Isaac became frightened and very astonished. And wondering beyond what can be believed, he said: “Then who is he that a while ago brought me the prey from his hunting, from which I ate, before you arrived? And I blessed him, and he will be blessed.”
verses.textLa: Expavit Isaac stupore vehementi: et ultra quam credi potest, admirans, ait: Quis igitur ille est qui dudum captam venationem attulit mihi, et comedi ex omnibus priusquam tu venires? benedixique ei, et erit benedictus.

verses.textEn: Esau, having heard his father’s words, roared out with a great outcry. And, being confounded, he said, “But bless me also, my father.”
verses.textLa: Auditis Esau sermonibus patris, irrugiit clamore magno: et consternatus, ait: Benedic etiam et mihi, pater mi.

verses.textEn: And he said, “Your twin came deceitfully, and he received your blessing.”
verses.textLa: Qui ait: Venit germanus tuus fraudulenter, et accepit benedictionem tuam.

verses.textEn: But he responded: “Justly is his name called Jacob. For he has supplanted me yet another time. My birthright he took away before, and now, this second time, he has stolen my blessing.” And again, he said to his father, “Have you not reserved a blessing for me also?”
verses.textLa: At ille subiunxit: Iuste vocatum est nomen eius Iacob: supplantavit enim me en altera vice: primogenita mea ante tulit, et nunc secundo surripuit benedictionem meam. Rursumque ad patrem: Numquid non reservasti, ait, et mihi benedictionem?

verses.textEn: Isaac answered: “I have appointed him as your lord, and I have subjugated all his brothers as his servants. I have reinforced him with grain and wine, and after this, my son, what more shall I do for you?”
verses.textLa: Respondit Isaac: Illum constitui dominum tuum, et omnes fratres eius servituti illius subiugavi: frumento et vino stabilivi eum, et tibi post hæc, fili mi, ultra quid faciam?

verses.textEn: And Esau said to him: “Have you only one blessing, father? I beg you, bless me also.” And when he wept with a loud wail,
verses.textLa: Cui Esau: Num unam, inquit, tantum benedictionem habes, pater? mihi quoque obsecro ut benedicas. Cumque eiulatu magno fleret,

verses.textEn: Isaac was moved, and he said to him: “In the fatness of the earth, and in the dew of heaven from above,
verses.textLa: motus Isaac, dixit ad eum: In pinguedine terræ, et in rore cæli desuper

verses.textEn: will your blessing be. You will live by the sword, and you will serve your brother. But the time will arrive when you will shake off and release his yoke from your neck.”
verses.textLa: erit benedictio tua. Vives in gladio, et fratri tuo servies: tempusque veniet, cum excutias, et solvas iugum eius de cervicibus tuis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Esau always hated Jacob, for the blessing with which his father had blessed him. And he said in his heart, “The days will arrive for the mourning of my father, and I will kill my brother Jacob.”
verses.textLa: Oderat ergo semper Esau Iacob pro benedictione qua benedixerat ei pater: dixitque in corde suo: Venient dies luctus patris mei, et occidam Iacob fratrem meum.

verses.textEn: These things were reported to Rebekah. And sending and calling for her son Jacob, she said to him, “Behold, your brother Esau is threatening to kill you.
verses.textLa: Nunciata sunt hæc Rebeccæ: quæ mittens et vocans Iacob filium suum, dixit ad eum: Ecce Esau frater tuus minatur ut occidat te.

verses.textEn: Therefore, now my son, listen to my voice. Rise up and flee to my brother Laban, in Haran.
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo, fili mi, audi vocem meam, et consurgens fuge ad Laban fratrem meum in Haran:

verses.textEn: And you will dwell with him for a few days, until the fury of your brother subsides,
verses.textLa: habitabisque cum eo dies paucos, donec requiescat furor fratris tui,

verses.textEn: and his indignation ceases, and he forgets the things that you have done to him. After this, I will send for you and bring you from there to here. Why should I be bereaved of both my sons in one day?”
verses.textLa: et cesset indignatio eius, obliviscaturque eorum quæ fecisti in eum: postea mittam, et adducam te inde huc. Cur utroque orbabor filio in uno die?

verses.textEn: And Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am weary of my life because of the daughters of Heth. If Jacob accepts a wife from the stock of this land, I would not be willing to live.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Rebecca ad Isaac: Tædet me vitæ meæ propter filias Heth: si acceperit Iacob uxorem de stirpe huius terræ, nolo vivere.

verses.textEn: And so Isaac called for Jacob, and he blessed him, and he instructed him, saying: “Do not be willing to accept a mate from the family of Canaan.
verses.textLa: Vocavit itaque Isaac Iacob, et benedixit eum, præcepitque ei dicens: Noli accipere coniugem de genere Chanaan:

verses.textEn: But go, and journey to Mesopotamia of Syria, to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father, and there accept for yourself a wife from the daughters of Laban, your maternal uncle.
verses.textLa: sed vade, et proficiscere in Mesopotamiam Syriæ, ad domum Bathuel patris matris tuæ, et accipe tibi inde uxorem de filiabus Laban avunculi tui.

verses.textEn: And may God almighty bless you, and may he cause you to increase and also to multiply, so that you may be influential among the people.
verses.textLa: Deus autem omnipotens benedicat tibi, et crescere te faciat, atque multiplicet: ut sis in turbas populorum.
verses.notes: The word ‘turbas’ generally refers to a commotion or disturbance, but in some contexts it means ‘influential,’ in other words, able to stir things up or able to cause a commotion. Cf. Esther 9:27, CPDV.

verses.textEn: And may he give the blessings of Abraham to you, and to your offspring after you, so that you may possess the land of your sojourning, which he promised to your grandfather.”
verses.textLa: Et det tibi benedictiones Abrahæ, et semini tuo post te: ut possideas terram peregrinationis tuæ, quam pollicitus est avo tuo.

verses.textEn: And when Isaac had dismissed him, setting out, he went to Mesopotamia of Syria, to Laban, the son of Bethuel, the Syrian, the brother to Rebekah, his mother.
verses.textLa: Cumque dimisisset eum Isaac, profectus venit in Mesopotamiam Syriæ ad Laban filium Bathuel Syri, fratrem Rebeccæ matris suæ.

verses.textEn: But Esau, seeing that his father had blessed Jacob and had sent him into Mesopotamia of Syria, to take a wife from there, and that, after the blessing, he had instructed him, saying: ‘You shall not accept a wife from the daughters of Canaan,’
verses.textLa: Videns autem Esau quod benedixisset pater suus Iacob, et misisset eum in Mesopotamiam Syriæ, ut inde uxorem duceret; et quod post benedictionem præcepisset ei, dicens: Non accipies uxorem de filiabus Chanaan:

verses.textEn: and that Jacob, obeying his parents, had gone into Syria,
verses.textLa: quodque obediens Iacob parentibus suis isset in Syriam:

verses.textEn: having evidence also that his father did not look with favor upon the daughters of Canaan,
verses.textLa: probans quoque quod non libenter aspiceret filias Chanaan pater suus:

verses.textEn: he went to Ishmael, and he took as a wife, beside those he had before, Mahalath, the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, the sister of Nebaioth.
verses.textLa: ivit ad Ismaelem, et duxit uxorem absque iis, quas prius habebat, Maheleth filiam Ismael filii Abraham, sororem Nabaioth.

verses.textEn: Meanwhile Jacob, having departed from Beersheba, continued on to Haran.
verses.textLa: Igitur egressus Iacob de Bersabee, pergebat Haran.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived at a certain place, where he would rest after the setting of the sun, he took some of the stones that lay there, and placing them under his head, he slept in the same place.
verses.textLa: Cumque venisset ad quemdam locum, et vellet in eo requiescere post solis occubitum, tulit de lapidibus qui iacebant, et supponens capiti suo, dormivit in eodem loco.

verses.textEn: And he saw in his sleep: a ladder standing upon the earth, with its top touching heaven, also, the Angels of God ascending and descending by it,
verses.textLa: Viditque in somnis scalam stantem super terram, et cacumen illius tangens cælum: Angelos quoque Dei ascendentes et descendentes per eam,

verses.textEn: and the Lord, leaning upon the ladder, saying to him: “I am the Lord, the God of Abraham your father, and the God of Isaac. The land, in which you sleep, I will give to you and to your offspring.
verses.textLa: et Dominum innixum scalæ dicentem sibi: Ego sum Dominus Deus Abraham patris tui, et Deus Isaac: Terram, in qua dormis, tibi dabo et semini tuo.

verses.textEn: And your offspring will be like the dust of the earth. You will spread abroad to the West, and to the East, and to the North, and to the Meridian. And in you and in your offspring, all the tribes of the earth shall be blessed.
verses.textLa: Eritque semen tuum quasi pulvis terræ: dilataberis ad Occidentem, et Orientem, et Septentrionem, et Meridiem: et benedicentur in te et in semine tuo cunctæ tribus terræ.
verses.notes: Or, ‘you will spread to the Setting, and the Rising, and the Seven Oxen (or the Seven Stars), and the Meridian.’ The word ‘septentrionem’ literally means ‘seven plough-oxen,’ but is an expression used to refer to a constellation of seven stars. The Meridian is the South, or rather, from a modern point of view, south of Mesopotamia, i.e. towards the equator.

verses.textEn: And I will be your guardian wherever you will journey, and I will bring you back into this land. Neither will I dismiss you, until I have accomplished all that I have said.”
verses.textLa: Et ero custos tuus quocumque perrexeris, et reducam te in terram hanc: nec dimittam nisi complevero universa quæ dixi.

verses.textEn: And when Jacob had awakened from sleep, he said, “Truly, the Lord is in this place, and I did not know it.”
verses.textLa: Cumque evigilasset Iacob de somno, ait: Vere Dominus est in loco isto, et ego nesciebam.

verses.textEn: And being terrified, he said: “How terrible this place is! This is nothing other than the house of God and the gateway of heaven.”
verses.textLa: Pavensque: Quam terribilis est, inquit, locus iste! non est hic aliud nisi domus Dei, et porta cæli.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jacob, arising in the morning, took the stone which he had placed under his head, and he set it up as monument, pouring oil over it.
verses.textLa: Surgens ergo Iacob mane, tulit lapidem quem supposuerat capiti suo, et erexit in titulum, fundens oleum desuper.

verses.textEn: And he called the name of the city, ‘Bethel,’ which before was called Luz.
verses.textLa: Appellavitque nomen urbis Bethel, quæ prius Luza vocabatur.

verses.textEn: And then he made a vow, saying: “If God will be with me, and will guard me along the way by which I walk, and will give me bread to eat and clothing to wear,
verses.textLa: Vovit etiam votum, dicens: Si fuerit Deus mecum, et custodierit me in via, per quam ego ambulo, et dederit mihi panem ad vescendum, et vestimentum ad induendum,

verses.textEn: and if I will return prosperously to my father’s house, then the Lord will be my God,
verses.textLa: reversusque fuero prospere ad domum patris mei: erit mihi Dominus in Deum,

verses.textEn: and this stone, which I have set up as a monument, will be called ‘the House of God.’ And from all the things that you will give to me, I will offer tithes to you.”
verses.textLa: et lapis iste, quem erexi in titulum, vocabitur Domus Dei: cunctorumque quæ dederis mihi, decimas offeram tibi.

verses.textEn: And so Jacob, setting out, arrived in the eastern land.
verses.textLa: Profectus ergo Iacob venit in terram Orientalem.

verses.textEn: And he saw a well in a field, and also three flocks of sheep reclining near it. For the animals were watered from it, and its mouth was closed with a great stone.
verses.textLa: Et vidit puteum in agro, tres quoque greges ovium accubantes iuxta eum: nam ex illo adaquabantur pecora, et os eius grandi lapide claudebatur.

verses.textEn: And the custom was, when all the sheep were gathered together, to roll away the stone. And when the flocks had been refreshed, they placed it over the mouth of the well again.
verses.textLa: Morisque erat ut cunctis ovibus congregatis devolverent lapidem, et refectis gregibus rursum super os putei ponerent.

verses.textEn: And he said to the shepherds, “Brothers, where are you from?” And they answered. “From Haran.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad pastores: Fratres, unde estis? Qui responderunt: De Haran.

verses.textEn: And questioning them, he said, “Do you know Laban, the son of Nahor?” They said, “We know him.”
verses.textLa: Quos interrogans, Numquid, ait, nostis Laban filium Nachor? Dixerunt: Novimus.

verses.textEn: He said, “Is he well?” “He is very well,” they said. “And behold, his daughter Rachel approaches with his flock.”
verses.textLa: Sanusne est? inquit: Valet, inquiunt: et ecce Rachel filia eius venit cum grege suo.

verses.textEn: And Jacob said, “There is still much daylight remaining, and it is not time to return the flocks to the sheepfold. Give the sheep to drink first, and then lead them back to pasture.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Iacob: Adhuc multum diei superest, nec est tempus ut reducantur ad caulas greges: date ante potum ovibus, et sic eas ad pastum reducite.

verses.textEn: They responded, “We cannot, until all the animals are gathered together and we remove the stone from the mouth of the well, so that we may water the flocks.”
verses.textLa: Qui responderunt: Non possumus, donec omnia pecora congregentur, et amoveamus lapidem de ore putei, ut adaquemus greges.

verses.textEn: They were still speaking, and behold, Rachel arrived with her father’s sheep; for she pastured the flock.
verses.textLa: Adhuc loquebantur, et ecce Rachel veniebat cum ovibus patris sui: nam gregem ipsa pascebat.

verses.textEn: When Jacob had seen her, and he realized that she was his maternal first cousin, and that these were the sheep of his uncle Laban, he removed the stone which closed the well.
verses.textLa: Quam cum vidisset Iacob, et sciret consobrinam suam, ovesque Laban avunculi sui: amovit lapidem quo puteus claudebatur.

verses.textEn: And having watered the flock, he kissed her. And lifting up his voice, he wept.
verses.textLa: Et adaquato grege, osculatus est eam: et elevata voce flevit,

verses.textEn: And he revealed to her that he was a brother of her father, and the son of Rebekah. And so, hurrying, she announced it to her father.
verses.textLa: et indicavit ei quod frater esset patris sui, et filius Rebeccæ: at illa festinans nunciavit patri suo.
verses.notes: This is one of very many examples where ‘brother’ is used more loosely in Scripture. Jacob was not the brother or Laban, but rather a close male relative, i.e. a brother in the broader sense of the word.

verses.textEn: And when he had heard that Jacob, his sister’s son, had arrived, he ran to meet him. And embracing him, and kissing him heartily, he brought him into his house. But when he had heard the reasons for his journey,
verses.textLa: Qui cum audisset venisse Iacob filium sororis suæ, cucurrit obviam ei: complexusque eum, et in oscula ruens, duxit in domum suam. Auditis autem causis itineris,

verses.textEn: he responded, “You are my bone and my flesh.” And after the days of one month were completed,
verses.textLa: respondit: Os meum es, et caro mea. Et postquam impleti sunt dies mensis unius,

verses.textEn: he said to him: “Though you are my brother, will you serve me for nothing? Tell me what wages you would accept.”
verses.textLa: dixit ei: Num quia frater meus es, gratis servies mihi? dic quid mercedis accipias.

verses.textEn: In truth, he had two daughters: the name of the elder was Leah; and truly the younger was called Rachel.
verses.textLa: Habebat vero duas filias, nomen maioris Lia: minor vero appellabatur Rachel.

verses.textEn: But while Leah was bleary-eyed, Rachel had an elegant appearance and was attractive to behold.
verses.textLa: Sed Lia lippis erat oculis: Rachel decora facie, et venusto aspectu.

verses.textEn: And Jacob, loving her, said, “I will serve you for seven years, for your younger daughter Rachel.”
verses.textLa: Quam diligens Iacob, ait: Serviam tibi pro Rachel filia tua minore, septem annis.

verses.textEn: Laban responded, “It is better that I give her to you than to another man; remain with me.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Laban: Melius est ut tibi eam dem quam alteri viro, mane apud me.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jacob served for seven years for Rachel. And these seemed like only a few days, because of the greatness of love.
verses.textLa: Servivit ergo Iacob pro Rachel septem annis: et videbantur illi pauci dies præ amoris magnitudine.

verses.textEn: And he said to Laban, “Give my wife to me. For now the time has been fulfilled, so that I may go in to her.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad Laban: Da mihi uxorem meam: quia iam tempus impletum est, ut ingrediar ad illam.

verses.textEn: And he, having called a great crowd of his friends to the feast, agreed to the marriage.
verses.textLa: Qui vocatis multis amicorum turbis ad convivium, fecit nuptias.

verses.textEn: And at night, he brought in his daughter Leah to him,
verses.textLa: Et vespere Liam filiam suam introduxit ad eum,

verses.textEn: giving his daughter a handmaid named Zilpah. After Jacob had gone in to her, according to custom, when morning had arrived, he saw Leah.
verses.textLa: dans ancillam filiæ, Zelpham nomine. Ad quam cum ex more Iacob fuisset ingressus, facto mane vidit Liam:

verses.textEn: And he said to his father-in-law, “What is it that you intended to do? Did I not serve you for Rachel? Why have you deceived me?”
verses.textLa: et dixit ad socerum suum: Quid est quod facere voluisti? nonne pro Rachel servivi tibi? quare imposuisti mihi?
