verses.textEn: Laban responded, “It is not the practice in this place to give the younger in marriage first.
verses.textLa: Respondit Laban: Non est in loco nostro consuetudinis, ut minores ante tradamus ad nuptias.

verses.textEn: Complete a week of days with this mating. And then I will give this one to you also, for the service that you will provide to me for another seven years.”
verses.textLa: Imple hebdomadam dierum huius copulæ: et hanc quoque dabo tibi pro opere quo serviturus es mihi septem annis aliis.

verses.textEn: He agreed to his pleading. And after the week had passed, he took Rachel as a wife.
verses.textLa: Acquievit placito: et hebdomada transacta, Rachel duxit uxorem:

verses.textEn: To her, the father had given Bilhah as her servant.
verses.textLa: cui pater servam Balam tradiderat.

verses.textEn: And, having at last obtained the marriage he desired, he preferred the love of the latter before the former, and he served with him another seven years.
verses.textLa: Tandemque potitus optatis nuptiis, amorem sequentis priori prætulit, serviens apud eum septem annis aliis.

verses.textEn: But the Lord, seeing that he despised Leah, opened her womb, but her sister remained barren.
verses.textLa: Videns autem Dominus quod despiceret Liam, aperuit vulvam eius, sorore sterili permanente.

verses.textEn: Having conceived, she gave birth to a son, and she called his name Reuben, saying: “The Lord saw my humiliation; now my husband will love me.”
verses.textLa: Quæ conceptum genuit filium, vocavitque nomen eius Ruben, dicens: Vidit Dominus humilitatem meam, nunc amabit me vir meus.

verses.textEn: And again she conceived and bore a son, and she said, “Because the Lord heard that I was treated with contempt, he has also given this one to me.” And she called his name Simeon.
verses.textLa: Rursumque concepit et peperit filium, et ait: Quoniam audivit me Dominus haberi contemptui, dedit etiam istum mihi. Vocavitque nomen eius Simeon.

verses.textEn: And she conceived a third time, and she gave birth to another son, and she said: “Now likewise my husband will unite with me, because I have borne him three sons.” And because of this, she called his name Levi.
verses.textLa: Concepitque tertio, et genuit alium filium: dixitque: Nunc quoque copulabitur mihi maritus meus, eo quod pepererim ei tres filios: et idcirco appellavit nomen eius, Levi.

verses.textEn: A fourth time she conceived and bore a son, and she said, “Only now will I confess to the Lord.” And for this reason, she called him Judah. And she ceased from child-bearing.
verses.textLa: Quarto concepit, et peperit filium, et ait: Modo confitebor Domino. Et ob hoc vocavit eum, Iudam: cessavitque parere.

verses.textEn: Then Rachel, discerning that she was infertile, envied her sister, and so she said to her husband, “Give me children, otherwise I will die.”
verses.textLa: Cernens autem Rachel quod infecunda esset, invidit sorori suæ, et ait marito suo: Da mihi liberos, alioquin moriar.

verses.textEn: Jacob, being angry, responded to her, “Am I in the place of God, who has deprived you of the fruit of your womb?”
verses.textLa: Cui iratus respondit Iacob: Num pro Deo ego sum, qui privavit te fructu ventris tui?

verses.textEn: But she said: “I have a handmaid Bilhah. Go in to her, so that she may give birth upon my knees, and I may have sons by her.”
verses.textLa: At illa: Habeo, inquit, famulam Balam: ingredere ad illam, ut pariat super genua mea, et habeam ex illa filios.

verses.textEn: And she gave him Bilhah in marriage.
verses.textLa: Deditque illi Balam in coniugium:

verses.textEn: And when her husband had gone in to her, she conceived and bore a son.
verses.textLa: quæ, ingresso ad se viro, concepit, et peperit filium.

verses.textEn: And Rachel said, “The Lord has judged for me, and he has heeded my voice, giving me a son.” And because of this, she called his name Dan.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Rachel: Iudicavit mihi Dominus, et exaudivit vocem meam, dans mihi filium. Et idcirco appellavit nomen eius, Dan.

verses.textEn: And conceiving again, Bilhah bore another,
verses.textLa: Rursumque Bala concipiens, peperit alterum,

verses.textEn: about whom Rachel said, “God has compared me with my sister, and I have prevailed.” And she called him Naphtali.
verses.textLa: pro quo ait Rachel: Comparavit me Deus cum sorore mea, et invalui: vocavitque eum, Nephthali.

verses.textEn: Leah, perceiving that she had desisted from child-bearing, delivered Zilpah, her handmaid, to her husband.
verses.textLa: Sentiens Lia quod parere desiisset, Zelpham ancillam suam marito tradidit.

verses.textEn: And she, after having borne a son with difficulty,
verses.textLa: Qua post conceptum edente filium,
verses.notes:
The word ‘edente’ is a concatenation of two words ‘e’ meaning ‘out of’ or ‘on account of,’ and ‘dente’ referring to teeth. The word ‘dente’ is also used figuratively to refer to something that causes one to grit one’s teeth, such as a difficult circumstance. In this case, in the context of pregnancy and child-bearing, the term ‘edente’ means that the pregnancy and birth of this child was difficult.
 Also, in this case, the term ‘conceptum’ refers to the entire process of conception, pregnancy, and birthing.

verses.textEn: said: “Happiness!” And for this reason, she called his name Gad.
verses.textLa: dixit: Feliciter. Et idcirco vocavit nomen eius, Gad.

verses.textEn: Likewise, Zilpah bore another.
verses.textLa: Peperit quoque Zelpha alterum.

verses.textEn: And Leah said, “This one is for my happiness. Indeed, women will call me blessed.” Because of this, she called him Asher.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Lia: Hoc pro beatitudine mea: Beatam quippe me dicent mulieres. Propterea appellavit eum, Aser.

verses.textEn: Then Reuben, going out into the field at the time of the wheat harvest, found mandrakes. These he brought to his mother Leah. And Rachel said, “Give me a portion of your son’s mandrakes.”
verses.textLa: Egressus autem Ruben tempore messis triticeæ in agrum, reperit mandragoras: quas matri Liæ detulit. Dixitque Rachel: Da mihi partem de mandragoris filii tui.

verses.textEn: She responded, “Does it seem like such a small matter to you, that you have usurped from me my husband, unless you will also take my son’s mandrakes?” Rachel said, “He will sleep with you this night because of your son’s mandrakes.”
verses.textLa: Illa respondit: Parumne tibi videtur quod præripueris maritum mihi, nisi etiam mandragoras filii mei tuleris? Ait Rachel: Dormiat tecum hac nocte pro mandragoris filii tui.
verses.notes: The word ‘praeripueris’ in this context refers to Rachel usurping Leah’s place as wife, for Leah was his first wife, but Rachel was first in his heart. The mandrake is a plant with a narcotic and soporific effect.

verses.textEn: And when Jacob returned from the field in the evening, Leah went out to meet him, and she said, “You will enter to me, because I have hired you for the reward of my son’s mandrakes.” And he slept with her that night.
verses.textLa: Redeuntique ad vesperam Iacob de agro, egressa est in occursum eius Lia, et ad me, inquit, intrabis: quia mercede conduxi te pro mandragoris filii mei. Dormivitque cum ea nocte illa.

verses.textEn: And God heard her prayers. And she conceived and bore a fifth son.
verses.textLa: Et exaudivit Deus preces eius: concepitque et peperit filium quintum,

verses.textEn: And she said, “God has given a reward to me, because I gave my handmaid to my husband.” And she called his name Issachar.
verses.textLa: et ait: Dedit Deus mercedem mihi, quia dedi ancillam meam viro meo. Appellavitque nomen eius, Issachar.

verses.textEn: Conceiving again, Leah bore a sixth son.
verses.textLa: Rursum Lia concipiens, peperit sextum filium,

verses.textEn: And she said: “God has endowed me with a good dowry. And now, at this turn, my husband will be with me, because I have conceived six sons for him.” And therefore she called his name Zebulun.
verses.textLa: et ait: Dotavit me Deus dote bona: etiam hac vice mecum erit maritus meus, eo quod genuerim ei sex filios: et idcirco appellavit nomen eius, Zabulon.

verses.textEn: After him, she bore a daughter, named Dinah.
verses.textLa: Post quem peperit filiam, nomine Dinam.

verses.textEn: The Lord, likewise remembering Rachel, heeded her and opened her womb.
verses.textLa: Recordatus quoque Dominus Rachelis, exaudivit eam, et aperuit vulvam eius.

verses.textEn: And she conceived and bore a son, saying, “God has taken away my reproach.”
verses.textLa: Quæ concepit, et peperit filium, dicens: Abstulit Deus opprobrium meum.

verses.textEn: And she called his name Joseph, saying, “The Lord has added to me another son.”
verses.textLa: Et vocavit nomen eius, Ioseph, dicens: Addat mihi Dominus filium alterum.

verses.textEn: But when Joseph was born, Jacob said to his father-in-law: “Release me, so that I may return to my native country and to my land.
verses.textLa: Nato autem Ioseph, dixit Iacob socero suo: Dimitte me ut revertar in patriam, et ad terram meam.
verses.notes: The word ‘patriam’ might also be translated as ‘fatherland.’

verses.textEn: Give me my wives, and my children, for whom I have served you, so that I may depart. You know the servitude with which I have served you.”
verses.textLa: Da mihi uxores, et liberos meos, pro quibus servivi tibi, ut abeam: tu nosti servitutem qua servivi tibi.

verses.textEn: Laban said to him: “May I find grace in your sight. I have learned by experience that God has blessed me because of you.
verses.textLa: Ait illi Laban: Inveniam gratiam in conspectu tuo: experimento didici, quia benedixerit mihi Deus propter te:

verses.textEn: Choose your wages, which I will give you.”
verses.textLa: constitue mercedem tuam quam dem tibi.

verses.textEn: But he responded: “You know how I have served you, and how great your possession became in my hands.
verses.textLa: At ille respondit: Tu nosti quomodo servierim tibi, et quanta in manibus meis fuerit possessio tua.

verses.textEn: You had little before I came to you, and now you have achieved riches. And the Lord has blessed you since my arrival. It is just, therefore, that at some time I also should provide for my own house.”
verses.textLa: Modicum habuisti antequam venirem ad te, et nunc dives effectus es: benedixitque tibi Dominus ad introitum meum. Iustum est igitur ut aliquando provideam etiam domui meæ.

verses.textEn: And Laban said, “What shall I give to you?” But he said, “I want nothing. But if you will do what I ask, I will feed and guard your sheep again.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Laban: Quid tibi dabo? At ille ait: Nihil volo: sed si feceris quod postulo, iterum pascam, et custodiam pecora tua.

verses.textEn: Go around through all your flocks and separate all the sheep of variegated or spotted fleece; and whatever will be darkened or blemished or variegated, as much among the sheep as among the goats, will be my wages.
verses.textLa: Gyra omnes greges tuos, et separa cunctas oves varias, et sparso vellere; quodcumque furvum, et maculosum, variumque fuerit, tam in ovibus quam in capris, erit merces mea.

verses.textEn: And my justice will answer on my behalf tomorrow, when the time of settlement arrives before you. And all that is not variegated or blemished or darkened, as much among the sheep as among the goats, these will prove me to be a thief.”
verses.textLa: Respondebitque mihi cras iustitia mea, quando placiti tempus advenerit coram te: et omnia quæ non fuerint varia, et maculosa, et furva, tam in ovibus quam in capris, furti me arguent.

verses.textEn: And Laban said, “I hold favor for this request.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Laban: Gratum habeo quod petis.

verses.textEn: And on that day he separated the she-goats, and the sheep, and the he-goats, and the rams with variegations or with blemishes. But every one of the flock which was of one color, that is, of white or of black fleece, he delivered into the hands of his sons.
verses.textLa: Et separavit in die illa capras, et oves, et hircos, et arietes varios, atque maculosos: cunctum autem gregem unicolorem, id est albi, et nigri velleris, tradidit in manu filiorum suorum.

verses.textEn: And he established a distance of three days journey between himself and his son-in-law, who pastured the remainder of his flock.
verses.textLa: Et posuit spatium itineris trium dierum inter se et generum, qui pascebat reliquos greges eius.

verses.textEn: Then Jacob, taking green branches of poplar, and almond, and sycamore trees, debarked them in part. And when the bark was pulled off, in the parts that were stripped, there appeared whiteness, yet the parts that were left whole, remained green. And so, in this way the color was made variegated.
verses.textLa: Tollens ergo Iacob virgas populeas virides, et amygdalinas, et ex platanis, ex parte decorticavit eas: detractisque corticibus, in his, quæ spoliata fuerant, candor apparuit: illa vero quæ integra fuerant, viridia permanserunt: atque in hunc modum color effectus est varius.

verses.textEn: And he placed them in the troughs, where the water was poured out, so that when the flocks had arrived to drink, they would have the branches before their eyes, and in their sight they might conceive.
verses.textLa: Posuitque eas in canalibus, ubi effundebatur aqua: ut cum venissent greges ad bibendum, ante oculos haberent virgas, et in aspectu earum conciperent.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, in the very heat of joining together, the sheep looked upon the branches, and they bore the blemished and the variegated, those speckled with diverse color.
verses.textLa: Factumque est ut in ipso calore coitus, oves intuerentur virgas, et parerent maculosa, et varia, et diverso colore respersa.

verses.textEn: And Jacob divided the flock, and he set the branches in the troughs before the eyes of the rams. Now whatever was white or black belonged to Laban, but, in truth, the others belonged to Jacob, for the flocks were dispersed among one another.
verses.textLa: Divisitque gregem Iacob, et posuit virgas in canalibus ante oculos arietum: erant autem alba et nigra quæque, Laban: cetera vero, Iacob, separatis inter se gregibus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when the first to arrive were climbing on the ewes, Jacob placed the branches in the troughs of water before the eyes of the rams and the sheep, so that they might conceive while they were gazing upon them.
verses.textLa: Igitur quando primo tempore ascendebantur oves, ponebat Iacob virgas in canalibus aquarum ante oculos arietum et ovium, ut in earum contemplatione conciperent:

verses.textEn: Yet when the late arrivals and the last to conceive were let in, he did not place these. And so those that arrived late became Laban’s, and those that arrived first became Jacob’s.
verses.textLa: quando vero serotina admissura erat, et conceptus extremus, non ponebat eas. Factaque sunt ea quæ erant serotina, Laban: et quæ primi temporis, Iacob.

verses.textEn: And the man was enriched beyond limit, and he had many flocks, women servants and men servants, camels and donkeys.
verses.textLa: Ditatusque est homo ultra modum, et habuit greges multos, ancillas et servos, camelos et asinos.

verses.textEn: But afterwards, he heard the words of the sons of Laban, saying, “Jacob has taken all that was our father’s, and being enlarged by his ability, he has become famous.”
verses.textLa: Postquam autem audivit verba filiorum Laban dicentium: Tulit Iacob omnia quæ fuerunt patris nostri, et de illius facultate ditatus, factus est inclytus:

verses.textEn: Likewise, he observed that Laban’s face was not the same toward him as it was yesterday and the day before.
verses.textLa: animadvertit quoque faciem Laban, quod non esset erga se sicut heri et nudiustertius,

verses.textEn: Most importantly, the Lord was saying to him, “Return to the land of your fathers and to your generation, and I will be with you.”
verses.textLa: maxime dicente sibi Domino: Revertere in terram patrum tuorum, et ad generationem tuam, eroque tecum.

verses.textEn: He sent and called for Rachel and Leah, in the field where he pastured the flocks,
verses.textLa: Misit, et vocavit Rachel et Liam in agrum, ubi pascebat greges,

verses.textEn: and he said to them: “I see that your father’s face is not the same toward me as it was yesterday and the day before. But the God of my father has been with me.
verses.textLa: dixitque eis: Video faciem patris vestri quod non sit erga me sicut heri, et nudiustertius: Deus autem patris mei fuit mecum.

verses.textEn: And you know that I have served your father with all my strength.
verses.textLa: Et ipsæ nostis quod totis viribus meis servierim patri vestro.

verses.textEn: Even so, your father has circumvented me, and he has changed my wages ten times. And yet God has not permitted him to harm me.
verses.textLa: Sed et pater vester circumvenit me, et mutavit mercedem meam decem vicibus: et tamen non dimisit eum Deus ut noceret mihi.

verses.textEn: Whenever he said, ‘The speckled will be your wages,’ all the sheep gave birth to speckled newborns. Yet truly, when he said the contrary, ‘You will take whatever is white for your wages,’ all the flocks gave birth to white ones.
verses.textLa: Si quando dixit: Variæ erunt mercedes tuæ: pariebant omnes oves varios fœtus. Quando vero econtrario ait: Alba quæque accipies pro mercede: omnes greges alba pepererunt.

verses.textEn: And it is God who has taken your father’s substance and given it to me.
verses.textLa: Tulitque Deus substantiam patris vestri, et dedit mihi.

verses.textEn: For after the time had arrived for the ewes to conceive, I lifted up my eyes, and I saw in my sleep that the males climbing on the females were of variegated, and spotted, and diverse colors.
verses.textLa: Postquam enim conceptus ovium tempus advenerat, levavi oculos meos, et vidi in somnis ascendentes mares super feminas, varios et maculosos, et diversorum colorum.

verses.textEn: And the Angel of God said to me in my sleep, ‘Jacob.’ And I responded, ‘Here I am.’
verses.textLa: Dixitque Angelus Dei ad me in somnis: Iacob? Et ego respondi: Adsum.

verses.textEn: And he said: ‘Lift up your eyes, and see that all the males climbing on the females are variegated, spotted, and also speckled. For I have seen all that Laban has done to you.
verses.textLa: Qui ait: Leva oculos tuos, et vide universos masculos ascendentes super feminas, varios, maculosos, atque respersos. Vidi enim omnia quæ fecit tibi Laban.

verses.textEn: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed the stone and made a vow to me. Now therefore arise, and depart from this land, returning to the land of your nativity.’ ”
verses.textLa: Ego sum Deus Bethel, ubi unxisti lapidem, et votum vovisti mihi. Nunc ergo surge, et egredere de terra hac, revertens in terram nativitatis tuæ.
verses.notes: The Angel says, ‘I am the God of Bethel....’ because the Angel was sent to convey God’s words to Jacob. In ancient times, when one wanted to convey a message to someone, one would send another person, usually a youth, to that someone to repeat your words to them. So it made perfect sense to Jacob that God would send an Angel (a messenger of God) convey a message by repeating God’s words to Jacob.

verses.textEn: And Rachel and Leah responded: “Have we anything left behind among the resources and inheritance of our father’s house?
verses.textLa: Responderuntque Rachel et Lia: Numquid habemus residui quidquam in facultatibus, et hereditate domus patris nostri?

verses.textEn: Has he not considered us as foreigners, and sold us, and consumed our price?
verses.textLa: Nonne quasi alienas reputavit nos, et vendidit, comeditque pretium nostrum?

verses.textEn: But God has taken our father’s riches and handed these to us and to our sons. Therefore, do all that God has instructed you.”
verses.textLa: Sed Deus tulit opes patris nostri, et eas tradidit nobis, ac filiis nostris: unde omnia quæ præcepit tibi Deus, fac.

verses.textEn: And so Jacob rose up, and having placed the children and his wives upon camels, he went forth.
verses.textLa: Surrexit itaque Iacob, et impositis liberis, ac coniugibus suis super camelos, abiit.

verses.textEn: And he took all his substance and flocks, and whatever he had acquired in Mesopotamia, and he journeyed to his father Isaac, in the land of Canaan.
verses.textLa: Tulitque omnem substantiam suam, et greges, et quidquid in Mesopotamia acquisierat, pergens ad Isaac patrem suum in terram Chanaan.

verses.textEn: At that time, Laban had gone to shear the sheep, and so Rachel stole her father’s idols.
verses.textLa: Eo tempore ierat Laban ad tondendas oves, et Rachel furata est idola patris sui.

verses.textEn: And Jacob was not willing to confess to his father-in-law that he was fleeing.
verses.textLa: Noluitque Iacob confiteri socero suo quod fugeret.

verses.textEn: And when he had gone away with all such things that were justly his, and, having crossed the river, was continuing on toward Mount Gilead,
verses.textLa: Cumque abiisset tam ipse quam omnia quæ iuris sui erant, et amne transmisso pergeret contra Montem Galaad,

verses.textEn: it was reported to Laban on the third day that Jacob had fled.
verses.textLa: nunciatum est Laban die tertio quod fugeret Iacob.

verses.textEn: And taking his brothers with him, he pursued him for seven days. And he overtook him at Mount Gilead.
verses.textLa: Qui, assumptis fratribus suis, persecutus est eum diebus septem: et comprehendit eum in Monte Galaad.

verses.textEn: And he saw in a dream, God saying to him, “Beware that you not speak anything harsh against Jacob.”
verses.textLa: Viditque in somnis dicentem sibi Deum: Cave ne quidquam aspere loquaris contra Iacob.

verses.textEn: And now Jacob had pitched his tent at the mountain. And when he, with his brothers, had overtaken him, he set his tent at the same place at Mount Gilead.
verses.textLa: Iamque Iacob extenderat in monte tabernaculum: cumque ille consecutus fuisset eum cum fratribus suis, in eodem Monte Galaad fixit tentorium.

verses.textEn: And he said to Jacob: “Why have you acted this way, departing from me in secret, with my daughters like captives of the sword?
verses.textLa: Et dixit ad Iacob: Quare ita egisti, ut clam me abigeres filias meas quasi captivas gladio?

verses.textEn: Why would you want to flee without my knowledge and without telling me, though I might have led you forward with gladness, and songs, and timbrels, and lyres?
verses.textLa: Cur ignorante me fugere voluisti, nec indicare mihi, ut prosequerer te cum gaudio, et canticis, et tympanis, et citharis?

verses.textEn: You have not permitted me to kiss my sons and daughters. You have acted foolishly. And now, indeed,
verses.textLa: Non es passus ut oscularer filios meos et filias: stulte operatus es: et nunc quidem

verses.textEn: my hand has power to repay you with harm. But the God of your father said to me yesterday, ‘Beware that you not speak anything stern against Jacob.’
verses.textLa: valet manus mea reddere tibi malum: sed Deus patris vestri heri dixit mihi: Cave ne loquaris contra Iacob quidquam durius.

verses.textEn: It may be that you desired to go to your own, and that you longed for the house of your father. But why have you stolen my gods?”
verses.textLa: Esto, ad tuos ire cupiebas, et desiderio erat tibi domus patris tui: cur furatus es deos meos?

verses.textEn: Jacob answered: “I set out, unknown to you, because I feared that you might take away your daughters by violence.
verses.textLa: Respondit Iacob: Quod inscio te profectus sum, timui ne violenter auferres filias tuas.

verses.textEn: But, since you accuse me of theft, with whomever you will find your gods, let him be slain in the sight of our brothers. Search; anything of yours that you will find with me, take it away.” Now when he said this, he did not know that Rachel had stolen the idols.
verses.textLa: Quod autem furti me arguis: apud quemcumque inveneris deos tuos, necetur coram fratribus nostris. Scrutare, quidquid tuorum apud me inveneris, et aufer. Hæc dicens, ignorabat quod Rachel furata esset idola.

verses.textEn: And so Laban, entering the tent of Jacob, and of Leah, and of both the handmaids, did not find them. And when he had entered the tent of Rachel,
verses.textLa: Ingressus itaque Laban tabernaculum Iacob et Liæ, et utriusque famulæ, non invenit. Cumque intrasset tentorium Rachelis,

verses.textEn: she quickly hid the idols under the camel’s bedding, and she sat upon them. And when he had searched the entire tent and found nothing,
verses.textLa: illa festinans abscondit idola subter stramenta cameli, et sedit desuper: scrutantique omne tentorium, et nihil invenienti,

verses.textEn: she said: “Do not be angry, my lord, that I am unable to rise up in your sight, because it has now happened to me according to the custom of women.” So his careful search was thwarted.
verses.textLa: ait: Ne irascatur dominus meus quod coram te assurgere nequeo: quia iuxta consuetudinem feminarum nunc accidit mihi. Sic delusa solicitudo quærentis est.

verses.textEn: And Jacob, being inflated, said with contention: “For which fault of mine, or for what sin of mine, have you become so enraged against me
verses.textLa: Tumensque Iacob, cum iurgio ait: Quam ob culpam meam, et ob quod peccatum meum sic exarsisti post me,

verses.textEn: and searched all the items of my house? What have you found from all the substance of your house? Place it here before my brothers, and your brothers, and let them judge between me and you.
verses.textLa: et scrutatus es omnem supellectilem meam? Quid invenisti de cuncta substantia domus tuæ? pone hic coram fratribus meis, et fratribus tuis, et iudicent inter me, et te.

verses.textEn: For what reason have I been with you for twenty years? Your ewes and she-goats were not barren; the rams of your flocks I did not consume.
verses.textLa: Idcirco viginti annis fui tecum? oves tuæ et capræ steriles non fuerunt, arietes gregis tui non comedi:

verses.textEn: Neither did I reveal to you what was seized by the wild beast. I replaced all that was damaged. Whatever was lost by theft, you collected it from me.
verses.textLa: nec captum a bestia ostendi tibi, ego damnum omne reddebam: quidquid furto peribat, a me exigebas:

verses.textEn: Day and night, I was burned by heat and by frost, and sleep fled from my eyes.
verses.textLa: die noctuque æstu urebar, et gelu, fugiebatque somnus ab oculis meis.

verses.textEn: And in this way, for twenty years, I have served you in your house: fourteen for your daughters, and six for your flocks. You have also changed my wages ten times.
verses.textLa: Sicque per viginti annos in domo tua servivi tibi, quatuordecim pro filiabus, et sex pro gregibus tuis: immutasti quoque mercedem meam decem vicibus.

verses.textEn: If the God of my father Abraham and the fear of Isaac had not been close to me, perhaps by now you would have sent me away naked. But God looked kindly on my affliction and the labor of my hands, and he rebuked you yesterday.”
verses.textLa: Nisi Deus patris mei Abraham, et timor Isaac affuisset mihi, forsitan modo nudum me dimisisses: afflictionem meam et laborem manuum mearum respexit Deus, et arguit te heri.

verses.textEn: Laban answered him: “My daughters and sons, and your flocks, and all that you discern are mine. What can I do to my sons and grandchildren?
verses.textLa: Respondit ei Laban: Filiæ meæ et filii, et greges tui, et omnia quæ cernis, mea sunt: quid possum facere filiis et nepotibus meis?

verses.textEn: Come, therefore, let us enter into a pact, so that it may be a testimony between me and you.”
verses.textLa: Veni ergo, et ineamus fœdus: ut sit in testimonium inter me et te.

verses.textEn: And so Jacob took a stone, and he set it up as a memorial.
verses.textLa: Tulit itaque Iacob lapidem, et erexit illum in titulum:

verses.textEn: And he said to his brothers, “Bring stones.” And they, gathering together stones, made a tomb, and they ate upon it.
verses.textLa: dixitque fratribus suis: Afferte lapides. Qui congregantes fecerunt tumulum, comederuntque super eum:

verses.textEn: And Laban called it, ‘Tomb of Witness,’ and Jacob, ‘Pile of Testimony;’ each of them according to the fitness of his own language.
verses.textLa: quem vocavit Laban Tumulum Testis: et Iacob, Acervum Testimonii, uterque iuxta proprietatem linguæ suæ.
verses.notes: Here is a verse whereby the Bible comments on its own translation, permitting an event to be described with varied wording, as best fits the language into which it is translated. Also, note that what each one chooses to call it reveals his attitude towards the agreement. Laban’s ‘tumulum’ can be translated as ‘tomb’ (cf. Job 10:19). Laban was losing his daughters, flocks, and son-in-law (a valuable employee); this loss was like a kind of death to him. But Jacob thought little of this agreement, for it was merely an agreement to let him have what was already justly his. So he calls it ‘acervum,’ which means ‘little hill’ or ‘pile’ or ‘heap.’

verses.textEn: And Laban said: “This tomb will be a witness between me and you this day.” (And for this reason, its name has been called Gilead, that is, ‘Tomb of Witness.’)
verses.textLa: Dixitque Laban: Tumulus iste erit testis inter me et te hodie: et idcirco appellatum est nomen eius Galaad, id est, Tumulus Testis.

verses.textEn: “May the Lord consider and judge between us, when we will have withdrawn from one another.
verses.textLa: Intueatur et iudicet Dominus inter nos quando recesserimus a nobis,

verses.textEn: If you afflict my daughters, and if you bring in other wives over them, no one is a witness of our words except God, who understands beforehand.”
verses.textLa: si afflixeris filias meas, et si introduxeris alias uxores super eas: nullus sermonis nostri testis est absque Deo, qui præsens respicit.
verses.notes: The verb ‘respicit’ does not merely mean ‘to see.’ It means to see and understand, or to look with the intention of understanding. And the word ‘praesens’ is the word ‘sens’ (a form of the verb ‘to be’) and the prefix ‘prae’ which means ‘before.’ As a phrase taken as a whole, and in this context, ‘præsens respicit’ means to understand beforehand.

verses.textEn: And again he said to Jacob. “Lo, this tomb and the stone that I have set up between me and you,
verses.textLa: Dixitque rursus ad Iacob: En tumulus hic, et lapis quem erexi inter me et te,

verses.textEn: will be a witness. This tomb,” I say, “and the stone, they are for testimony, in case either I cross beyond it going toward you, or you cross beyond it thinking to harm me.
verses.textLa: testis erit: tumulus, inquam, iste et lapis sint in testimonium, si aut ego transiero illum pergens ad te, aut tu præterieris, malum mihi cogitans.

verses.textEn: May the God of Abraham, and the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us.” Therefore, Jacob swore by the fear of his father Isaac.
verses.textLa: Deus Abraham, et Deus Nachor iudicet inter nos, Deus patris eorum. Iuravit ergo Iacob per timorem patris sui Isaac:

verses.textEn: And after he had immolated sacrifices on the mountain, he called his brothers to eat bread. And when they had eaten, they lodged there.
verses.textLa: immolatisque victimis in monte, vocavit fratres suos ut ederent panem. Qui cum comedissent, manserunt ibi.

verses.textEn: In truth, Laban rose up in the night, and he kissed his sons and daughters, and he blessed them. And he returned to his place.
verses.textLa: Laban vero de nocte consurgens, osculatus est filios, et filias suas, et benedixit illis: reversusque est in locum suum.

verses.textEn: Likewise, Jacob continued on the journey that he had begun. And the Angels of God met him.
verses.textLa: Iacob quoque abiit itinere quo cœperat: fueruntque ei obviam Angeli Dei.

verses.textEn: When he had seen them, he said, “These are the Encampments of God.” And he called the name of that place Mahanaim, that is, ‘Encampments.’
verses.textLa: Quos cum vidisset, ait: Castra Dei sunt hæc. Et appellavit nomen loci illius Mahanaim, id est, Castra.

verses.textEn: Then he also sent messengers before him to his brother Esau, in the land of Seir, in the region of Edom.
verses.textLa: Misit autem et nuncios ante se ad Esau fratrem suum in terram Seir, in regionem Edom:

verses.textEn: And he instructed them, saying: “You shall speak in this way to my lord Esau: ‘Your brother Jacob says these things: “I have sojourned with Laban, and I have been with him until the present day.
verses.textLa: præcepitque eis, dicens: Sic loquimini domino meo Esau: Hæc dicit frater tuus Iacob: Apud Laban peregrinatus sum, et fui usque in præsentem diem.

verses.textEn: I have oxen, and donkeys, and sheep, and men servants, and women servants. And now I send an ambassador to my lord, so that I may find favor in your sight.” ’ ”
verses.textLa: Habeo boves, et asinos, et oves, et servos, et ancillas: mittoque nunc legationem ad dominum meum, ut inveniam gratiam in conspectu tuo.

verses.textEn: And the messengers returned to Jacob, saying, “We went to your brother Esau, and behold, he rushes to meet you with four hundred men.”
verses.textLa: Reversique sunt nuncii ad Iacob, dicentes: Venimus ad Esau fratrem tuum, et ecce properat tibi in occursum cum quadringentis viris.

verses.textEn: Jacob was very afraid. And in his terror, he divided the people who were with him, likewise the flocks, and the sheep, and the oxen, and the camels, into two companies,
verses.textLa: Timuit Iacob valde: et perterritus divisit populum qui secum erat, greges quoque et oves et boves, et camelos in duas turmas,

verses.textEn: saying: “If Esau goes to one company, and strikes it, the other company, which is left behind, will be saved.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Si venerit Esau ad unam turmam, et percusserit eam, alia turma, quæ relicta est, salvabitur.

verses.textEn: And Jacob said: “God of my father Abraham, and God of my father Isaac, O Lord who said to me: ‘Return to your land, and to the place of your nativity, and I will do well for you.’
verses.textLa: Dixitque Iacob: Deus patris mei Abraham, et Deus patris mei Isaac: Domine qui dixisti mihi: Revertere in terram tuam, et in locum nativitatis tuæ, et benefaciam tibi:

verses.textEn: I am less than any of your compassions and your truth, which you have fulfilled to your servant. With my staff I crossed over this Jordan. And now I go back with two companies.
verses.textLa: minor sum cunctis miserationibus tuis, et veritate tua quam explevisti servo tuo. In baculo meo transivi Iordanem istum: et nunc cum duabus turmis regredior.

verses.textEn: Rescue me from the hand of my brother Esau, for I am very afraid of him, lest perhaps he may come and strike down the mother with the sons.
verses.textLa: Erue me de manu fratris mei Esau, quia valde eum timeo: ne forte veniens percutiat matrem cum filiis.

verses.textEn: You did say that you would do well by me, and that you would expand my offspring like the sand of the sea, which, because of its multitude, cannot be numbered.”
verses.textLa: Tu locutus es quod benefaceres mihi, et dilatares semen meum sicut arenam maris, quæ præ multitudine numerari non potest.

verses.textEn: And when he had slept there that night, he separated, from the things that he had, gifts for his brother Esau:
verses.textLa: Cumque dormisset ibi nocte illa, separavit de his quæ habebat, munera Esau fratri suo,

verses.textEn: two hundred she-goats, twenty he-goats, two hundred ewes, and twenty rams,
verses.textLa: capras ducentas, hircos viginti, oves ducentas, et arietes viginti,

verses.textEn: thirty milking camels with their young, forty cows, and twenty bulls, twenty she-donkeys, and ten of their young.
verses.textLa: camelos fœtas cum pullis suis triginta, vaccas quadraginta, et tauros viginti, asinas viginti, et pullos earum decem.

verses.textEn: And he sent them by the hands of his servants, each flock separately, and he said to his servants: “Pass before me, and let there be a space between flock and flock.”
verses.textLa: Et misit per manus servorum suorum singulos seorsum greges, dixitque pueris suis: Antecedite me, et sit spatium inter gregem et gregem.

verses.textEn: And he instructed the first, saying: “If you happen to meet my brother Esau, and he questions you: “Whose are you?” or, “Where are you going?” or, “Whose are these which follow you?”
verses.textLa: Et præcepit priori, dicens: Si obvium habueris fratrem meum Esau, et interrogaverit te, Cuius es? aut, Quo vadis? aut, Cuius sunt ista quæ sequeris?

verses.textEn: you shall respond: “Your servant Jacob’s. He has sent them as a gift to my lord Esau. And he is also coming after us.”
verses.textLa: respondebis: Servi tui Iacob, munera misit domino meo Esau: ipse quoque post nos venit.

verses.textEn: Similarly, he gave orders to the second, and the third, and to all who followed the flocks, saying: “Speak these same words to Esau, when you find him.
verses.textLa: Similiter dedit mandata secundo, et tertio, et cunctis qui sequebantur greges, dicens: Iisdem verbis loquimini ad Esau, cum inveneritis eum.

verses.textEn: And you will add: ‘Your servant Jacob himself also follows after us, for he said: “I will appease him with the gifts that go ahead, and after this, I will see him; perhaps he will be gracious to me.” ’ ”
verses.textLa: Et addetis: Ipse quoque servus tuus Iacob iter nostrum insequitur: dixit enim: Placabo illum muneribus quæ præcedunt, et postea videbo illum, forsitan propitiabitur mihi.

verses.textEn: And so the gifts went before him, but he himself lodged that night in the camp.
verses.textLa: Præcesserunt itaque munera ante eum, ipse vero mansit nocte illa in castris.

verses.textEn: And when he had arisen early, he took his two wives, and the same number of handmaids, with his eleven sons, and he crossed over the ford of Jabbok.
verses.textLa: Cumque mature surrexisset, tulit duas uxores suas, et totidem famulas cum undecim filiis, et transivit vadum Iaboc.

verses.textEn: And having delivered over all the things that belonged to him,
verses.textLa: Traductisque omnibus quæ ad se pertinebant,

verses.textEn: he remained alone. And behold, a man wrestled with him until morning.
verses.textLa: mansit solus: et ecce vir luctabatur cum eo usque mane.

verses.textEn: And when he saw that he would not be able to overcome him, he touched the nerve of his thigh, and immediately it withered.
verses.textLa: Qui cum videret quod eum superare non posset, tetigit nervum femoris eius, et statim emarcuit.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, “Release me, for now the dawn ascends.” He responded, “I will not release you, unless you bless me.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad eum: Dimitte me, iam enim ascendit aurora. Respondit: Non dimittam te, nisi benedixeris mihi.

verses.textEn: Therefore he said, “What is your name?” He answered, “Jacob.”
verses.textLa: Ait ergo: Quod nomen est tibi? Respondit: Iacob.

verses.textEn: But he said, “Your name will not be called Jacob, but Israel; for if you have been strong against God, how much more will you prevail against men?”
verses.textLa: At ille, Nequaquam, inquit, Iacob appellabitur nomen tuum, sed Israel: quoniam si contra Deum fortis fuisti, quanto magis contra homines prævalebis?

verses.textEn: Jacob questioned him, “Tell me, by what name are you called?” He responded, “Why do you ask my name?” And he blessed him in the same place.
verses.textLa: Interrogavit eum Iacob: Dic mihi, quo appellaris nomine? Respondit: Cur quæris nomen meum? Et benedixit ei in eodem loco.

verses.textEn: And Jacob called the name of the place Peniel, saying, “I have seen God face to face, and my soul has been saved.”
verses.textLa: Vocavitque Iacob nomen loci illius Phanuel, dicens: Vidi Deum facie ad faciem, et salva facta est anima mea.

verses.textEn: And immediately the sun rose upon him, after he had crossed beyond Peniel. Yet in truth, he limped on his foot.
verses.textLa: Ortusque est ei statim sol, postquam transgressus est Phanuel: ipse vero claudicabat pede.

verses.textEn: For this reason, the sons of Israel, even to the present day, do not eat the nerve that withered in Jacob’s thigh, because he touched the nerve of his thigh and it was obstructed.
verses.textLa: Quam ob causam non comedunt nervum filii Israel, qui emarcuit in femore Iacob, usque in præsentem diem: eo quod tetigerit nervum femoris eius, et obstupuerit.

verses.textEn: Then Jacob, lifting up his eyes, saw Esau arriving, and with him four hundred men. And he divided the sons of Leah and Rachel, and of both the handmaids.
verses.textLa: Elevans autem Iacob oculos suos, vidit venientem Esau, et cum eo quadringentos viros: divisitque filios Liæ et Rachel, ambarumque famularum:

verses.textEn: And he placed the two handmaids and their children at the beginning. Truly, Leah and her sons were in the second place. Then Rachel and Joseph were last.
verses.textLa: et posuit utramque ancillam, et liberos earum in principio: Liam vero, et filios eius in secundo loco: Rachel autem, et Ioseph novissimos.

verses.textEn: And advancing, he reverenced prostrate on the ground seven times, until his brother approached.
verses.textLa: Et ipse progrediens adoravit pronus in terram septies, donec appropinquaret frater eius.

verses.textEn: And so Esau ran to meet his brother, and he embraced him. And drawing him by his neck and kissing him, he wept.
verses.textLa: Currens itaque Esau obviam fratri suo, amplexatus est eum: stringensque collum eius, et osculans flevit.

verses.textEn: And lifting up his eyes, he saw the women and their little ones, and he said: “What do these want for themselves?” and “Are they related to you?” He responded, “These are the little ones that God has given as a gift to me, your servant.”
verses.textLa: Levatisque oculis, vidit mulieres et parvulos earum, et ait: Quid sibi volunt isti? et si ad te pertinent? Respondit: Parvuli sunt, quos donavit mihi Deus servo tuo.
verses.notes: The word ‘donavit’ is a verb which refers to giving a gift; it is difficult to accurately express in English with only one word. It might even be rendered ‘gifted’ rather than ‘given.’ “These are the little ones that God has gifted to me, your servant.”

verses.textEn: Then the handmaids and their sons approached and bowed down.
verses.textLa: Et appropinquantes ancillæ et filii earum, incurvati sunt.

verses.textEn: Likewise Leah, with her sons, came near. And when they had reverenced similarly, last of all, Joseph and Rachel reverenced.
verses.textLa: Accessit quoque Lia cum pueris suis: et cum similiter adorassent, extremi Ioseph et Rachel adoraverunt.

verses.textEn: And Esau said, “What are these companies that I have been meeting?” He responded, “So may I find favor before my lord.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Esau: Quænam sunt istæ turmæ quas obviam habui? Respondit: Ut invenirem gratiam coram domino meo.

verses.textEn: But he said, “I have plenty, my brother; let these be for yourself.”
verses.textLa: At ille ait: Habeo plurima, frater mi, sint tua tibi.

verses.textEn: And Jacob said: “I beg you, let it not be so. But if I have found favor in your eyes, receive a small present from my hands. For I have looked upon your face as I would look upon the countenance of God. Be gracious to me,
verses.textLa: Dixitque Iacob: Noli ita, obsecro: sed si inveni gratiam in oculis tuis, accipe munusculum de manibus meis: sic enim vidi faciem tuam, quasi viderim vultum Dei: esto mihi propitius,

verses.textEn: and take the blessing which I have brought to you, and which God, who bestows all things, has given as a gift to me.” Accepting it reluctantly, at the insistence of his brother,
verses.textLa: et suscipe benedictionem quam attuli tibi, et quam donavit mihi Deus tribuens omnia. Vix fratre compellente, suscipiens,

verses.textEn: he said, “Let us go on together, and I will accompany you on your journey.”
verses.textLa: ait: Gradiamur simul, eroque socius itineris tui.

verses.textEn: And Jacob said: “My lord, you know that I have with me tender little ones, and sheep, and cows with young. If I cause these to labor too much in walking, all the flocks will die in one day.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Iacob: Nosti domine mi quod parvulos habeam teneros, et oves, et boves fœtas mecum: quas si plus in ambulando fecero laborare, morientur una die cuncti greges.

verses.textEn: May it please my lord to go before his servant. And I will follow gradually in his steps, as much as I see my little ones to be able, until I arrive to my lord in Seir.”
verses.textLa: Præcedat dominus meus ante servum suum: et ego sequar paulatim vestigia eius, sicut videro parvulos meos posse, donec veniam ad dominum meum in Seir.

verses.textEn: Esau responded, “I beg you, that at least some of the people who are with me may remain to accompany you on the way.” But he said, “There is no need. I have need of one thing only: to find favor in your sight, my lord.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Esau: Oro te, ut de populo qui mecum est, saltem socri remaneant viæ tuæ. Non est, inquit, necesse: hoc uno tantum indigeo, ut inveniam gratiam in conspectu tuo domine mi.

verses.textEn: And so Esau returned that day, by the way that he had arrived, to Seir.
verses.textLa: Reversus est itaque illo die Esau itinere quo venerat in Seir.

verses.textEn: And Jacob went to Succoth, where, having built a house and pitched tents, he called the name of that place Succoth, that is, ‘Tents.’
verses.textLa: Et Iacob venit in Socoth: ubi ædificata domo et fixis tentoriis appellavit nomen loci illius Socoth, id est, Tabernacula.

verses.textEn: And he crossed over to Salem, a city of the Shechemites, which is in the land of Canaan, after he returned from Mesopotamia of Syria. And he lived near the town.
verses.textLa: Transivitque in Salem urbem Sichimorum, quæ est in terra Chanaan, postquam reversus est de Mesopotamia Syriæ: et habitavit iuxta oppidum.

verses.textEn: And he bought the part of the field in which he had pitched his tents from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for one hundred lambs.
verses.textLa: Emitque partem agri in qua fixerat tabernacula, a filiis Hemor patris Sichem centum agnis.

verses.textEn: And erecting an altar there, he invoked upon it the most strong God of Israel.
verses.textLa: Et erecto ibi altari, invocavit super illud fortissimum Deum Israel.

verses.textEn: Then Dinah, the daughter of Leah, went out to see the women of that region.
verses.textLa: Egressa est autem Dina filia Liæ ut videret mulieres regionis illius.

verses.textEn: And when Shechem, the son of Hamor the Hivite, the leader of that land, had seen her, he fell in love with her. And so he seized her and slept with her, overwhelming the virgin by force.
verses.textLa: Quam cum vidisset Sichem filius Hemor Hevæi, princeps terræ illius, adamavit eam: et rapuit, et dormivit cum illa, vi opprimens virginem.

verses.textEn: And his soul was closely bound to her, and, since she was sorrowful, he soothed her with flattery.
verses.textLa: Et conglutinata est anima eius cum ea, tristemque delinivit blanditiis.

verses.textEn: And going on to Hamor, his father, he said, “Obtain this girl for me as a mate.”
verses.textLa: Et pergens ad Hemor patrem suum, Accipe, inquit, mihi puellam hanc coniugem.

verses.textEn: But when Jacob had heard this, since his sons were absent and he was occupied in pasturing the cattle, he remained silent until they came back.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset Iacob, absentibus filiis, et in pastu pecorum occupatis, siluit donec redirent.

verses.textEn: Then, when Hamor, the father of Shechem, had gone out to speak to Jacob,
verses.textLa: Egresso autem Hemor patre Sichem ut loqueretur ad Iacob,

verses.textEn: behold, his sons arrived from the field. And hearing what had happened, they were very angry, because he had done a filthy thing in Israel and, in violating a daughter of Jacob, had perpetrated an unlawful act.
verses.textLa: ecce filii eius veniebant de agro: auditoque quod acciderat, irati sunt valde, eo quod fœdam rem operatus esset in Israel et, violata filia Iacob, rem illicitam perpetrasset.

verses.textEn: And so Hamor spoke to them: “The soul of my son Shechem has become attached to your daughter. Give her to him as a wife.
verses.textLa: Locutus est itaque Hemor ad eos: Sichem filii mei adhæsit anima filiæ vestræ: date eam illi uxorem:

verses.textEn: And let us celebrate marriages with one with another. Give us your daughters, and receive our daughters.
verses.textLa: et iungamus vicissim connubia: filias vestras tradite nobis, et filias nostras accipite.

verses.textEn: And live with us. The land is in your power: cultivate, trade, and possess it.”
verses.textLa: Et habitate nobiscum: terra in potestate vestra est, exercete, negotiamini, et possidete eam.

verses.textEn: And Shechem even said to her father and to her brothers: “May I find favor in your sight, and whatever you will appoint, I will give.
verses.textLa: Sed et Sichem ad patrem et ad fratres eius ait: Inveniam gratiam coram vobis: et quæcumque statueritis, dabo:

verses.textEn: Increase the dowry, and request gifts, and I will freely bestow what you will ask. Only give me this girl as a wife.”
verses.textLa: augete dotem, et munera postulate, et libenter tribuam quod petieritis: tantum date mihi puellam hanc uxorem.

verses.textEn: The sons of Jacob answered Shechem and his father with deceit, being enraged at the rape of their sister:
verses.textLa: Responderunt filii Iacob Sichem et patri eius in dolo, sævientes ob stuprum sororis:

verses.textEn: “We are not able to do what you ask, nor to give our sister to an uncircumcised man. For us, this is unlawful and abominable.
verses.textLa: Non possumus facere quod petitis, nec dare sororem nostram homini incircumciso: quod illicitum et nefarium est apud nos.

verses.textEn: But we may succeed in this, so as to be allied with you, if you are willing to become like us, and if all the male sex among you will be circumcised.
verses.textLa: Sed in hoc valebimus fœderari, si volueritis esse similes nostri, et circumcidatur in vobis omne masculini sexus;

verses.textEn: Then we will mutually give and receive your daughters as well as ours; and we will live with you, and we will become one people.
verses.textLa: tunc dabimus et accipiemus mutuo filias vestras, ac nostras: et habitabimus vobiscum, erimusque unus populus:

verses.textEn: But if you will not be circumcised, we will take our daughter and withdraw.”
verses.textLa: si autem circumcidi nolueritis, tollemus filiam nostram, et recedemus.

verses.textEn: Their offer pleased Hamor and his son Shechem.
verses.textLa: Placuit oblatio eorum Hemor, et Sichem filio eius:

verses.textEn: Neither did the young man cause any delay; in fact he immediately fulfilled what was requested. For he loved the girl very much, and he was well-known throughout his father’s house.
verses.textLa: nec distulit adolescens quin statim quod petebatur expleret: amabat enim puellam valde, et ipse erat inclytus in omni domo patris sui.

verses.textEn: And entering at the gate of the city, they spoke to the people:
verses.textLa: Ingressique portam urbis, locuti sunt ad populum:

verses.textEn: “These men are peaceful, and they want to live among us. Let them trade in the land and cultivate it, for, being spacious and broad, it is in need of cultivation. We will receive their daughters as wives, and we will give them ours.
verses.textLa: Viri isti pacifici sunt, et volunt habitare nobiscum: negotientur in terra, et exerceant eam, quæ spatiosa et lata cultoribus indiget: filias eorum accipiemus uxores, et nostras illis dabimus.

verses.textEn: There is one thing that prevents so great a good: whether we will circumcise our males, imitating the ritual of their nation.
verses.textLa: Unum est quo differtur tantum bonum: Si circumcidamus masculos nostros, ritum gentis imitantes.

verses.textEn: And their substance, and cattle, and all that they possess, will be ours, if only we will acquiesce to this, and so, in living together, will form one people.”
verses.textLa: Et substantia eorum, et pecora, et cuncta quæ possident, nostra erunt: tantum in hoc acquiescamus, et habitantes simul, unum efficiemus populum.

verses.textEn: And they all agreed to circumcise every one of the males.
verses.textLa: Assensique sunt omnes, circumcisis cunctis maribus.

verses.textEn: And behold, on the third day, when the pain of the wound was greatest, two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, the brothers of Dinah, boldly entered the city with swords. And they put to death all of the males.
verses.textLa: Et ecce, die tertio quando gravissimus vulnerum dolor est: arreptis, duo filii Iacob, Simeon et Levi fratres Dinæ, gladiis, ingressi sunt urbem confidenter: interfectisque omnibus masculis,

verses.textEn: They killed Hamor and Shechem together, taking their sister Dinah from the house of Shechem.
verses.textLa: Hemor et Sichem pariter necaverunt, tollentes Dinam de domo Sichem sororem suam.

verses.textEn: And when they had departed, the other sons of Jacob rushed over the slain, and they plundered the city in vengeance for the rape.
verses.textLa: Quibus egressis, irruerunt super occisos ceteri filii Iacob: et depopulati sunt urbem in ultionem stupri.

verses.textEn: Taking their sheep, and herds, and donkeys, and laying waste to everything else that was in their houses and in their fields,
verses.textLa: Oves eorum, et armenta, et asinos, cunctaque vastantes quæ in domibus et in agris erant,

verses.textEn: they also took their little ones and their wives captive.
verses.textLa: parvulos quoque eorum et uxores duxerunt captivas.

verses.textEn: When they had boldly completed these acts, Jacob said to Simeon and Levi: “You have troubled me, and you have made me hateful to the Canaanites and the Perizzites, the inhabitants of this land. We are few. They, gathering themselves together, may strike me down, and then both I and my house will be wiped away.”
verses.textLa: Quibus patratis audacter, Iacob dixit ad Simeon et Levi: Turbastis me, et odiosum fecistis me Chananæis, et Pherezæis habitatoribus terræ huius. Nos pauci sumus: illi congregati percutient me, et delebor ego, et domus mea.

verses.textEn: They responded, “Should they abuse our sister like a prostitute?”
verses.textLa: Responderunt: Numquid ut scorto abuti debuere sorore nostra?

verses.textEn: About this time, God said to Jacob, “Arise and go up to Bethel, and live there, and make an altar to God, who appeared to you when you fled from your brother Esau.”
verses.textLa: Interea locutus est Deus ad Iacob: Surge, et ascende Bethel, et habita ibi, facque altare Deo qui apparuit tibi quando fugiebas Esau fratrem tuum.

verses.textEn: In truth, Jacob, having called together all his house, said: “Cast away the foreign gods that are in your midst and be cleansed, and also change your garments.
verses.textLa: Iacob vero convocata omni domo sua, ait: Abiicite deos alienos qui in medio vestri sunt, et mundamini, ac mutate vestimenta vestra.

verses.textEn: Arise, and let us go up to Bethel, so that we may make an altar there to God, who heeded me in the day of my tribulation, and who accompanied me on my journey.”
verses.textLa: Surgite, et ascendamus in Bethel, ut faciamus ibi altare Deo: qui exaudivit me in die tribulationis meæ, et socius fuit itineris mei.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they gave him all the foreign gods which they had, and the earrings which were in their ears. And then he buried them under the terebinth tree, which is beyond the city of Shechem.
verses.textLa: Dederunt ergo ei omnes deos alienos quos habebant, et inaures quæ erant in auribus eorum: at ille infodit ea subter terebinthum, quæ est post urbem Sichem.

verses.textEn: And when they had set out, the terror of God invaded all the surrounding cities, and they dared not pursue them as they withdrew.
verses.textLa: Cumque profecti essent, terror Dei invasit omnes per circuitum civitates, et non sunt ausi persequi recedentes.

verses.textEn: And so, Jacob arrived at Luz, which is in the land of Canaan, also named Bethel: he and all the people with him.
verses.textLa: Venit igitur Iacob Luzam, quæ est in terra Chanaan, cognomento Bethel: ipse et omnis populus cum eo.

verses.textEn: And he built an altar there, and he called the name of that place, ‘House of God.’ For there, God appeared to him when he fled from his brother.
verses.textLa: Ædificavitque ibi altare, et appellavit nomen loci illius, Domus Dei: ibi enim apparuit ei Deus cum fugeret fratrem suum.

verses.textEn: About the same time, Deborah, the nurse of Rebekah, died, and she was buried at the base of Bethel, under an oak tree. And the name of that place was called, ‘Oak of Weeping.’
verses.textLa: Eodem tempore mortua est Debora nutrix Rebeccæ, et sepulta est ad radices Bethel subter quercum: vocatumque est nomen loci illius, Quercus fletus.
verses.notes: Cities were generally built on high ground, so Deborah was buried on the outskirts of the city, at its roots or base.

verses.textEn: Then God appeared again to Jacob, after he returned from Mesopotamia of Syria, and he blessed him,
verses.textLa: Apparuit autem iterum Deus Iacob postquam reversus est de Mespotamia Syriæ, benedixitque ei,

verses.textEn: saying: “You will no longer be called Jacob, for your name shall be Israel.” And he called him Israel,
verses.textLa: dicens: Non vocaberis ultra Iacob, sed Israel erit nomen tuum. Et appellavit eum Israel,

verses.textEn: and he said to him: “I am Almighty God: increase and multiply. Tribes and peoples of nations will be from you, and kings will go forth from your loins.
verses.textLa: dixitque ei: Ego Deus omnipotens, cresce, et multiplicare: gentes, et populi nationum ex te erunt, reges de lumbis tuis egredientur.

verses.textEn: And the land that I gave to Abraham and Isaac, I will give to you, and to your offspring after you.”
verses.textLa: Terramque quam dedi Abraham et Isaac, dabo tibi et semini tuo post te.

verses.textEn: And he withdrew from him.
verses.textLa: Et recessit ab eo.

verses.textEn: In truth, he set up a monument of stone, in the place where God had spoken to him, pouring out libations over it, and pouring oil,
verses.textLa: Ille vero erexit titulum lapideum in loco quo locutus fuerat ei Deus: libans super eum libamina, et effundens oleum:

verses.textEn: and he called the name of that place, ‘Bethel.’
verses.textLa: vocansque nomen loci illius, Bethel.

verses.textEn: Then, departing from there, he arrived in springtime at the land that leads to Ephrath. And there, when Rachel was giving birth,
verses.textLa: Egressus autem inde, venit verno tempore ad terram quæ ducit Ephratam: in qua cum parturiret Rachel,

verses.textEn: because it was a difficult birth, she began to be in danger. And the midwife said to her, “Do not be afraid, for you will have this son also.”
verses.textLa: ob difficultatem partus periclitari cœpit. Dixitque ei obstetrix: Noli timere, quia et hunc habebis filium.

verses.textEn: Then, when her life was departing because of the pain, and death was now imminent, she called the name of her son Benoni, that is, the son of my pain. Yet truly, his father called him Benjamin, that is, the son of the right hand.
verses.textLa: Egrediente autem anima præ dolore, et imminente iam morte, vocavit nomen filii sui Benomi, id est, filius doloris mei: pater vero appellavit eum Beniamin, id est, filius dextræ.

verses.textEn: And so Rachel died, and she was buried in the way that leads to Ephrath: this place is Bethlehem.
verses.textLa: Mortua est ergo Rachel, et sepulta est in via quæ ducit Ephratam, hæc est Bethlehem.

verses.textEn: And Jacob erected a monument over her sepulcher. This is the monument to Rachel’s tomb, even to the present day.
verses.textLa: Erexitque Iacob titulum super sepulchrum eius: hic est titulus monumenti Rachel, usque in præsentem diem.

verses.textEn: Departing from there, he pitched his tent beyond the Tower of the Flock.
verses.textLa: Egressus inde, fixit tabernaculum trans Turrem Gregis.

verses.textEn: And when he was living in that region, Reuben went out, and he slept with Bilhah the concubine of his father, which was not such a small matter as to be hidden from him. Now the sons of Jacob were twelve.
verses.textLa: Cumque habitaret in illa regione, abiit Ruben, et dormivit cum Bala concubina patris sui: quod illum minime latuit. Erant autem filii Iacob duodecim.

verses.textEn: The sons of Leah: Reuben the first born, and Simeon, and Levi, and Judah, and Issachar, and Zebulun.
verses.textLa: Filii Liæ: primogenitus Ruben, et Simeon, et Levi, et Iudas, et Issachar, et Zabulon.

verses.textEn: The sons of Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.textLa: Filii Rachel: Ioseph et Beniamin.

verses.textEn: The sons of Bilhah, handmaid of Rachel: Dan and Naphtali.
verses.textLa: Filii Balæ ancillæ Rachelis: Dan et Nephthali.

verses.textEn: The sons of Zilpah, handmaid of Leah: Gad and Asher. These are the sons of Jacob, who were born to him in Mesopotamia of Syria.
verses.textLa: Filii Zelphæ ancillæ Liæ: Gad et Aser: hi sunt filii Iacob, qui nati sunt ei in Mesopotamia Syriæ.

verses.textEn: And then he went to his father Isaac in Mamre, the city of Arba: this place is Hebron, where Abraham and Isaac sojourned.
verses.textLa: Venit etiam ad Isaac patrem suum in Mambre, civitatem Arbee, hæc est Hebron: in qua peregrinatus est Abraham et Isaac.

verses.textEn: And the days of Isaac were completed: one hundred and eighty years.
verses.textLa: Et completi sunt dies Isaac centum octoginta annorum.

verses.textEn: And being consumed by old age, he died. And he was placed with his people, being old and full of days. And his sons, Esau and Jacob, buried him.
verses.textLa: Consumptusque ætate mortuus est: et appositus est populo suo senex et plenus dierum: et sepelierunt eum Esau et Iacob filii sui.

verses.textEn: Now these are the generations of Esau, who is Edom.
verses.textLa: Hæ sunt autem generationes Esau, ipse est Edom.

verses.textEn: Esau took wives from the daughters of Canaan: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon the Hivite,
verses.textLa: Esau accepit uxores de filiabus Chanaan: Ada filiam Elon Hethæi, et Oolibama filiam Anæ filiæ Sebeon Hevæi:

verses.textEn: and Basemath, the daughter of Ishmael, sister of Nebaioth.
verses.textLa: Basemath quoque filiam Ismael sororem Nabaioth.

verses.textEn: Then Adah bore Eliphaz. Basemath conceived Reuel.
verses.textLa: Peperit autem Ada, Eliphaz: Basemath genuit Rahuel:

verses.textEn: Oholibamah conceived Jeush, and Jalam, and Korah. These are the sons of Esau, who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
verses.textLa: Oolibama genuit Iehus et Ihelon et Core. Hi filii Esau qui nati sunt ei in terra Chanaan.

verses.textEn: Then Esau took his wives, and sons, and daughters, and every soul of his house, and his substance, and cattle, and whatever he was able to obtain in the land of Canaan, and he went into another region, withdrawing from his brother Jacob.
verses.textLa: Tulit autem Esau uxores suas et filios et filias, et omnem animam domus suæ, et substantiam, et pecora, et cuncta quæ habere poterat in terra Chanaan: et abiit in alteram regionem, recessitque a fratre suo Iacob.

verses.textEn: For they were very wealthy and were not able to live together. Neither was the land of their sojourn able to sustain them, because of the multitude of their flocks.
verses.textLa: Divites enim erant valde, et simul habitare non poterant: nec sustinebat eos terra peregrinationis eorum præ multitudine gregum.

verses.textEn: And Esau lived at mount Seir: he is Edom.
verses.textLa: Habitavitque Esau in monte Seir, ipse est Edom.

verses.textEn: So these are the generations of Esau, the father of Edom, at mount Seir,
verses.textLa: Hæ autem sunt generationes Esau patris Edom in monte Seir,

verses.textEn: and these are the names of his sons: Eliphaz the son of Adah, the wife of Esau, likewise Reuel, the son of Basemath, his wife.
verses.textLa: et hæc nomina filiorum eius: Eliphaz filius Ada uxoris Esau: Rahuel quoque filius Basemath uxoris eius.

verses.textEn: And Eliphaz had sons: Teman, Omar, Zepho, and Gatam, and Kenez.
verses.textLa: Fueruntque Eliphaz filii: Theman, Omar, Sepho, et Gatham, et Cenez.

verses.textEn: Now Timna was the concubine of Eliphaz, the son of Esau. And she bore him Amalek. These are the sons of Adah, the wife of Esau.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Thamna, concubina Eliphaz filii Esau: quæ peperit ei Amalech. Hi sunt filii Ada uxoris Esau.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Reuel were Nahath and Zerah, Shammah and Mizzah. These are the sons of Basemath, the wife of Esau.
verses.textLa: Filii autem Rahuel: Nahath et Zara, Samma et Meza. Hi filii Basemath uxoris Esau.

verses.textEn: Likewise, these were the sons of Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon, the wife of Esau, whom she bore to him: Jeush, and Jalam, and Korah.
verses.textLa: Isti quoque erant filii Oolibama filiæ Anæ filiæ Sebeon, uxoris Esau, quos genuit ei Iehus et Ihelon et Core.

verses.textEn: These were leaders of the sons of Esau, the sons of Eliphaz, the firstborn of Esau: leader Teman, leader Omar, leader Zepho, leader Kenez,
verses.textLa: Hi duces filiorum Esau: Filii Eliphaz primogeniti Esau: dux Theman, dux Omra, dux Sepho, dux Cenez,

verses.textEn: leader Korah, leader Gatam, leader Amalek. These are the sons of Eliphaz, in the land of Edom, and these the sons of Adah.
verses.textLa: dux Core, dux Gathan, dux Amalech. Hi filii Eliphaz in terra Edom, et hi filii Ada.

verses.textEn: Likewise, these are the sons of Reuel, the son of Esau: leader Nahath, leader Zerah, leader Shammah, leader Mizzah. And these were the leaders of Reuel, in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Basemath, the wife of Esau.
verses.textLa: Hi quoque filii Rahuel filii Esau: dux Nahath, dux Zara, dux Samma, dux Meza. Hi autem duces Rahuel in terra Edom: isti filii Basemath uxoris Esau.

verses.textEn: Now these are the sons of Oholibamah, the wife of Esau: leader Jeush, leader Jalam, leader Korah. These were the leaders of Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah and the wife of Esau.
verses.textLa: Hi autem filii Oolibama uxoris Esau: dux Iehus, dux Ihelon, dux Core. Hi duces Oolibama filiæ Anæ uxoris Esau.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of Esau, and these were their leaders: this is Edom.
verses.textLa: Isti sunt filii Esau, et hi duces eorum: ipse est Edom.
verses.notes: Edom was the name of a people, the Edomites. These sons of Esau were their leaders.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of Seir, the Horite, the inhabitants of the land: Lotan, and Shobal, and Zibeon, and Anah,
verses.textLa: Isti sunt filii Seir Horræi, habitatores terræ: Lotan, et Sobal, et Sebeon, et Ana,

verses.textEn: and Dishon, and Ezer, and Dishan. These were the leaders of the Horites, the sons of Seir, in the land of Edom.
verses.textLa: et Dison, et Eser, et Disan. Hi duces Horræi, filii Seir in Terra Edom.

verses.textEn: Now Lotan produced sons: Hori and Heman. But the sister of Lotan was Timna.
verses.textLa: Facti sunt autem filii Lotan: Hori et Heman. Erat autem soror Lotan, Thamna.

verses.textEn: And these are the sons of Shobal: Alvan, and Manahath, and Ebal, and Shepho, and Onam.
verses.textLa: Et isti filii Sobal: Alvan et Manahat et Ebal, et Sepho et Onam.

verses.textEn: And these are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah. This is the Anah who found the hot springs in the wilderness, when he was pasturing the donkeys of his father Zibeon.
verses.textLa: Et hi filii Sebeon: Aia et Ana. Iste est Ana qui invenit aquas calidas in solitudine, cum pasceret asinos Sebeon patris sui:

verses.textEn: And he had a son Dishon, and a daughter Oholibamah.
verses.textLa: habuitque filium Dison, et filiam Oolibama.

verses.textEn: And these are the sons of Dishon: Hemdan, and Esheban, and Ithran, and Cheran.
verses.textLa: Et isti filii Dison: Hamdan, et Eseban, et Iethram, et Charan.

verses.textEn: Likewise, these are the sons of Ezer: Bilhan, and Zaavan, and Akan.
verses.textLa: Hi quoque filii Eser: Balaan, et Zavan, et Acan.

verses.textEn: Then Dishan had sons: Uz and Aran.
verses.textLa: Habuit autem filios Disan: Hus, et Aram.

verses.textEn: These were the leaders of the Horites: leader Lotan, leader Shobal, leader Zibeon, leader Anah,
verses.textLa: Hi duces Horræorum: dux Lotan, dux Sobal, dux Sebeon, dux Ana,

verses.textEn: leader Dishon, leader Ezer, leader Disan. These were leaders of the Horites who ruled in the land of Seir.
verses.textLa: dux Dison, dux Eser, dux Disan: isti duces Horræorum qui imperaverunt in Terra Seir.

verses.textEn: Now before the sons of Israel had a king, the kings who ruled in the land of Edom were these:
verses.textLa: Reges autem qui regnaverunt in Terra Edom antequam haberent regem filii Israel, fuerunt hi:

verses.textEn: Bela the son of Beor, and the name of his city was Dinhabah.
verses.textLa: Bela filius Beor, nomenque urbis eius Denaba.

verses.textEn: Then Bela died, and Jobab, the son of Zerah from Bozrah, reigned in his place.
verses.textLa: Mortuus est autem Bela, et regnavit pro eo Iobab filius Zaræ de Bosra.

verses.textEn: And when Jobab was dead, Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his place.
verses.textLa: Cumque mortuus esset Iobab, regnavit pro eo Husam de terra Themanorum.

verses.textEn: Likewise, this one having died, Hadad the son of Bedad reigned in his place. He struck down Midian in the region of Moab. And the name of his city was Avith.
verses.textLa: Hoc quoque mortuo, regnavit pro eo Adad filius Badad, qui percussit Madian in regione Moab: et nomen urbis eius Avith.

verses.textEn: And when Adad was dead, Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his place.
verses.textLa: Cumque mortuus esset Adad, regnavit pro eo Semla de Masreca.

verses.textEn: Likewise, this one being dead, Shaul of the river Rehoboth, reigned in his place.
verses.textLa: Hoc quoque mortuo regnavit pro eo Saul de fluvio Rohoboth.

verses.textEn: And when he also had passed away, Baal-hanan, the son of Achbor, succeeded to the kingdom.
verses.textLa: Cumque et hic obiisset, successit in regnum Balanan filius Achobor.

verses.textEn: Likewise, this one being dead, Hadar reigned in his place; and the name of his city was Pau. And his wife was called Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, daughter of Mezahab.
verses.textLa: Isto quoque mortuo regnavit pro eo Adar, nomenque urbis eius Phau: et appellabatur uxor eius Meetabel, filia Matred filiæ Mezaab.

verses.textEn: Therefore, these were the names of the leaders of Esau, by their families, and places, and in their vocabulary: leader Timna, leader Alvah, leader Jetheth,
verses.textLa: Hæc ergo nomina ducum Esau in cognationibus, et locis, et vocabulis suis: dux Thamna, dux Alva, dux Ietheth,

verses.textEn: leader Oholibamah, leader Elah, leader Pinon,
verses.textLa: dux Oolibama, dux Ela, dux Phinon,
verses.notes: One of the leaders of the Edomites was a woman, Oholibamah.

verses.textEn: leader Kanez, leader Teman, leader Mibzar,
verses.textLa: dux Cenez, dux Theman, dux Mabsar,

verses.textEn: leader Magdiel, leader Iram. These were the leaders of Edom living in the land of their rule: this is Esau, the father of Idumea.
verses.textLa: dux Magdiel, dux Hiram: hi duces Edom habitantes in terra imperii sui, ipse est Esau pater Idumæorum.

verses.textEn: Now Jacob lived in the land of Canaan, where his father sojourned.
verses.textLa: Habitavit autem Iacob in terra Chanaan, in qua pater suus peregrinatus est.

verses.textEn: And these are his generations. Joseph, when he was sixteen years old, was pasturing the flock with his brothers, when he was still a boy. And he was with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, the wives of his father. And he accused his brothers to their father of a most sinful crime.
verses.textLa: Et hæ sunt generationes eius: Ioseph cum sedecim esset annorum, pascebat gregem cum fratribus suis adhuc puer: et erat cum filiis Balæ et Zelphæ uxorum patris sui: accusavitque fratres suos apud patrem crimine pessimo.

verses.textEn: Now Israel loved Joseph above all his sons, because he had conceived him in his old age. And he made him a tunic, woven of many colors.
verses.textLa: Israel autem diligebat Ioseph super omnes filios suos, eo quod in senectute genuisset eum: fecitque ei tunicam polymitam.

verses.textEn: Then his brothers, seeing that he was loved by his father more than all his other sons, hated him, and they were not able to say anything peacefully to him.
verses.textLa: Videntes autem fratres eius quod a patre plus cunctis filiis amaretur, oderant eum, nec poterant ei quidquam pacifice loqui.

verses.textEn: Then it also happened that he recounted the vision of a dream to his brothers, for which reason a greater hatred began to be nurtured.
verses.textLa: Accidit quoque ut visum somnium referret fratribus suis: quæ causa maioris odii seminarium fuit.

verses.textEn: And he said to them, “Listen to my dream that I saw.
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad eos: Audite somnium meum quod vidi:

verses.textEn: I thought we were binding sheaves in the field. And my sheaf seemed to rise up and stand, and your sheaves, standing in a circle, reverenced my sheaf.”
verses.textLa: Putabam nos ligare manipulos in agro: et quasi consurgere manipulum meum, et stare, vestrosque manipulos circumstantes adorare manipulum meum.

verses.textEn: His brothers responded: “Would you be our king? Or will we be subject to your dominion?” Therefore, this matter of his dreams and words provided kindling to their envy and hatred.
verses.textLa: Responderunt fratres eius: Numquid rex noster eris? aut subiiciemur ditioni tuæ? Hæc ergo causa somniorum atque sermonum, invidiæ et odii fomitem ministravit.

verses.textEn: Likewise, he saw another dream, which he explained to his brothers, saying, “I saw by a dream, as if the sun, and the moon, and eleven stars were reverencing me.”
verses.textLa: Aliud quoque vidit somnium, quod narrans fratribus, ait: Vidi per somnium, quasi solem, et lunam, et stellas undecim adorare me.
verses.notes: The word ‘adorare’ can be translated as ‘worship’ (adore) or ‘reverence’. Joseph did not think that he himself would be worshipped (this would be blasphemy). So the correct translation for the literal meaning is ‘reverence.’ However, the text has a spiritual meaning, that a descendent of Joseph, namely the Christ, would be worshipped, in which case the correct translation is ‘worship’ or ‘adore.’

verses.textEn: And when he had related this to his father and brothers, his father rebuked him, and he said: “What does it mean to you, this dream that you have seen? Should I, and your mother, and your brothers reverence you upon the earth?”
verses.textLa: Quod cum patri suo, et fratribus retulisset, increpavit eum pater suus, et dixit: Quid sibi vult hoc somnium quod vidisti? num ego et mater tua, et fratres tui adorabimus te super terram?

verses.textEn: Therefore, his brothers were envious of him. Yet truly, his father considered the matter silently.
verses.textLa: Invidebant ei igitur fratres sui: pater vero rem tacitus considerabat.

verses.textEn: And while his brothers were lodging at Shechem, pasturing their father’s flocks,
verses.textLa: Cumque fratres illius in pascendis gregibus patris morarentur in Sichem,

verses.textEn: Israel said to him: “Your brothers are pasturing the sheep at Shechem. Come, I will send you to them.” And when he answered,
verses.textLa: dixit ad eum Israel: Fratres tui pascunt oves in Sichimis: veni, mittam te ad eos. Quo respondente,

verses.textEn: “I am ready,” he said to him, “Go, and see if everything is prospering with your brothers and the cattle, and report to me what is happening.” So, having been sent from the valley of Hebron, he arrived at Shechem.
verses.textLa: Præsto sum, ait ei: Vade, et vide si cuncta prospera sint erga fratres tuos, et pecora: et renuncia mihi quid agatur. Missus de Valle Hebron, venit in Sichem:

verses.textEn: And a man found him wandering in a field, and he asked him what he was seeking.
verses.textLa: invenitque eum vir errantem in agro, et interrogavit quid quæreret.

verses.textEn: So he responded: “I seek my brothers. Tell me where they pasture the flocks.”
verses.textLa: At ille respondit: Fratres meos quæro, indica mihi ubi pascant greges.

verses.textEn: And the man said to him: “They have withdrawn from this place. But I heard them saying, ‘Let us go to Dothan.’ ” Therefore, Joseph continued on after his brothers, and he found them at Dothan.
verses.textLa: Dixitque ei vir: Recesserunt de loco isto: audivi autem eos dicentes: Eamus in Dothain. Perrexit ergo Ioseph post fratres suos, et invenit eos in Dothain.

verses.textEn: And, when they had seen him from afar, before he approached them, they decided to kill him.
verses.textLa: Qui cum vidissent eum procul, antequam accederet ad eos, cogitaverunt illum occidere:

verses.textEn: And they said one to another: “Behold, the dreamer approaches.
verses.textLa: et mutuo loquebantur: Ecce somniator venit:

verses.textEn: Come, let us kill him and cast him into the old cistern. And let us say: ‘an evil wild beast has devoured him.’ And then it will become apparent what his dreams will do for him.”
verses.textLa: venite, occidamus eum, et mittamus in cisternam veterem: dicemusque: Fera pessima devoravit eum: et tunc apparebit quid illi prosint somnia sua.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘cisternam veterem’ not only indicates that the well is old, but also that it is dry. In other words, it is old in the sense of outmoded or no longer useful.

verses.textEn: But Reuben, on hearing this, strove to free him from their hands, and he said:
verses.textLa: Audiens autem hoc Ruben, nitebatur liberare eum de manibus eorum, et dicebat:

verses.textEn: “Do not take away his life, nor shed blood. But throw him into this cistern, which is in the wilderness, and so keep your hands harmless.” But he said this, wanting to rescue him from their hands, so as to return him to his father.
verses.textLa: Non interficiatis animam eius, nec effundatis sanguinem: sed proiicite eum in cisternam hanc, quæ est in solitudine, manusque vestras servate innoxias: hoc autem dicebat, volens eripere eum de manibus eorum, et reddere patri suo.

verses.textEn: And so, as soon as he came to his brothers, they very quickly stripped him of his tunic, which was ankle-length and woven of many colors,
verses.textLa: Confestim igitur ut pervenit ad fratres suos, nudaverunt eum tunica talari, et polymita:

verses.textEn: and they cast him into an old cistern, which held no water.
verses.textLa: miseruntque eum in cisternam veterem, quæ non habebat aquam.

verses.textEn: And sitting down to eat bread, they saw some Ishmaelites, travelers coming from Gilead, with their camels, carrying spices, and resin, and oil of myrrh into Egypt.
verses.textLa: Et sedentes ut comederent panem, viderunt Ismaelitas viatores venire de Galaad, et camelos eorum portantes aromata, et resinam, et stacten in Ægyptum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Judah said to his brothers: “What will it profit us, if we kill our brother and conceal his blood?
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Iudas fratribus suis: Quid nobis prodest si occiderimus fratrem nostrum, et celaverimus sanguinem ipsius?

verses.textEn: It is better that he be sold to the Ishmaelites, and then our hands will not be defiled. For he is our brother and our flesh.” His brothers agreed to his words.
verses.textLa: Melius est ut venundetur Ismaelitis, et manus nostræ non polluantur: frater enim, et caro nostra est. Acquieverunt fratres sermonibus illius.
