verses.textEn: And when the Midianite merchants were passing by, they drew him from the cistern, and they sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. And these led him into Egypt.
verses.textLa: Et prætereuntibus Madianitis negotiatoribus, extrahentes eum de cisterna, vendiderunt eum Ismaelitis, viginti argenteis: qui duxerunt eum in Ægyptum.

verses.textEn: And Reuben, returning to the cistern, did not find the boy.
verses.textLa: Reversusque Ruben ad cisternam, non invenit puerum:

verses.textEn: And rending his garments, he went to his brothers and said, “The boy is not present, and so where shall I go?”
verses.textLa: et scissis vestibus pergens ad fratres suos, ait: Puer non comparet, et ego quo ibo?

verses.textEn: Then they took his tunic, and they dipped it in the blood of a young goat, which they had killed,
verses.textLa: Tulerunt autem tunicam eius, et in sanguine hœdi, quem occiderant, tinxerunt:

verses.textEn: sending those who carried it to their father, and they said: “We found this. See whether it is the tunic of your son or not.”
verses.textLa: mittentes qui ferrent ad patrem, et dicerent: Hanc invenimus: vide utrum tunica filii tui sit, an non.

verses.textEn: And when the father acknowledged it, he said: “It is the tunic of my son. An evil wild beast has eaten him; a beast has devoured Joseph.”
verses.textLa: Quam cum agnovisset pater, ait: Tunica filii mei est, fera pessima comedit eum, bestia devoravit Ioseph.

verses.textEn: And tearing his garments, he was clothed in haircloth, mourning his son for a long time.
verses.textLa: Scissisque vestibus, indutus est cilicio, lugens filium suum multo tempore.

verses.textEn: Then, when all of his sons gathered together to ease their father’s sorrow, he was not willing to accept consolation, but he said: “I will descend in mourning to my son in the underworld.” And while he persevered in weeping,
verses.textLa: Congregatis autem cunctis liberis eius ut lenirent dolorem patris, noluit consolationem accipere, sed ait: Descendam ad filium meum lugens in infernum. Et illo perseverante in fletu,

verses.textEn: the Midianites in Egypt sold Joseph to Potiphar, a eunuch of Pharaoh, instructor of the soldiers.
verses.textLa: Madianitæ vendiderunt Ioseph in Ægypto Putiphari eunucho Pharaonis magistro militum.
verses.notes: The word ‘magistro’ has more of the meaning of a teacher or instructor, than of a captain or magistrate. This eunuch was an instructor of the soldiers (probably of the new recruits), not an officer over the active duty soldiers.

verses.textEn: About the same time, Judah, descending from his brothers, turned toward an Adullamite man, named Hirah.
verses.textLa: Eodem tempore descendens Iudas a fratribus suis, divertit ad virum Odollamitem, nomine Hiram.

verses.textEn: And he saw there the daughter of a man called Shua, of Canaan. And taking her as a wife, he entered to her.
verses.textLa: Viditque ibi filiam hominis Chananæi, vocabulo Sue: et accepta uxore, ingressus est ad eam.

verses.textEn: And she conceived and bore a son, and she called his name Er.
verses.textLa: Quæ concepit, et peperit filium, et vocavit nomen eius Her.

verses.textEn: And conceiving offspring again, having given birth to a son, she called him Onan.
verses.textLa: Rursumque concepto fœtu, natum filium vocavit Onan.

verses.textEn: Likewise, she bore a third, whom she called Shelah, after whose birth, she ceased to bear any more.
verses.textLa: Tertium quoque peperit: quem appellavit Sela. Quo nato, parere ultra cessavit.

verses.textEn: Then Judah gave a wife to his first born Er, whose name was Tamar.
verses.textLa: Dedit autem Iudas uxorem primogenito suo Her, nomine Thamar.

verses.textEn: And it also happened that Er, the first born of Judah, was wicked in the sight of the Lord and was killed by him.
verses.textLa: Fuit quoque Her primogenitus Iudæ, nequam in conspectu Domini: et ab eo occisus est.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Judah said to his son Onan: “Enter to the wife of your brother, and associate with her, so that you may raise offspring to your brother.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Iudas ad Onan filium suum: Ingredere uxorem fratris tui, et sociare illi, ut suscites semen fratri tuo.

verses.textEn: He, knowing that the sons to be born would not be his, when he entered to the wife of his brother, he spilled his seed on the ground, lest children should be born in his brother’s name.
verses.textLa: Ille sciens non sibi nasci filios, introiens ad uxorem fratris sui, semen fundebat in terram, ne liberi fratris nomine nascerentur.

verses.textEn: And for this reason, the Lord struck him down, because he did a detestable thing.
verses.textLa: Et idcirco percussit eum Dominus, quod rem detestabilem faceret.

verses.textEn: Because of this matter, Judah said to his daughter-in-law Tamar, “Be a widow in your father’s house, until my son Shelah grows up.” For he was afraid, lest he also might die, just as his brothers did. She went away, and she lived in her father’s house.
verses.textLa: Quam ob rem dixit Iudas Thamar nurui suæ: Esto vidua in domo patris tui, donec crescat Sela filius meus: timebat enim ne et ipse moreretur, sicut fratres eius. Quæ abiit, et habitavit in domo patris sui.

verses.textEn: Then, after many days had passed, the daughter of Shua, the wife of Judah, died. And when he accepted consolation after his mourning, he went up to the shearers of his sheep at Timnah, he and Hirah, the herdsman of the Adullamite flock.
verses.textLa: Evolutis autem multis diebus, mortua est filia Sue uxor Iudæ: qui post luctum consolatione suscepta, ascendebat ad tonsores ovium suarum, ipse et Hiras opilio gregis Odollamites, in Thamnas.

verses.textEn: And it was reported to Tamar that her father-in-law had gone up to Timnah to shear the sheep.
verses.textLa: Nunciatumque est Thamar quod socer illius ascenderet in Thamnas ad tondendas oves.

verses.textEn: And storing away the garments of her widowhood, she took up a veil. And changing her clothing, she sat at the crossroad that leads to Timnah, because Shelah had grown up, and she had not received him as a husband.
verses.textLa: Quæ, depositis viduitatis vestibus, assumpsit theristrum: et mutato habitu, sedit in bivio itineris, quod ducit Thamnam: eo quod crevisset Sela, et non eum accepisset maritum.

verses.textEn: And when Judah saw her, he thought her to be a harlot. For she had covered her face, lest she be recognized.
verses.textLa: Quam cum vidisset Iudas, suspicatus est esse meretricem: operuerat enim vultum suum, ne agnosceretur.

verses.textEn: And entering to her, he said, “Permit me to join with you.” For he did not know her to be his daughter-in-law. And she responded, “What will you give to me, to enjoy me as a concubine?”
verses.textLa: Ingrediensque ad eam, ait: Dimitte me ut coeam tecum: nesciebat enim quod nurus sua esset. Qua respondente: Quid dabis mihi ut fruaris concubitu meo?

verses.textEn: He said, “I will send you a young goat from the flock.” And again, she said, “I will allow what you want, if you give me a pledge, until you may send what you promise.”
verses.textLa: dixit: Mittam tibi hœdam de gregibus. Rursumque illa dicente: Patiar quod vis, si dederis mihi arrhabonem, donec mittas quod polliceris.

verses.textEn: Judah said, “What do you want to be given for a pledge?” She responded, “Your ring and bracelet, and the staff that you hold in your hand.” Thereupon, the woman, from one sexual encounter, conceived.
verses.textLa: Ait Iudas: Quid tibi vis pro arrhabone dari? Respondit: Annulum tuum, et armillam, et baculum quem manu tenes. Ad unum igitur coitum mulier concepit,

verses.textEn: And she arose and went away. And storing away the garments that she had taken up, she was clothed in the garments of her widowhood.
verses.textLa: et surgens abiit: depositoque habitu, quem sumpserat, induta est viduitatis vestibus.

verses.textEn: Then Judah sent a young goat by his shepherd, the Adullamite, so that he might receive the pledge that he had given to the woman. But, when he had not found her,
verses.textLa: Misit autem Iudas hœdum per pastorem suum Odollamitem, ut reciperet pignus quod dederat mulieri: qui cum non invenisset eam,

verses.textEn: he questioned the men of that place: “Where is the woman who sat at the crossroad?” And they all responded, “There has been no harlot in this place.”
verses.textLa: interrogavit homines loci illius: Ubi est mulier quæ sedebat in bivio? Respondentibus cunctis: Non fuit in loco ista meretrix.

verses.textEn: He returned to Judah, and he said to him: “I did not find her. Moreover, the men of that place told me that a prostitute had never sat there.”
verses.textLa: Reversus est ad Iudam, et dixit ei: Non inveni eam: sed et homines loci illius dixerunt mihi, numquam sedisse ibi scortum.

verses.textEn: Judah said: “Let her hold herself to blame. Certainly, she is not able to accuse us of a lie. I sent the young goat that I had promised, and you did not find her.”
verses.textLa: Ait Iudas: Habeat sibi, certe mendacii arguere nos non potest, ego misi hœdum quem promiseram: et tu non invenisti eam.

verses.textEn: And behold, after three months, they reported to Judah, saying, “Tamar, your daughter-in-law, has committed fornication and her abdomen appears to be enlarged.” And Judah said, “Produce her, so that she may be burned.”
verses.textLa: Ecce autem post tres menses nunciaverunt Iudæ, dicentes: Fornicata est Thamar nurus tua, et videtur uterus illius intumescere. Dixitque Iudas: Producite eam ut comburatur.

verses.textEn: But when she was led out to the punishment, she sent to her father-in-law, saying: “I conceived by the man to whom these things belong. Recognize whose ring, and bracelet, and staff this is.”
verses.textLa: Quæ cum duceretur ad pœnam, misit ad socerum suum, dicens: De viro, cuius hæc sunt, concepi: cognosce cuius sit annulus, et armilla, et baculus.

verses.textEn: But he, acknowledging the gifts, said: “She is more just than I am. For I did not deliver her to my son Shelah.” However, he knew her no more.
verses.textLa: Qui, agnitis muneribus, ait: Iustior me est: quia non tradidi eam Sela filio meo. Attamen ultra non cognovit eam.

verses.textEn: Then, at the moment of birth, there appeared twins in the womb. And so, in the very delivery of the infants, one put forth a hand, on which the midwife tied a scarlet thread, saying,
verses.textLa: Instante autem partu, apparuerunt gemini in utero: atque in ipsa effusione infantium unus protulit manum, in qua obstetrix ligavit coccinum, dicens:

verses.textEn: “This one will go out first.”
verses.textLa: Iste egredietur prior.

verses.textEn: But in truth, drawing back his hand, the other came out. And the woman said, “Why is the partition divided for you?” And for this reason, she called his name Perez.
verses.textLa: Illo vero retrahente manum, egressus est alter: dixitque mulier: Quare divisa est propter te maceria? et ob hanc causam vocavit nomen eius Phares.

verses.textEn: After this, his brother came out, on whose hand was the scarlet thread. And she called him Zerah.
verses.textLa: Postea egressus est frater eius, in cuius manu erat coccinum: quem appellavit Zara.

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, Joseph was led into Egypt. And Putiphar, a eunuch of Pharaoh, a leader of the army, an Egyptian man, purchased him from the hand of the Ishmaelites, by whom he was brought.
verses.textLa: Igitur Ioseph ductus est in Ægyptum, emitque eum Putiphar eunuchus Pharaonis, princeps exercitus, vir Ægyptius, de manu Ismaelitarum, a quibus perductus erat.

verses.textEn: And the Lord was with him, and he was a man who prospered in everything that he did. And he lived in the house of his lord,
verses.textLa: Fuitque Dominus cum eo, et erat vir in cunctis prospere agens: habitavitque in domo domini sui,

verses.textEn: who knew very well that the Lord was with him, and that all the things that were done by him were directed by his hand.
verses.textLa: qui optime noverat Dominum esse cum eo, et omnia, quæ gerebat, ab eo dirigi in manu illius.

verses.textEn: And Joseph found favor in the sight of his lord, and he ministered to him. And, having been placed in charge of everything by him, he governed the house that was entrusted to him and all the things that had been delivered to him.
verses.textLa: Invenitque Ioseph gratiam coram domino suo, et ministrabat ei, a quo præpositus omnibus gubernabat creditam sibi domum, et universa quæ ei tradita fuerant:

verses.textEn: And the Lord blessed the house of the Egyptian, because of Joseph, and he multiplied all his substance, as much in the buildings, as in the fields.
verses.textLa: benedixitque Dominus domui Ægyptii propter Ioseph, et multiplicavit tam in ædibus quam in agris cunctam eius substantiam:

verses.textEn: Neither did he know anything other than the bread that he ate. Now Joseph was beautiful in form, and stately in appearance.
verses.textLa: nec quidquam aliud noverat, nisi panem quo vescebatur. Erat autem Ioseph pulchra facie, et decorus aspectu.
verses.notes: The master of the house knew nothing about what went on in his own house, except he knew that he ate meals there. He was ignorant of everything but the bread that he ate.

verses.textEn: And so, after many days, his mistress cast her eyes on Joseph, and she said, “Sleep with me.”
verses.textLa: Post multos itaque dies iniecit domina sua oculos suos in Ioseph, et ait: Dormi mecum.

verses.textEn: And without consenting at all to the wicked act, he said to her: “Behold, my lord has delivered all things to me, and he does not know what he has in his own house.
verses.textLa: Qui nequaquam acquiescens operi nefario, dixit ad eam: Ecce dominus meus, omnibus mihi traditis, ignorat quid habeat in domo sua:

verses.textEn: Neither is there anything which is not in my power, or that he has not delivered to me, except you, for you are his wife. How then can I do this evil act and sin against my God?”
verses.textLa: nec quidquam est quod non in mea sit potestate, vel non tradiderit mihi, præter te, quæ uxor eius es: Quo modo ergo possum hoc malum facere, et peccare in Deum meum?

verses.textEn: With such words as these, throughout each day, the woman was pestering the young man, and he was refusing the adultery.
verses.textLa: Huiuscemodi verbis per singulos dies et mulier molesta erat adolescenti: et ille recusabat stuprum.

verses.textEn: Then it happened, on a certain day, that Joseph entered the house, and he was doing something, without any witnesses.
verses.textLa: Accidit autem quadam die ut intraret Ioseph domum, et operis quippiam absque arbitris faceret:

verses.textEn: And she, grasping the hem of his garment, said, “Sleep with me.” But he, leaving behind the cloak in her hand, fled and went outside.
verses.textLa: et illa, apprehensa lacinia vestimenti eius, diceret: Dormi mecum. Qui relicto in manu eius pallio fugit, et egressus est foras.

verses.textEn: And when the woman saw the garment in her hands and herself being treated with disrespect,
verses.textLa: Cumque vidisset mulier vestem in manibus suis, et se esse contemptam,

verses.textEn: she called to herself the men of her house, and she said to them: “Lo, he has brought in a Hebrew man to abuse us. He entered toward me, in order to join with me; and when I had shouted out,
verses.textLa: vocavit ad se homines domus suæ, et ait ad eos: En introduxit virum Hebræum, ut illuderet nobis: ingressus est ad me, ut coiret mecum: cumque ego succlamassem,

verses.textEn: and he had heard my voice, he left behind the cloak that I held, and he fled outside.”
verses.textLa: et audisset vocem meam, reliquit pallium quod tenebam, et fugit foras.

verses.textEn: As a proof, therefore, of her fidelity, she retained the cloak, and she showed it to her husband, when he returned home.
verses.textLa: In argumentum ergo fidei retentum pallium ostendit marito revertenti domum,

verses.textEn: And she said: “The Hebrew servant, whom you have brought in to me, approached me to abuse me.
verses.textLa: et ait: Ingressus est ad me servus Hebræus quem adduxisti ut illuderet mihi:

verses.textEn: And when he had heard me cry out, he left behind the cloak that I held, and he fled outside.”
verses.textLa: cumque audisset me clamare, reliquit pallium quod tenebam, et fugit foras.

verses.textEn: His lord, upon hearing these things, and having excessive trust in the words of his mate, was very angry.
verses.textLa: His auditis dominus, et nimium credulus verbis coniugis, iratus est valde:

verses.textEn: And he delivered Joseph into prison, where the prisoners of the king were kept, and he was enclosed in that place.
verses.textLa: tradiditque Ioseph in carcerem, ubi vincti regis custodiebantur, et erat ibi clausus.

verses.textEn: But the Lord was with Joseph, and, having mercy on him, he gave him favor in the sight of the leader of the prison,
verses.textLa: Fuit autem Dominus cum Ioseph, et misertus illius dedit ei gratiam in conspectu principis carceris.

verses.textEn: who delivered into his hand all the prisoners who were held in custody. And whatever was done, was under him.
verses.textLa: Qui tradidit in manu illius universos vinctos qui in custodia tenebantur: et quidquid fiebat, sub ipso erat.

verses.textEn: Neither did he himself know anything, having entrusted all things to him. For the Lord was with him, and he directed everything that he did.
verses.textLa: Nec noverat aliquid, cunctis ei creditis: Dominus enim erat cum illo, et omnia opera eius dirigebat.

verses.textEn: While these things were going on, it happened that two eunuchs, the cupbearer of the king of Egypt, and the miller of grain, offended their lord.
verses.textLa: His ita gestis, accidit ut peccarent duo eunuchi, pincerna regis Ægypti, et pistor, domino suo.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh, being angry with them, (now the one was in charge of the cupbearers, the other of the millers of grain)
verses.textLa: Iratusque contra eos Pharao (nam alter pincernis præerat, alter pistoribus)

verses.textEn: sent them to the prison of the leader of the military, in which Joseph also was a prisoner.
verses.textLa: misit eos in carcerem principis militum, in quo erat vinctus et Ioseph.

verses.textEn: But the keeper of the prison delivered them to Joseph, who ministered to them also. Some little time passed by, while they were held in custody.
verses.textLa: At custos carceris tradidit eos Ioseph, qui et ministrabat eis: aliquantulum temporis fluxerat, et illi in custodia tenebantur.

verses.textEn: And they both saw a similar dream on one night, whose interpretations should be related to one another.
verses.textLa: Videruntque ambo somnium nocte una iuxta interpretationem congruam sibi:

verses.textEn: And when Joseph had entered to them in the morning, and had seen them sad,
verses.textLa: ad quos cum introisset Ioseph mane, et vidisset eos tristes,

verses.textEn: he consulted them, saying, “Why is your expression sadder today than usual?”
verses.textLa: sciscitatus est eos, dicens: Cur tristior est hodie solito facies vestra?

verses.textEn: They responded, “We have seen a dream, and there is no one to interpret it for us.” And Joseph said to them, “Doesn’t interpretation belong to God? Recount for me what you have seen.”
verses.textLa: Qui responderunt: Somnium vidimus, et non est qui interpretetur nobis. Dixitque ad eos Ioseph: Numquid non Dei est interpretatio? referte mihi quid videritis.

verses.textEn: The chief cupbearer explained his dream first. “I saw before me a vine,
verses.textLa: Narravit prior, præpositus pincernarum, somnium suum: Videbam coram me vitem,

verses.textEn: on which were three shoots, which grew little by little into buds, and, after the flowers, it matured into grapes.
verses.textLa: in qua erant tres propagines, crescere paulatim in gemmas, et post flores uvas maturescere:

verses.textEn: And the cup of Pharaoh was in my hand. Therefore, I took the grapes, and I pressed them into the cup that I held, and I handed the cup to Pharaoh.”
verses.textLa: calicemque Pharaonis in manu mea: tuli ergo uvas, et expressi in calicem quem tenebam, et tradidi poculum Pharaoni.

verses.textEn: Joseph responded: “This is the interpretation of the dream. The three shoots are the next three days,
verses.textLa: Respondit Ioseph: Hæc est interpretatio somnii: Tres propagines, tres adhuc dies sunt:

verses.textEn: after which Pharaoh will remember your service, and he will restore you to your former position. And you will give him the cup according to your office, as you were accustomed to do before.
verses.textLa: post quos recordabitur Pharao ministerii tui, et restituet te in gradum pristinum: dabisque ei calicem iuxta officium tuum, sicut ante facere consueveras.

verses.textEn: Only remember me, when it will be well with you, and do me this mercy, to suggest to Pharaoh to lead me out of this prison.
verses.textLa: Tantum memento mei, cum bene tibi fuerit, et facias mecum misericordiam: ut suggeras Pharaoni ut educat me de isto carcere:

verses.textEn: For I have been stolen from the land of the Hebrews, and here, innocently, I was cast into the pit.”
verses.textLa: quia furto sublatus sum de terra Hebræorum, et hic innocens in lacum missus sum.

verses.textEn: The chief miller of grain, seeing that he had wisely unraveled the dream, said: “I also saw a dream: that I had three baskets of meal above my head,
verses.textLa: Videns pistorum magister quod prudenter somnium dissolvisset, ait: Et ego vidi somnium: Quod tria canistra farinæ haberem super caput meum:

verses.textEn: and in one basket, which was the highest, I carried all foods that are made by the art of baking, and the birds ate from it.”
verses.textLa: et in uno canistro quod erat excelsius, portare me omnes cibos qui fiunt arte pistoria, avesque comedere ex eo.

verses.textEn: Joseph responded: “This is the interpretation of the dream. The three baskets are the next three days,
verses.textLa: Respondit Ioseph: Hæc est interpretatio somnii: Tria canistra, tres adhuc dies sunt:

verses.textEn: after which Pharaoh will carry away your head, and also suspend you from a cross, and the birds will tear your flesh.”
verses.textLa: post quos auferet Pharao caput tuum, ac suspendet te in cruce, et lacerabunt volucres carnes tuas.

verses.textEn: The third day thereafter was the birthday of Pharaoh. And making a great feast for his servants, he remembered, during the banquet, the chief cupbearer and the chief miller of grain.
verses.textLa: Exinde dies tertius natalitius Pharaonis erat: qui faciens grande convivium pueris suis, recordatus est inter epulas magistri pincernarum, et pistorum principis.

verses.textEn: And he restored the one to his place, to present him the cup;
verses.textLa: Restituitque alterum in locum suum, ut porrigeret ei poculum:

verses.textEn: the other he hanged on a gallows, and thus the truth of the interpreter of dreams was proven.
verses.textLa: alterum suspendit in patibulo, ut coniectoris veritas probaretur.

verses.textEn: And although he advanced with so much prosperity, the chief cupbearer forgot his interpreter of dreams.
verses.textLa: Et tamen succedentibus prosperis, præpositus pincernarum oblitus est interpretis sui.

verses.textEn: After two years, Pharaoh saw a dream. He thought himself to be standing above a river,
verses.textLa: Post duos annos vidit Pharao somnium. Putabat se stare super fluvium,

verses.textEn: from which ascended seven cows, exceedingly beautiful and stout. And they pastured in marshy places.
verses.textLa: de quo ascendebant septem boves, pulchræ et crassæ nimis: et pascebantur in locis palustribus.

verses.textEn: Likewise, another seven emerged from the river, filthy and thoroughly emaciated. And they pastured on the same bank of the river, in green places.
verses.textLa: Aliæ quoque septem emergebant de flumine, fœdæ, confectæque macie: et pascebantur in ipsa amnis ripa in locis virentibus:

verses.textEn: And they devoured those whose appearance and condition of body was so wonderful. Pharaoh, having been awakened,
verses.textLa: devoraveruntque eas, quarum mira species, et habitudo corporum erat. Expergefactus Pharao,

verses.textEn: slept again, and he saw another dream. Seven ears of grain sprung up on one stalk, full and well-formed.
verses.textLa: rursum dormivit, et vidit alterum somnium: Septem spicæ pullulabant in culmo uno plenæ atque formosæ:

verses.textEn: Likewise, other ears of grain, of the same number, rose up, thin and struck with blight,
verses.textLa: aliæ quoque totidem spicæ tenues, et percussæ uredine oriebantur,

verses.textEn: devouring all the beauty of the first. Pharaoh, when he awakened after his rest,
verses.textLa: devorantes omnium priorum pulchritudinem. Evigilans Pharao post quietem,

verses.textEn: and when morning arrived, being terrified with fear, sent to all the interpreters of Egypt and to all of the wise men. And when they were summoned, he explained to them his dream; but there was no one who could interpret it.
verses.textLa: et facto mane, pavore perterritus, misit ad omnes coniectores Ægypti, cunctosque sapientes: et accersitis narravit somnium, nec erat qui interpretaretur.

verses.textEn: Then at last the chief cupbearer, remembering, said, “I confess my sin.
verses.textLa: Tunc demum reminiscens pincernarum magister, ait: Confiteor peccatum meum:

verses.textEn: The king, being angry with his servants, ordered me and the chief miller of grain to be forced into the prison of the leader of the military.
verses.textLa: Iratus rex servis suis, me et magistrum pistorum retrudi iussit in carcerem principis militum:

verses.textEn: There, in one night, both of us saw a dream presaging the future.
verses.textLa: ubi una nocte uterque vidimus somnium præsagum futurorum.

verses.textEn: In that place, there was a Hebrew, a servant of the same commander of the military, to whom we explained our dreams.
verses.textLa: Erat ibi puer Hebræus, eiusdem ducis militum famulus: cui narrantes somnia,

verses.textEn: Whatever we heard was proven afterwards by the event of the matter. For I was restored to my office, and he was suspended on a cross.”
verses.textLa: audivimus quidquid postea rei probavit eventus. Ego enim redditus sum officio meo: et ille suspensus est in cruce.

verses.textEn: Immediately, by the king’s authority, Joseph was led out of prison, and they shaved him. And changing his apparel, they presented him to him.
verses.textLa: Protinus ad regis imperium eductum de carcere Ioseph totonderunt: ac veste mutata, obtulerunt ei.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, “I have seen dreams, and there is no one who can unfold them. I have heard that you are very wise at interpreting these.”
verses.textLa: Cui ille ait: Vidi somnia, nec est qui edisserat: quæ audivi te sapientissime coniicere.

verses.textEn: Joseph responded, “Apart from me, God will respond favorably to Pharaoh.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Ioseph: Absque me Deus respondebit prospera Pharaoni.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Pharaoh explained what he had seen: “I thought myself to be standing on the bank of a river,
verses.textLa: Narravit ergo Pharao quod viderat: Putabam me stare super ripam fluminis,

verses.textEn: and seven cows climbed up from the river, exceedingly beautiful and full of flesh. And they grazed in a pasture of a marshy greenery.
verses.textLa: et septem boves de amne conscendere, pulchras nimis, et obesis carnibus: quæ in pastu paludis virecta carpebant.

verses.textEn: And behold, there followed after these, another seven cows, with such deformity and emaciation as I had never seen in the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Et ecce, has sequebantur aliæ septem boves in tantum deformes et macilentæ, ut numquam tales in terra Ægypti viderim:

verses.textEn: These devoured and consumed the first,
verses.textLa: quæ, devoratis et consumptis prioribus,

verses.textEn: giving no indication of being full. But they remained in the same state of emaciation and squalor. Awakening, but being weighed down into sleep again,
verses.textLa: nullum saturitatis dedere vestigium: sed simili macie et squalore torpebant. Evigilans, rursus sopore depressus,

verses.textEn: I saw a dream. Seven ears of grain sprang up on one stalk, full and very beautiful.
verses.textLa: vidi somnium: Septem spicæ pullulabant in culmo uno plenæ atque pulcherrimæ.

verses.textEn: Likewise, another seven, thin and struck with blight, rose up from the stalk.
verses.textLa: Aliæ quoque septem tenues et percussæ uredine, oriebantur e stipula:

verses.textEn: And they devoured the beauty of the first. I explained this dream to the interpreters, and there is no one who can unfold it.”
verses.textLa: quæ priorum pulchritudinem devoraverunt. Narravi coniectoribus somnium, et nemo est qui edisserat.

verses.textEn: Joseph responded: “The dream of the king is one. What God will do, he has revealed to Pharaoh.
verses.textLa: Respondit Ioseph: Somnium regis unum est: quæ facturus est Deus, ostendit Pharaoni.

verses.textEn: The seven beautiful cows, and the seven full ears of grain, are seven years of abundance. And so the force of the dreams is understood to be the same.
verses.textLa: Septem boves pulchræ, et septem spicæ plenæ: septem ubertatis anni sunt: eamdemque vim somnii comprehendunt.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the seven thin and emaciated cows, which ascended after them, and the seven thin ears of grain, which were struck with the burning wind, are seven approaching years of famine.
verses.textLa: Septem quoque boves tenues atque macilentæ, quæ ascenderunt post eas, et septem spicæ tenues, et vento urente percussæ, septem anni venturæ sunt famis.

verses.textEn: These will be fulfilled in this order.
verses.textLa: Qui hoc ordine complebuntur:

verses.textEn: Behold, there will arrive seven years of great fertility throughout the entire land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Ecce septem anni venient fertilitatis magnæ in universa terra Ægypti:

verses.textEn: After this, there will follow another seven years, of such great barrenness that all the former abundance will be delivered into oblivion. For the famine will consume all the land,
verses.textLa: quos sequentur septem anni alii tantæ sterilitatis, ut oblivioni tradatur cuncta retro abundantia: consumptura est enim fames omnem terram,

verses.textEn: and the greatness of this destitution will cause the greatness of the abundance to be lost.
verses.textLa: et ubertatis magnitudinem perditura est inopiæ magnitudo.

verses.textEn: Now, as to what you saw the second time, it is a dream pertaining to the same thing. It is an indication of its firmness, because the word of God shall be done, and it shall be completed swiftly.
verses.textLa: Quod autem vidisti secundo ad eamdem rem pertinens somnium: firmitatis indicium est, eo quod fiat sermo Dei, et velocius impleatur.

verses.textEn: Now therefore, let the king provide a wise and industrious man, and place him over the land of Egypt,
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo provideat rex virum sapientem et industrium, et præficiat eum Terræ Ægypti:

verses.textEn: so that he may appoint overseers throughout all the regions. And let a fifth part of the fruits, throughout the seven fertile years
verses.textLa: Qui constituat præpositos per cunctas regiones: et quintam partem fructuum per septem annos fertilitatis,

verses.textEn: that now have already begun to occur, be gathered into storehouses. And let all the grain be stored away, under the power of Pharaoh, and let it be kept in the cities.
verses.textLa: qui iam nunc futuri sunt, congreget in horrea: et omne frumentum sub Pharaonis potestate condatur, serveturque in urbibus.

verses.textEn: And let it be prepared for the future famine of seven years, which will oppress Egypt, and then the land will not be consumed by destitution.”
verses.textLa: Et præparetur futuræ septem annorum fami, quæ oppressura est Ægyptum, et non consumetur terra inopia.

verses.textEn: The counsel pleased Pharaoh and all his ministers.
verses.textLa: Placuit Pharaoni consilium et cunctis ministris eius:

verses.textEn: And he said to them, “Would we be able to find another such man, who is full of the Spirit of God?”
verses.textLa: locutusque est ad eos: Num invenire poterimus talem virum, qui Spiritu Dei plenus sit?

verses.textEn: Therefore, he said to Joseph: “Because God has revealed to you all that you have said, would I be able to find anyone wiser and as much like you?
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo ad Ioseph: Quia ostendit tibi Deus omnia quæ locutus es, numquid sapientiorem et consimilem tui invenire potero?

verses.textEn: You will be over my house, and to the authority of your mouth, all the people will show obedience. Only in one way, in the throne of the kingdom, will I go before you.”
verses.textLa: Tu eris super domum meam, et ad tui oris imperium cunctus populus obediet: uno tantum regni solio te præcedam.

verses.textEn: And again, Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Behold, I have appointed you over the entire land of Egypt.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque rursus Pharao ad Ioseph: Ecce, constitui te super universam terram Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And he took the ring from his own hand, and he gave it into his hand. And he clothed him with a robe of fine linen, and he placed a necklace of gold around his neck.
verses.textLa: Tulitque annulum de manu sua, et dedit eum in manu eius: vestivitque eum stola byssina, et collo torquem auream circumposuit.

verses.textEn: And he caused him to ascend upon his second swift chariot, with the herald proclaiming that everyone should bend their knee before him, and that they should know that he was governor over the entire land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Fecitque eum ascendere super currum suum secundum, clamante præcone, ut omnes coram eo genu flecterent, et præpositum esse scirent universæ Terræ Ægypti.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the king said to Joseph: “I am Pharaoh: apart from your authority, no one will move hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.”
verses.textLa: Dixit quoque rex ad Ioseph: Ego sum Pharao: absque tuo imperio non movebit quisquam manum aut pedem in omni terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And he changed his name and called him, in the Egyptian tongue: ‘Savior of the world.’ And he gave him as a wife, Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, priest of Heliopolis. And so Joseph went out into the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Vertitque nomen eius, et vocavit eum lingua Ægyptiaca, Salvatorem mundi. Deditque illi uxorem Aseneth filiam Putiphare sacerdotis Heliopoleos. Egressus est itaque Ioseph ad terram Ægypti

verses.textEn: (Now he was thirty years old when he stood in the sight of king Pharaoh.) And he traveled throughout the regions of Egypt.
verses.textLa: (Triginta autem annorum erat quando stetit in conspectu regis Pharaonis) et circuivit omnes regiones Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And the fertility of the seven years arrived. And when the grain fields were reduced to sheaves, these were gathered into the storehouses of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Venitque fertilitas septem annorum: et in manipulos redactæ segetes congregatæ sunt in horrea Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And now all the abundance of grain was stored away in every city.
verses.textLa: Omnis etiam frugum abundantia in singulis urbibus condita est.

verses.textEn: And there was such a great abundance of wheat that it was comparable to the sands of the sea, and its bounty exceeded all measure.
verses.textLa: Tantaque fuit abundantia tritici, ut arenæ maris coæquaretur, et copia mensuram excederet.

verses.textEn: Then, before the famine arrived, Joseph had two sons born, whom Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, priest of Heliopolis, bore for him.
verses.textLa: Nati sunt autem Ioseph filii duo antequam veniret fames: quos peperit ei Aseneth filia Putiphare sacerdotis Heliopoleos.

verses.textEn: And he called the name of the firstborn Manasseh, saying, “God has caused me to forget all my labors and the house of my father.”
verses.textLa: Vocavitque nomen primogeniti, Manasses, dicens: Oblivisci me fecit Deus omnium laborum meorum, et domus patris mei.

verses.textEn: Likewise, he named the second Ephraim, saying, “God has caused me to increase in the land of my poverty.”
verses.textLa: Nomen quoque secundi appellavit Ephraim, dicens: Crescere me fecit Deus in terra paupertatis meæ.

verses.textEn: And so, when the seven years of fertility that occurred in Egypt had passed,
verses.textLa: Igitur transactis septem ubertatis annis, qui fuerant in Ægypto:

verses.textEn: the seven years of destitution, which Joseph had predicted, began to arrive. And the famine prevailed throughout the whole world, but there was bread in all the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: cœperunt venire septem anni inopiæ: quos prædixerat Ioseph: et in universo orbe fames prævaluit, in cuncta autem terra Ægypti panis erat.

verses.textEn: And being hungry, the people cried out to Pharaoh, asking for provisions. And he said to them: “Go to Joseph. And do whatever he will tell you.”
verses.textLa: Qua esuriente, clamavit populus ad Pharaonem, alimenta petens. Quibus ille respondit: Ite ad Ioseph: et quidquid ipse vobis dixerit, facite.

verses.textEn: Then the famine increased daily in all the land. And Joseph opened all of the storehouses and sold to the Egyptians. For the famine had oppressed them also.
verses.textLa: Crescebat autem quotidie fames in omni terra: aperuitque Ioseph universa horrea, et vendebat Ægyptiis: nam et illos oppresserat fames.

verses.textEn: And all the provinces came to Egypt, to buy food and to temper the misfortune of their destitution.
verses.textLa: Omnesque provinciæ veniebant in Ægyptum, ut emerent escas, et malum inopiæ temperarent.

verses.textEn: Then Jacob, hearing that food was being sold in Egypt, said to his sons: “Why are you negligent?
verses.textLa: Audiens autem Iacob quod alimenta venderentur in Ægypto, dixit filiis suis: Quare negligitis?

verses.textEn: I have heard that wheat is being sold in Egypt. Go down and buy necessities for us, so that we may be able to live, and not be consumed by destitution.”
verses.textLa: Audivi quod triticum venundetur in Ægypto: descendite, et emite nobis necessaria, ut possimus vivere, et non consumamur inopia.

verses.textEn: And so, when ten brothers of Joseph went down to buy grain in Egypt,
verses.textLa: Descendentes igitur fratres Ioseph decem, ut emerent frumenta in Ægypto,

verses.textEn: Benjamin was kept at home by Jacob, who said to his brothers, “Lest perhaps he may suffer harm on the journey.”
verses.textLa: Beniamin domi retento a Iacob, qui dixerat fratribus eius: Ne forte in itinere quidquam patiatur mali:

verses.textEn: And they entered into the land of Egypt with the others who traveled to buy. For the famine was in the land of Canaan.
verses.textLa: ingressi sunt terram Ægypti cum aliis qui pergebant ad emendum. Erat autem fames in terra Chanaan.

verses.textEn: And Joseph was governor in the land of Egypt, and grain was sold under his direction to the people. And when his brothers had reverenced him
verses.textLa: Et Ioseph erat princeps in terra Ægypti, atque ad eius nutum frumenta populis vendebantur. Cumque adorassent eum fratres sui,

verses.textEn: and he had recognized them, he spoke harshly, as if to foreigners, questioning them: “Where did you come from?” And they responded, “From the land of Canaan, to buy necessary provisions.”
verses.textLa: et agnovisset eos, quasi ad alienos durius loquebatur, interrogans eos: Unde venistis? Qui responderunt: De terra Chanaan, ut emamus victui necessaria.

verses.textEn: And although he knew his brothers, he was not known by them.
verses.textLa: Et tamen fratres ipse cognoscens, non est cognitus ab eis.

verses.textEn: And remembering the dreams, which he had seen in another time, he said to them: “You are scouts. You have come in order to see which parts of the land are weaker.”
verses.textLa: Recordatusque somniorum, quæ aliquando viderat, ait ad eos: Exploratores estis: ut videatis infirmiora terræ venistis.

verses.textEn: And they said: “It is not so, my lord. But your servants have arrived in order to buy food.
verses.textLa: Qui dixerunt: Non est ita, domine, sed servi tui venerunt ut emerent cibos.

verses.textEn: We are all sons of one man. We have come in peace, nor do any of your subjects devise evil.”
verses.textLa: Omnes filii unius viri sumus: pacifici venimus, nec quidquam famuli tui machinantur mali.

verses.textEn: And he answered them: “It is otherwise. You have come to examine the unguarded parts of this land.”
verses.textLa: Quibus ille respondit: Aliter est: immunita terræ huius considerare venistis.

verses.textEn: But they said: “We, your servants, are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan. The youngest is with our father; the other is not living.”
verses.textLa: At illi: Duodecim, inquiunt, servi tui, fratres sumus, filii viri unius in terra Chanaan: minimus cum patre nostro est, alius non est super.

verses.textEn: He said: “This is just as I have said. You are scouts.
verses.textLa: Hoc est, ait, quod locutus sum: Exploratores estis.

verses.textEn: I will now continue to put you to the test. By the health of Pharaoh, you will not depart from here, until your youngest brother arrives.
verses.textLa: Iam nunc experimentum vestri capiam: per salutem Pharaonis non egrediemini hinc, donec veniat frater vester minimus.

verses.textEn: Send one of you and bring him. But you will be in chains, until what you have said is proven to be either true or false. Otherwise, by the health of Pharaoh, you are scouts.”
verses.textLa: Mittite ex vobis unum, et adducat eum: vos autem eritis in vinculis, donec probentur quæ dixistis utrum vera an falsa sint: alioquin per salutem Pharaonis exploratores estis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he delivered them into custody for three days.
verses.textLa: Tradidit ergo illos custodiæ tribus diebus.

verses.textEn: Then, on the third day, he brought them out of prison, and he said: “Do as I have said, and you will live. For I fear God.
verses.textLa: Die autem tertio eductis de carcere, ait: Facite quæ dixi, et vivetis: Deum enim timeo.

verses.textEn: If you are peaceful, let one of your brothers be bound in prison. Then you may go away and carry the grain that you have bought to your houses.
verses.textLa: Si pacifici estis, frater vester unus ligetur in carcere: vos autem abite, et ferte frumenta quæ emistis, in domos vestras,

verses.textEn: And bring your youngest brother to me, so that I may be able to test your words, and you may not die.” They did as he had said,
verses.textLa: et fratrem vestrum minimum ad me adducite, ut possim vestros probare sermones, et non moriamini. Fecerunt ut dixerat,

verses.textEn: and they spoke to one another: “We deserve to suffer these things, because we have sinned against our brother, seeing the anguish of his soul, when he begged us and we would not listen. For that reason, this tribulation has come upon us.”
verses.textLa: et locuti sunt ad invicem: Merito hæc patimur, quia peccavimus in fratrem nostrum, videntes angustiam animæ illius, dum deprecaretur nos, et non audivimus: idcirco venit super nos ista tribulatio.

verses.textEn: And Reuben, one of them, said: “Did not I say to you, ‘Do not sin against the boy,’ and you would not listen to me? See, his blood is exacted.”
verses.textLa: E quibus unus Ruben, ait: Numquid non dixi vobis: Nolite peccare in puerum: et non audistis me? en sanguis eius exquiritur.

verses.textEn: But they did not know that Joseph understood, because he was speaking to them through an interpreter.
verses.textLa: Nesciebant autem quod intelligeret Ioseph: eo quod per interpretem loqueretur ad eos.

verses.textEn: And he turned himself away briefly and wept. And returning, he spoke to them.
verses.textLa: Avertitque se parumper, et flevit: et reversus locutus est ad eos.

verses.textEn: And taking Simeon, and binding him in their presence, he ordered his ministers to fill their sacks with wheat, and to replace each one’s money in their sacks, and to give them, in addition, provisions for the way. And they did so.
verses.textLa: Tollensque Simeon, et ligans illis præsentibus, iussit ministris ut implerent eorum saccos tritico, et reponerent pecunias singulorum in sacculis suis, datis supra cibariis in viam: qui fecerunt ita.

verses.textEn: Then, having loaded their donkeys with the grain, they set out.
verses.textLa: At illi portantes frumenta in asinis suis, profecti sunt.

verses.textEn: And one of them, opening a sack to give his beast of burden fodder at the inn, looked upon the money at the sack’s mouth,
verses.textLa: Apertoque unus sacco, ut daret iumento pabulum in diversorio, contemplatus pecuniam in ore sacculi,

verses.textEn: and he said to his brothers: “My money has returned to me. See, it is held in the sack.” And they were astonished and troubled, and they said to one another, “What is this that God has done to us?”
verses.textLa: dixit fratribus suis: Reddita est mihi pecunia, en habetur in sacco. Et obstupefacti, turbatique mutuo dixerunt: Quidnam est hoc quod fecit nobis Deus?

verses.textEn: And they went to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan, and they explained to him all the things that had befallen them, saying:
verses.textLa: Veneruntque ad Iacob patrem suum in terram Chanaan, et narraverunt ei omnia quæ accidissent sibi, dicentes:

verses.textEn: “The lord of the land spoke harshly to us, and he considered us to be scouts of the province.
verses.textLa: Locutus est nobis dominus terræ dure, et putavit nos exploratores esse provinciæ.

verses.textEn: And we answered him: ‘We are peaceful, and we do not intend any treachery.
verses.textLa: Cui respondimus: Pacifici sumus, nec ullas molimur insidias.

verses.textEn: We are twelve brothers conceived of one father. One is not living; the youngest is with our father in the land of Canaan.’
verses.textLa: Duodecim fratres uno patre geniti sumus: unus non est super, minimus cum patre nostro est in terra Chanaan.

verses.textEn: And he said to us: ‘Thus will I prove that you are peaceful. Release one of your brothers to me, and take necessary provisions for your houses, and go away,
verses.textLa: Qui ait nobis: Sic probabo quod pacifici sitis: Fratrem vestrum unum dimittite apud me, et cibaria domibus vestris necessaria sumite, et abite,

verses.textEn: and bring your youngest brother to me, so that I may know that you are not scouts. And this one, who is held in chains, you may be able to receive again. And thereafter, you shall have permission to buy what you want.’ ”
verses.textLa: fratremque vestrum minimum adducite ad me, ut sciam quod non sitis exploratores: et istum, qui tenetur in vinculis, recipere possitis: ac deinceps quæ vultis, emendi habeatis licentiam.

verses.textEn: Having said this, when they poured out their grain, each found his money tied to the mouth of his sack. And all were terrified together.
verses.textLa: His dictis, cum frumenta effunderent, singuli repererunt in ore saccorum ligatas pecunias, exterritisque simul omnibus,

verses.textEn: Their father Jacob said, “You have caused me to be without children. Joseph is not living, Simeon is held in chains, and Benjamin you would carry away. All these evils have fallen back upon me.”
verses.textLa: dixit pater Iacob: Absque liberis me esse fecistis, Ioseph non est super, Simeon tenetur in vinculis, et Beniamin auferetis: in me hæc omnia mala reciderunt.

verses.textEn: And Reuben answered him, “Put my two sons to death, if I do not lead him back to you. Deliver him into my hand, and I will restore him to you.”
verses.textLa: Cui respondit Ruben: Duos filios meos interfice, si non reduxero illum tibi: trade illum in manu mea, et ego eum tibi restituam.

verses.textEn: But he said: “My son will not go down with you. His brother is dead, and he is left alone. If any adversity will befall him in the land to which you travel, you would lead my grey hairs down with sorrow to the grave.”
verses.textLa: At ille: Non descendet, inquit, filius meus vobiscum: frater eius mortuus est, et ipse solus remansit: si quid ei adversi acciderit in terra ad quam pergitis, deducetis canos meos cum dolore ad inferos.
verses.notes: The word ‘inferos’ can refer to Hell, in some contexts. But it also can refer to the afterlife in general, particularly when one dies under adverse circumstances. Thus the translation here could be ‘grave’ or ‘underworld.’

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, the famine pressed heavily on all the land.
verses.textLa: Interim fames omnem terram vehementer premebat.

verses.textEn: And having consumed the provisions that they had brought out of Egypt, Jacob said to his sons, “Return and buy us a little food.”
verses.textLa: Consumptisque cibis quos ex Ægypto detulerant, dixit Iacob ad filios suos: Revertimini, et emite nobis pauxillum escarum.

verses.textEn: Judah answered: “The man himself declared to us, under the attestation of an oath, saying: ‘You will not see my face, unless you bring your youngest brother with you.’
verses.textLa: Respondit Iudas: Denuntiavit nobis vir ille sub attestatione iurisiurandi, dicens: Non videbitis faciem meam, nisi fratrem vestrum minimum adduxeritis vobiscum.

verses.textEn: If therefore you are willing to send him with us, we will travel together, and we will buy necessities for you.
verses.textLa: Si ergo vis eum mittere nobiscum, pergemus pariter, et ememus tibi necessaria:

verses.textEn: But if you are not willing, we will not go. For the man, as we have often said, declared to us, saying: ‘You will not see my face without your youngest brother.’ ”
verses.textLa: sin autem non vis, non ibimus: vir enim, ut sæpe diximus, denunciavit nobis, dicens: Non videbitis faciem meam absque fratre vestro minimo.

verses.textEn: Israel said to them, “You have done this for my misery, in that you revealed to him that you also had another brother.”
verses.textLa: Dixit eis Israel: In meam hoc fecistis miseriam, ut indicaretis ei et alium habere vos fratrem.

verses.textEn: But they responded: “The man questioned us in order, concerning our family: whether our father lived, if we had a brother. And we answered him respectively, according to what he demanded. How could we know that he would say, ‘Bring your brother with you?’ ”
verses.textLa: At illi responderunt: Interrogavit nos homo per ordinem nostram progeniem: si pater viveret: si haberemus fratrem: et nos respondimus ei consequenter iuxta id quod fuerat sciscitatus: numquid scire poteramus quod dicturus esset: Adducite fratrem vestrum vobiscum?

verses.textEn: Likewise, Judah said to his father: “Send the boy with me, so that we may set out and be able to live, lest we and our little ones should die.
verses.textLa: Iudas quoque dixit patri suo: Mitte puerum mecum, ut proficiscamur, et possimus vivere: ne moriamur nos et parvuli nostri.

verses.textEn: I accept the boy; require him at my hand. Unless I lead him back and restore him to you, I will be guilty of a sin against you for all time.
verses.textLa: Ego suscipio puerum: de manu mea require illum. Nisi reduxero, et reddidero eum tibi, ero peccati reus in te omni tempore.

verses.textEn: If a delay had not intervened, by now we would have returned here a second time.”
verses.textLa: Si non intercessisset dilatio, iam vice alter venissemus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, their father Israel said to them: “If it is necessary to do so, then do what you will. Take, in your vessels, from the best fruits of the land, and carry down gifts to the man: a little resin, and honey, and storax ointment, oil of myrrh, turpentine, and almonds.
verses.textLa: Igitur Israel pater eorum dixit ad eos: Si sic necesse est, facite quod vultis: sumite de optimis terræ fructibus in vasis vestris, et deferte viro munera, modicum resinæ, et mellis, et storacis, stactes, et terebinthi, et amygdalarum.
verses.notes: The Challoner revision lacks ‘their father’ in the first part of the verse. Again, here is an indication that Challoner was working from a slightly different edition than the Clementine Vulgate.

verses.textEn: Also, take with you double the money, and carry back what you found in your sacks, lest perhaps it was done in error.
verses.textLa: Pecuniam quoque duplicem ferte vobiscum: et illam, quam invenistis in sacculis, reportate, ne forte errore factum sit:

verses.textEn: But also take your brother, and go to the man.
verses.textLa: sed et fratrem vestrum tollite, et ite ad virum.

verses.textEn: Then may my Almighty God cause him to be pleased by you. And send your brother, whom he holds, back with you, along with this one, Benjamin. But as for me, without my children, I will be like one who is bereaved.”
verses.textLa: Deus autem meus omnipotens faciat vobis eum placabilem: et remittat vobiscum fratrem vestrum quem tenet, et hunc Beniamin: ego autem quasi orbatus absque liberis ero.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the men took the gifts, and double the money, and Benjamin. And they went down into Egypt, and they stood in the presence of Joseph.
verses.textLa: Tulerunt ergo viri munera, et pecuniam duplicem, et Beniamin: descenderuntque in Ægyptum, et steterunt coram Ioseph.

verses.textEn: And when he had seen them and Benjamin together, he instructed the steward of his house, saying: “Lead the men into the house, and kill victims, and prepare a feast, because they will be eating with me at midday.”
verses.textLa: Quos cum ille vidisset, et Beniamin simul, præcepit dispensatori domus suæ, dicens: Introduc viros domum, et occide victimas, et instrue convivium: quoniam mecum sunt comesturi meridie.

verses.textEn: He did what he had been ordered to do, and he brought the men into the house.
verses.textLa: Fecit ille quod sibi fuerat imperatum, et introduxit viros domum.

verses.textEn: And there, being terrified, they said one to another: “Because of the money, which we carried back the first time in our sacks, we have been brought in, so that he may unleash a false accusation against us, and by violence subjugate both us and our donkeys into servitude.”
verses.textLa: Ibique exterriti, dixerunt mutuo: Propter pecuniam, quam retulimus prius in saccis nostris, introducti sumus: ut devolvat in nos calumniam, et violenter subiiciat servituti et nos, et asinos nostros.

verses.textEn: For this reason, approaching the steward of the house at his door,
verses.textLa: Quam ob rem in ipsis foribus accedentes ad dispensatorem domus

verses.textEn: they said: “We beg you, lord, to hear us. We came down once before to buy food.
verses.textLa: locuti sunt: Oramus domine ut audias nos. Iam ante descendimus ut emeremus escas:

verses.textEn: And having bought it, when we arrived at the inn, we opened our sacks and found the money in the mouths of the sacks, which we now have carried back in the same amount.
verses.textLa: quibus emptis, cum venissemus ad diversorium, aperuimus saccos nostros, et invenimus pecuniam in ore saccorum: quam nunc eodem pondere reportavimus.

verses.textEn: But we have also brought other silver, so that we may buy those things that are necessary for us. It is not on our conscience who had placed it in our bags.”
verses.textLa: Sed et aliud attulimus argentum, ut emamus quæ nobis necessaria sunt: non est in nostra conscientia quis posuerit eam in marsupiis nostris.

verses.textEn: But he responded: “Peace be with you. Do not be afraid. Your God, and the God of your father, has given you the treasure in your sacks. As for the money that you gave to me, I held it as a test.” And he led Simeon out to them.
verses.textLa: At ille respondit: Pax vobiscum, nolite timere: Deus vester, et Deus patris vestri dedit vobis thesauros in saccis vestris. Nam pecuniam, quam dedistis mihi, probatam ego habeo. Eduxitque ad eos Simeon.

verses.textEn: And having led them into the house, he brought water, and they washed their feet, and he gave fodder to their donkeys.
verses.textLa: Et introductis domum, attulit aquam, et laverunt pedes suos, deditque pabulum asinis eorum.

verses.textEn: But they also prepared the gifts, until Joseph entered at midday. For they had heard that they would eat bread there.
verses.textLa: Illi vero parabant munera, donec ingrederetur Ioseph meridie: audierant enim quod ibi comesturi essent panem.

verses.textEn: And so Joseph entered his house, and they offered him the gifts, holding them in their hands. And they reverenced prone on the ground.
verses.textLa: Igitur ingressus est Ioseph domum suam, obtuleruntque ei munera, tenentes in manibus suis: et adoraverunt proni in terram.

verses.textEn: But he, gently greeting them again, questioned them, saying: “Is your father, the old man about whom you spoke to me, in good health? Is he still alive?”
verses.textLa: At ille, clementer resalutatis eis, interrogavit eos, dicens: Salvusne est pater vester senex, de quo dixeratis mihi? Adhuc vivit?

verses.textEn: And they answered: “Your servant, our father, is safe; he is still alive.” And bowing, they reverenced him.
verses.textLa: Qui responderunt: Sospes est servus tuus pater noster, adhuc vivit. Et incurvati, adoraverunt eum.

verses.textEn: Then Joseph, lifting up his eyes, saw Benjamin, his brother of the same womb, and he said, “Is this your little brother, about whom you spoke to me?” And again, he said, “May God be compassionate to you, my son.”
verses.textLa: Attollens autem Ioseph oculos, vidit Beniamin fratrem suum uterinum, et ait: Iste est frater vester parvulus, de quo dixeratis mihi? Et rursum: Deus, inquit, misereatur tui, fili mi.

verses.textEn: And he hurried out, because his heart had been moved over his brother, and tears gushed out. And going into his chamber, he wept.
verses.textLa: Festinavitque quia commota fuerant viscera eius super fratre suo, et erumpebant lacrymæ: et introiens cubiculum flevit.

verses.textEn: And when he had washed his face, coming out again, he composed himself, and he said, “Set out bread.”
verses.textLa: Rursumque lota facie egressus, continuit se, et ait: Ponite panes.

verses.textEn: And when it was set out, separately for Joseph, and separately for his brothers, likewise separately for the Egyptians, who ate at the same time, (for it is unlawful for Egyptians to eat with Hebrews, and they consider feasting in this way to be profane)
verses.textLa: Quibus appositis, seorsum Ioseph, et seorsum fratribus, Ægyptiis quoque qui vescebantur simul, seorsum (illicitum est enim Ægyptiis comedere cum Hebræis, et profanum putant huiuscemodi convivium)

verses.textEn: they sat before him, the firstborn according to his birthright, and the youngest according to his state of life. And they wondered exceedingly,
verses.textLa: sederunt coram eo, primogenitus iuxta primogenita sua, et minimus iuxta ætatem suam. Et mirabantur nimis,

verses.textEn: taking the portions that they received from him. And the greater portion went to Benjamin, so much so that it exceeded five parts. And they drank and became inebriated along with him.
verses.textLa: sumptis partibus quas ab eo acceperant: maiorque pars venit Beniamin, ita ut quinque partibus excederet. Biberuntque et inebriati sunt cum eo.

verses.textEn: Then Joseph instructed the steward of his house, saying: “Fill their sacks with grain, as much as they are able to hold. And place each one’s money at the top of the sack.
verses.textLa: Præcepit autem Ioseph dispensatori domus suæ, dicens: Imple saccos eorum frumento, quantum possunt capere: et pone pecuniam singulorum in summitate sacci.

verses.textEn: But place my silver bowl, and the price that he gave for the wheat, in the mouth of the sack of the youngest.” And so it was done.
verses.textLa: Scyphum autem meum argenteum, et pretium quod dedit tritici, pone in ore sacci iunioris. Factumque est ita.

verses.textEn: And when morning arose, they were sent away with their donkeys.
verses.textLa: Et orto mane, dimissi sunt cum asinis suis.

verses.textEn: And now they had departed from the city and had set out a short distance. Then Joseph, sending for the steward of his house, said: “Rise up and pursue the men. And when you have overtaken them, say: ‘Why have you returned evil for good?
verses.textLa: Iamque urbem exierant, et processerant paululum: tunc Ioseph accersito dispensatore domus, Surge, inquit, et persequere viros: et apprehensis dicito: Quare reddidistis malum pro bono?

verses.textEn: The cup that you have stolen, it is that from which my lord drinks, and in which he is accustomed to discern signs. You have done a very sinful thing.’ ”
verses.textLa: Scyphus, quem furati estis, ipse est in quo bibit dominus meus, et in quo augurari solet: pessimam rem fecistis.

verses.textEn: He did as he had been ordered. And having overtaken them, he spoke to them according to the order.
verses.textLa: Fecit ille ut iusserat. Et apprehensis per ordinem locutus est.

verses.textEn: And they responded: “Why does our lord speak in this way, as though your servants had committed such a shameful act?
verses.textLa: Qui responderunt: Quare sic loquitur dominus noster, ut servi tui tantum flagitii commiserint?

verses.textEn: The money, which we found at the top of our sacks, we carried back to you from the land of Canaan. So in what way does it follow that we would steal, from the house of your lord, gold or silver?
verses.textLa: Pecuniam, quam invenimus in summitate saccorum, reportavimus ad te de terra Chanaan: et quomodo consequens est ut furati simus de domo domini tui aurum vel argentum?

verses.textEn: Whichever of your servants will be found to have what you seek, may he die, and we shall be the servants of my lord.”
verses.textLa: Apud quemcumque fuerit inventum servorum tuorum quod quæris, moriatur, et nos erimus servi domini nostri.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Let it be according to your verdict. With whomever it will be found, let him be my servant, but you will be unharmed.”
verses.textLa: Qui dixit eis: Fiat iuxta vestram sententiam: apud quemcumque fuerit inventus, ipse sit servus meus, vos autem eritis innoxii.

verses.textEn: And so, they quickly placed their sacks down to the ground, and each one was opened.
verses.textLa: Itaque festinato deponentes in terram saccos, aperuerunt singuli.

verses.textEn: And when he had searched, beginning with the oldest, all the way to the youngest, he found the cup in Benjamin’s sack.
verses.textLa: Quos scrutatus, incipiens a maiore usque ad minimum, invenit scyphum in sacco Beniamin.

verses.textEn: But they, tearing their garments and burdening their donkeys again, returned to the town.
verses.textLa: At illi, scissis vestibus, oneratisque rursum asinis, reversi sunt in oppidum.

verses.textEn: And Judah, first among his brothers, entered to Joseph (for he had not yet departed from the place) and together they all fell down before him to the ground.
verses.textLa: Primusque Iudas cum fratribus ingressus est ad Ioseph (necdum enim de loco abierat) omnesque ante eum pariter in terram corruerunt.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Why would you choose to act in this way? Could you be ignorant that there is no one like me in the knowledge of discerning signs?”
verses.textLa: Quibus ille ait: Cur sic agere voluistis? an ignoratis quod non sit similis mei in augurandi scientia?

verses.textEn: And Judah said to him, “What could we answer to my lord? And what would we be able to say, or to justly claim? God has discovered the iniquity of your servants. See, we have all become servants to my lord, both we, and he with whom the cup was found.”
verses.textLa: Cui Iudas: Quid respondebimus, inquit, domino meo? vel quid loquemur aut iuste poterimus obtendere? Deus invenit iniquitatem servorum tuorum: en omnes servi sumus domini mei, et nos, et apud quem inventus est scyphus.

verses.textEn: Joseph responded: “Far be it from me that I should act in this way. He who stole the cup, he will be my servant. But you may go away free to your father.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Ioseph: Absit a me ut sic agam: qui furatus est scyphum, ipse sit servus meus: vos autem abite liberi ad patrem vestrum.

verses.textEn: Then Judah, approaching closer, said confidently: “I beg you, my lord, let your servant speak a word in your ears, and do not be angry with your servant. For you are next to Pharaoh.
verses.textLa: Accedens autem propius Iudas, confidenter ait: Oro domini mi, loquatur servus tuus verbum in auribus tuis, et ne irascaris famulo tuo: tu es enim post Pharaonem

verses.textEn: My lord, you questioned your servants before: ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’
verses.textLa: Interrogasti dominus meus prius servos tuos: Habetis patrem, aut fratrem?

verses.textEn: And we answered you, my lord: ‘There is our father, an old man, and a young boy, who was born in his old age. His brother of the same womb has died, and he alone is left to his mother and father, who truly love him tenderly.’
verses.textLa: et nos respondimus tibi domino meo: Est nobis pater senex, et puer parvulus, qui in senectute illius natus est; cuius uterinus frater mortuus est: et ipsum solum habet mater sua, pater vero tenere diliget eum.

verses.textEn: And you said to your servants, ‘Bring him to me, and I will set my eyes on him.’
verses.textLa: Dixistique servis tuis: Adducite eum ad me, et ponam oculos meos super illum.

verses.textEn: We suggested to my lord: ‘The boy is not able to leave his father. For if he sends him away, he will die.’
verses.textLa: Suggessimus domino meo: Non potest puer relinquere patrem suum: si enim illum dimiserit, morietur.

verses.textEn: And you said to your servants: ‘Unless your youngest brother arrives with you, you will not see my face any more.’
verses.textLa: Et dixisti servis tuis: Nisi venerit frater vester minimus vobiscum, non videbitis amplius faciem meam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when we had gone up to your servant our father, we explained to him all that my lord had spoken.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo ascendissemus ad famulum tuum patrem nostrum, narravimus ei omnia quæ locutus est dominus meus.

verses.textEn: And our father said: ‘Return and buy us a little wheat.’
verses.textLa: Et dixit pater noster: Revertimini, et emite nobis parum tritici.

verses.textEn: And we said to him: ‘We cannot go. If our youngest brother descends with us, we will set out together. Otherwise, in his absence, we do not dare to see the face of the man.’
verses.textLa: Cui diximus: Ire non possumus: si frater noster minimus descenderit nobiscum, proficiscemur simul: alioquin illo absente, non audemus videre faciem viri.

verses.textEn: To which he responded: ‘You know that my wife conceived twice by me.
verses.textLa: Ad quæ ille respondit: Vos scitis quod duos genuerit mihi uxor mea.

verses.textEn: One went out, and you said, “A beast devoured him.” And since then, he has not appeared.
verses.textLa: Egressus est unus, et dixistis: Bestia devoravit eum: et hucusque non comparet.

verses.textEn: If you take this one also, and anything happens to him on the way, you will lead my grey hairs down with grief to the grave.’
verses.textLa: Si tuleritis et istum, et aliquid ei in via contigerit, deducetis canos meos cum mœrore ad inferos.

verses.textEn: Therefore, if I would have gone to your servant, our father, with the boy not present, (though his life depends upon the life of him)
verses.textLa: Igitur si intravero ad servum tuum patrem nostrum, et puer defuerit, (cum anima illius ex huius anima pendeat)

verses.textEn: and if he were to see that he is not with us, he would die, and your servants will lead his grey hairs down with sorrow to the grave.
verses.textLa: videritque eum non esse nobiscum, morietur, et deducent famuli tui canos eius cum dolore ad inferos.

verses.textEn: Let me be your very own servant, for I accepted this one into my trust, and I promised, saying: ‘Unless I lead him back, I will be guilty of a sin against my father for all time.’
verses.textLa: Ego proprie servus tuus sim qui in meam hunc recepi fidem, et spopondi dicens: Nisi reduxero eum, peccati reus ero in patrem meum omni tempore.

verses.textEn: And so I, your servant, will remain in place of the boy, in ministry to my lord, and then let the boy go up with his brothers.
verses.textLa: Manebo itaque servus tuus pro puero in ministerio domini mei, et puer ascendat cum fratribus suis.

verses.textEn: For I cannot return to my father without the boy, lest I appear as a witness to the calamity that will oppress my father.”
verses.textLa: Non enim possum redire ad patrem meum, absente puero: ne calamitatis, quæ oppressura est patrem meum, testis assistam.

verses.textEn: Joseph was unable to restrain himself any longer, standing before so many. Therefore, he instructed that all should go outside, and that no stranger should be among them as they recognized one another.
verses.textLa: Non se poterat ultra cohibere Ioseph multis coram astantibus: unde præcepit ut egrederentur cuncti foras, et nullus interesset alienus agnitioni mutuæ.

verses.textEn: And he lifted up his voice with weeping, which the Egyptians heard, along with the entire house of Pharaoh.
verses.textLa: Elevavitque vocem cum fletu: quam audierunt Ægyptii, omnisque domus Pharaonis.

verses.textEn: And he said to his brothers: “I am Joseph. Is my father still alive?” His brothers were unable to respond, being terrified by a very great fear.
verses.textLa: Et dixit fratribus suis: Ego sum Ioseph: adhuc pater meus vivit? Non poterant respondere fratres nimio terrore perterriti.

verses.textEn: And he said to them mildly, “Approach toward me.” And when they had approached close by, he said: “I am Joseph, your brother, whom you sold into Egypt.
verses.textLa: Ad quos ille clementer: Accedite, inquit, ad me. Et cum accessissent prope, Ego sum, ait, Ioseph, frater vester, quem vendidistis in Ægyptum.

verses.textEn: Do not be afraid, and let it not seem to you to be a hardship that you sold me into these regions. For God sent me before you into Egypt for your salvation.
verses.textLa: Nolite pavere, neque vobis durum esse videatur quod vendidistis me in his regionibus: pro salute enim vestra misit me Deus ante vos in Ægyptum.

verses.textEn: For it is two years since the famine began to be upon the land, and five years more remain, in which there can be neither plowing, nor reaping.
verses.textLa: Biennium est enim quod cœpit fames esse in terra: et adhuc quinque anni restant, quibus nec arari poterit nec meti.

verses.textEn: And God sent me ahead, so that you may be preserved upon the earth, and so that you would be able to have food in order to live.
verses.textLa: Præmisitque me Deus ut reservemini super terram, et escas ad vivendum habere possitis.

verses.textEn: I was sent here, not by your counsel, but by the will of God. He has caused me to be like a father to Pharaoh, and to be the lord of his entire house, as well as governor throughout all the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Non vestro consilio, sed Dei voluntate huc missum sum: qui fecit me quasi patrem Pharaonis, et dominum universæ domus eius, ac principem in omni terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: Hurry, and go up to my father, and say to him: ‘Your son Joseph commands this: God has caused me to be lord of the entire land of Egypt. Come down to me, do not delay,
verses.textLa: Festinate, et ascendite ad patrem meum, et dicetis ei: Hæc mandat filius tuus Ioseph: Deus fecit me dominum universæ terræ Ægypti: descende ad me, ne moreris,

verses.textEn: and you will live in the land of Goshen. And you will be next to me, you and your sons and the sons of your sons, your sheep and your herds, and all that you possess.
verses.textLa: et habitabis in terra Gessen: erisque iuxta me tu, et filii tui, et filii filiorum tuorum, oves tuæ, et armenta tua, et universa quæ possides.

verses.textEn: And there I will pasture you, (for there are still five years of famine remaining) lest both you and your house perish, along with all that you possess.’
verses.textLa: Ibique te pascam (adhuc enim quinque anni residui sunt famis) ne et tu pereas, et domus tua, et omnia quæ possides.

verses.textEn: Behold, your eyes and the eyes of my brother Benjamin can see that it is my mouth speaking to you.
verses.textLa: En oculi vestri, et oculi fratris mei Beniamin vident quod os meum loquatur ad vos.

verses.textEn: You will report to my father about all my glory, and about all that you have seen in Egypt. Hurry, and bring him to me.”
verses.textLa: Nunciate patri meo universam gloriam meam, et cuncta quæ vidistis in Ægypto: festinate, et adducite eum ad me.

verses.textEn: And then falling upon the neck of his brother Benjamin, he embraced him and wept. And likewise, Benjamin wept at the same time on his neck.
verses.textLa: Cumque amplexatus recidisset in collum Beniamin fratris sui, flevit: illo quoque similiter flente super collum eius.

verses.textEn: And Joseph kissed all his brothers, and he cried over each one. After this, they were emboldened to speak to him.
verses.textLa: Osculatusque est Ioseph omnes fratres suos, et ploravit super singulos: post quæ ausi sunt loqui ad eum.

verses.textEn: And it was overheard, and the news spread by word throughout the king’s court. The brothers of Joseph had arrived, and Pharaoh was gladdened along with all his family.
verses.textLa: Auditumque est, et celebri sermone vulgatum in aula regis: Venerunt fratres Ioseph: et gavisus est Pharao, atque omnis familia eius.

verses.textEn: And he told Joseph that he should command his brothers, saying: “ ‘Burden your beasts, and go into the land of Canaan,
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad Ioseph ut imperaret fratribus suis, dicens: Onerantes iumenta, ite in terram Chanaan,

verses.textEn: and take from there your father and kindred, and come to me. And I will give you all the good things of Egypt, so that you may eat from the marrow of the land.’ ”
verses.textLa: et tollite inde patrem vestrum et cognationem, et venite ad me: et ego dabo vobis omnia bona Ægypti, ut comedatis medullam terræ.

verses.textEn: “And you may even instruct that they take wagons from the land of Egypt, in order to transport their little ones as well as their wives. And say: ‘Take your father, and come quickly, as soon as possible.
verses.textLa: Præcipe etiam ut tollant plaustra de terra Ægypti, ad subvectionem parvulorum suorum ac coniugum: et dicito: Tollite patrem vestrum, et properate quantocius venientes.

verses.textEn: You need not give up anything from your household, for all the riches of Egypt will be yours.’ ”
verses.textLa: Nec dimittatis quidquam de supellectili vestra: quia omnes opes Ægypti, vestræ erunt.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel did just as they were commanded. And Joseph gave them wagons, according to the command of Pharaoh, and provisions for the journey.
verses.textLa: Feceruntque filii Israel ut eis mandatum fuerat. Quibus dedit Ioseph plaustra, secundum Pharaonis imperium: et cibaria in itinere.

verses.textEn: Likewise, he ordered two robes for each of them to be brought. Yet truly, to Benjamin he gave three hundred pieces of silver along with five of the best robes.
verses.textLa: Singulis quoque proferri iussit binas stolas: Beniamin vero dedit trecentos argenteos cum quinque stolis optimis:

verses.textEn: And he sent just as much money and clothing to his father, adding also ten male donkeys, with which to transport all the riches of Egypt, and as many female donkeys, carrying wheat and bread for the journey.
verses.textLa: tantumdem pecuniæ et vestium mittens patri suo, addens et asinos decem, qui subveherent ex omnibus divitiis Ægypti: et totidem asinas, triticum in itinere, panesque portantes.

verses.textEn: Thus he sent away his brothers, and as they set out he said, “Do not become angry on the way.”
verses.textLa: Dimisit ergo fratres suos, et proficiscentibus ait: Ne irascamini in via.

verses.textEn: And they ascended out of Egypt, and they arrived in the land of Canaan, to their father Jacob.
verses.textLa: Qui ascendentes ex Ægypto, venerunt in terram Chanaan ad patrem suum Iacob.

verses.textEn: And they reported to him, saying: “Your son Joseph is alive, and he is ruler throughout all the land of Egypt. When Jacob heard this, he was stirred up, as if from a deep sleep, yet he did not believe them.
verses.textLa: Et nunciaverunt ei, dicentes: Ioseph filius tuus vivit: et ipse dominatur in omni terra Ægypti. Quo audito Iacob, quasi de gravi somno evigilans, tamen non credebat eis.

verses.textEn: To the contrary, they explained the entire matter in order. And when he had seen the wagons, and all that he had sent, his spirit revived,
verses.textLa: Illi e contra referebant omnem ordinem rei. Cumque vidisset plaustra, et universa quæ miserat, revixit spiritus eius,

verses.textEn: and he said: “It is enough for me, if my son Joseph is still alive. I will go and see him before I die.”
verses.textLa: et ait: Sufficit mihi si adhuc Ioseph filius meus vivit: vadam, et videbo illum antequam moriar.

verses.textEn: And Israel, setting out with all that he had, arrived at the Well of the Oath. And sacrificing victims there to the God of his father Isaac,
verses.textLa: Profectusque Israel cum omnibus quæ habebat, venit ad Puteum iuramenti. Et mactatis ibi victimis Deo patris sui Isaac,

verses.textEn: he heard him, by a vision in the night, calling him, and saying to him: “Jacob, Jacob.” And he answered him, “Behold, here I am.”
verses.textLa: audivit eum per visionem noctis vocantem se, et dicentem sibi: Iacob, Iacob. Cui respondit: Ecce adsum.

verses.textEn: God said to him: “I am the most strong God of your father. Do not be afraid. Descend into Egypt, for there I will make of you a great nation.
verses.textLa: Ait illi Deus: Ego sum fortissimus Deus patris tui: noli timere, descende in Ægyptum, quia in gentem magnam faciam te ibi.

verses.textEn: I will descend with you to that place, and I will lead you back from there, returning. Also, Joseph will place his hands over your eyes.
verses.textLa: Ego descendam tecum illuc, et ego inde adducam te revertentem: Ioseph quoque ponet manus suas super oculos tuos.
verses.notes: The participle ‘revertentem’ (returning) seems redundant, but there may be an additional level of meaning to which this refers, so it is translated fairly literally and left in.

verses.textEn: Then Jacob rose up from the Well of the Oath. And his sons took him, with their little ones and wives, in the wagons that Pharaoh had sent to carry the old man,
verses.textLa: Surrexit autem Iacob a Puteo iuramenti: tuleruntque eum filii cum parvulis et uxoribus suis in plaustris quæ miserat Pharao ad portandum senem,

verses.textEn: along with all that he possessed in the land of Canaan. And he arrived in Egypt with all his offspring:
verses.textLa: et omnia quæ possederat in Terra Chanaan: venitque in Ægyptum cum omni semine suo,

verses.textEn: his sons and his grandsons, his daughters and all his progeny together.
verses.textLa: filii eius, et nepotes, filiæ, et cuncta simul progenies.

verses.textEn: Now these are the names of the sons of Israel, who entered into Egypt, he with his children. The firstborn is Reuben.
verses.textLa: Hæc sunt autem nomina filiorum Israel, qui ingressi sunt in Ægyptum, ipse cum liberis suis. Primogenitus Ruben.

verses.textEn: The sons of Reuben: Hanoch and Pallu, and Hezron and Carmi.
verses.textLa: Filii Ruben: Henoch et Phallu et Hesron et Charmi.

verses.textEn: The sons of Simeon: Jemuel and Jamin and Ohad, and Jachin and Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman.
verses.textLa: Filii Simeon: Iamuel et Iamin et Ahod, et Iachin et Sohar, et Saul filius Chanaanitidis.

verses.textEn: The sons of Levi: Gershon and Kohath, and Merari.
verses.textLa: Filii Levi: Gerson et Caath et Merari.
