verses.textEn: The sons of Judah: Er and Onan, and Shelah, and Perez and Zerah. Now Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan. And sons were born to Perez: Hezron and Hamul.
verses.textLa: Filii Iuda: Her et Onan et Sela et Phares et Zara. Mortui sunt autem Her et Onan in terra Chanaan. Natique sunt filii Phares: Hesron et Hamul.

verses.textEn: The sons of Issachar: Tola and Puvah, and Job and Shimron.
verses.textLa: Filii Issachar: Thola et Phua et Iob et Semron.

verses.textEn: The sons of Zebulun: Sered and Elon and Jahleel.
verses.textLa: Filii Zabulon: Sared et Elon et Iahelel.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of Leah, whom she bore, along with his daughter Dinah, in Mesopotamia of Syria. All the souls of her sons and daughters are thirty-three.
verses.textLa: Hi filii Liæ quos genuit in Mesopotamia Syriæ cum Dina filia sua. Omnes animæ filiorum eius et filiarum, triginta tres.

verses.textEn: The sons of Gad: Ziphion and Haggi, and Shuni and Ezbon, and Eri and Arodi, and Areli.
verses.textLa: Filii Gad: Sephion et Haggi et Suni et Esebon et Heri et Arodi et Areli.

verses.textEn: The sons of Asher: Imnah and Jesua, and Jessui and Beriah, and also their sister Sarah. The sons of Beria: Heber and Malchiel.
verses.textLa: Filii Aser: Iamne et Iesua et Iessui et Beria, Sara quoque soror eorum. Filii Beria: Heber et Melchiel.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah. And these she bore to Jacob: sixteen souls.
verses.textLa: Hi filii Zelphæ, quam dedit Laban Liæ filiæ suæ. Et hos genuit Iacob sedecim animas.

verses.textEn: The sons of Rachel, the wife of Jacob: Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.textLa: Filii Rachel uxoris Iacob: Ioseph et Beniamin.

verses.textEn: And sons were born to Joseph in the land of Egypt, whom Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, priest of Heliopolis, bore for him: Manasseh and Ephraim.
verses.textLa: Natique sunt Ioseph filii in Terra Ægypti, quos genuit ei Aseneth filia Putiphare sacerdotis Heliopoleos: Manasses et Ephraim.

verses.textEn: The sons of Benjamin: Bela and Becher, and Ashbel and Gera, and Naaman and Ehi, and Rosh and Moppim, and Huppim and Ard.
verses.textLa: Filii Beniamin: Bela et Bechor et Asbel et Gera et Naaman et Echi et Ros et Mophim et Ophim et Ared.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of Rachel, whom she bore to Jacob: all these souls are fourteen.
verses.textLa: Hi filii Rachel quos genuit Iacob: omnes animæ, quatuordecim.

verses.textEn: The sons of Dan: Hushim.
verses.textLa: Filii Dan: Husim.

verses.textEn: The sons of Naphtali: Jahzeel and Guni, and Jezer and Shillem.
verses.textLa: Filii Nephthali: Iasiel et Guni et Ieser et Sallem.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Rachel, and these she bore to Jacob: all these souls are seven.
verses.textLa: Hi filii Balæ, quam dedit Laban Racheli filiæ suæ: et hos genuit Iacob: omnes animæ, septem.

verses.textEn: All the souls who went into Egypt with Jacob and who went out from his thigh, besides the wives of his sons, were sixty-six.
verses.textLa: Cunctæ animæ, quæ ingressæ sunt cum Iacob in Ægyptum, et egressæ sunt de femore illius, absque uxoribus filiorum eius, sexaginta sex.

verses.textEn: Now the sons of Joseph, who were born to him in the land of Egypt, were two souls. All the souls of the house of Jacob, who went into Egypt, were seventy.
verses.textLa: Filii autem Ioseph, qui nati sunt ei in terra Ægypti, animæ duæ. Omnes animæ domus Iacob, quæ ingressæ sunt in Ægyptum, fuere septuaginta.

verses.textEn: Then he sent Judah ahead of himself, to Joseph, in order to report to him, and so that he would meet him in Goshen.
verses.textLa: Misit autem Iudam ante se ad Ioseph, ut nunciaret ei, et occurreret in Gessen.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived there, Joseph harnessed his chariot, and he went up to meet his father at the same place. And seeing him, he fell upon his neck, and, amid embraces, he wept.
verses.textLa: Quo cum pervenisset, iuncto Ioseph curro suo, ascendit obviam patri suo ad eumdem locum: vidensque eum, irruit super collum eius, et inter amplexus flevit.

verses.textEn: And the father said to Joseph, “Now I will die happy, because I have seen your face, and I am leaving you behind alive.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque pater ad Ioseph: Iam lætus moriar, quia vidi faciem tuam, et superstitem te relinquo.
verses.notes: Literally, ‘superstitem’ means ‘standing above.’ The term ‘super’ (above) is sometimes used in the Latin to indicate that someone is still alive.

verses.textEn: And he said to his brothers and to all his father’s house: “I will go up and report to Pharaoh, and I will say to him: ‘My brothers, and my father’s house, who were in the land of Canaan, have come to me.
verses.textLa: At ille locutus est ad fratres suos, et ad omnem domum patris sui: Ascendam, et nunciabo Pharaoni dicamque ei: Fratres mei, et domus patris mei, qui erant in Terra Chanaan, venerunt ad me:

verses.textEn: And these honorable men are pastors of sheep, and they have the task of feeding the flock. Their cattle, and herds, and all that they were able to hold, they have brought with them.’
verses.textLa: et sunt viri pastores ovium, curamque habent alendorum gregum: pecora sua, et armenta, et omnia quæ habere potuerunt, adduxerunt secum.
verses.notes: The word ‘viri’ is usually translated as ‘men,’ but it is derived from a Latin word referring to virtue or strength, so it can also be translated as ‘good men’ or ‘honorable men.’

verses.textEn: And when he will call you and will say, ‘What is your work?’
verses.textLa: Cumque vocaverit vos, et dixerit: Quod est opus vestrum?

verses.textEn: You will respond, ‘Your servants are pastors of honor, from our infancy even to the present time, both we and our fathers.’ Now you will say this so that you may be able to live in the land of Goshen, because the Egyptians detest all pastors of sheep.”
verses.textLa: Respondebitis: Viri pastores sumus servi tui, ab infantia nostra usque in præsens, et nos et patres nostri. Hæc autem dicetis, ut habitare possitis in Terra Gessen: quia detestantur Ægyptii omnes pastores ovium.
verses.notes: The word ‘viri’ can be genitive singular, as in ‘pastors of honor’ or ‘noble pastors,’ or, ‘pastors of virtue.’ Or it can be nominative plural, as in ‘We honorable men, your servants, are pastors.’

verses.textEn: And so Joseph entered and reported to Pharaoh, saying: “My father and brothers, their sheep and herds, and everything that they possess, have arrived from the land of Canaan. And behold, they stand together in the land of Goshen.”
verses.textLa: Ingressus ergo Ioseph nunciavit Pharaoni, dicens: Pater meus et fratres, oves eorum et armenta, et cuncta quæ possident, venerunt de Terra Chanaan: et ecce consistunt in Terra Gessen.

verses.textEn: Likewise, he stood in the sight of the king five men, the last of his brothers.
verses.textLa: Extremos quoque fratrum suorum quinque viros constituit coram rege:

verses.textEn: And he questioned them, “What do you have for work?” They responded: “Your servants are pastors of sheep, both we and our fathers.
verses.textLa: quos ille interrogavit: Quid habetis operis? Responderunt: Pastores ovium sumus servi tui, et nos, et patres nostri.

verses.textEn: We came to sojourn in your land, because there is no grass for the flocks of your servants, the famine being very grievous in the land of Canaan. And we petition you that you may order us, your servants, to be in the land of Goshen.”
verses.textLa: Ad peregrinandum in terra tua venimus: quoniam non est herba gregibus servorum tuorum, ingravescente fame in terra Chanaan: petimusque ut esse nos iubeas servos tuos in Terra Gessen.

verses.textEn: And so the king said to Joseph: “Your father and brothers have come to you.
verses.textLa: Dixit itaque rex ad Ioseph: Pater tuus et fratres tui venerunt ad te.

verses.textEn: The land of Egypt is in your sight. Cause them to live in the best place, and deliver to them the land of Goshen. And if you know there to be industrious men among them, appoint these as foremen over my cattle.”
verses.textLa: Terra Ægypti in conspectu tuo est: in optimo loco fac eos habitare, et trade eis Terram Gessen. Quod si nosti in eis esse viros industrios, constitue illos magistros pecorum meorum.

verses.textEn: After this, Joseph brought in his father to the king, and he stood him in his sight. He blessed him,
verses.textLa: Post hæc introduxit Ioseph patrem suum ad regem, et statuit eum coram eo: qui benedicens illi,

verses.textEn: and he questioned him: “How many are the days of the years of your life?”
verses.textLa: et interrogatus ab eo: Quot sunt dies annorum vitæ tuæ?

verses.textEn: He responded, “The days of my sojourn are one hundred and thirty years, few and unworthy, and they do not reach even to the days of the sojourning of my fathers.”
verses.textLa: Respondit: Dies peregrinationis meæ centum triginta annorum sunt, parvi et mali, et non pervenerunt usque ad dies patrum meorum quibus peregrinati sunt.

verses.textEn: And blessing the king, he went outside.
verses.textLa: Et benedicto rege, egressus est foras.

verses.textEn: Truly, Joseph gave his father and brothers a possession in Egypt, in the best place of the land, in Rameses, as Pharaoh had instructed.
verses.textLa: Ioseph vero patri et fratribus suis dedit possessionem in Ægypto in optimo terræ loco, Ramesses, ut præceperat Pharao.

verses.textEn: And he fed them, along with all his father’s house, providing portions of food to each one.
verses.textLa: Et alebat eos, omnemque domum patris sui, præbens cibaria singulis.

verses.textEn: For in the whole world there was a lack of bread, and a famine had oppressed the land, most of all Egypt and Canaan,
verses.textLa: In toto enim orbe panis deerat, et oppresserat fames terram, maxime Ægypti et Chanaan.

verses.textEn: from which he gathered together all the money for the grain that they bought, and he took it into the treasury of the king.
verses.textLa: E quibus omnem pecuniam congregavit pro venditione frumenti, et intulit eam in ærarium regis.

verses.textEn: And when the buyers had run out of money, all Egypt came to Joseph, saying: “Give us bread. Why should we die in your sight, lacking money?”
verses.textLa: Cumque defecisset emptoribus pretium, venit cuncta Ægyptus ad Ioseph, dicens: Da nobis panes: quare morimur coram te, deficiente pecunia?

verses.textEn: And he responded to them: “Bring me your cattle, and I will give food to you in exchange for them, if you do not have money.”
verses.textLa: Quibus ille respondit: Adducite pecora vestra, et dabo vobis pro eis cibos, si pretium non habetis.

verses.textEn: And when they had brought them, he gave them food for their horses, and sheep, and oxen, and donkeys. And he sustained them in that year in exchange for their cattle.
verses.textLa: Quæ cum adduxissent, dedit eis alimenta pro equis, et ovibus, et bobus, et asinis: sustentavitque eos illo anno pro commutatione pecorum.

verses.textEn: Likewise, they came the second year, and they said to him: “We will not conceal from our lord that our money is gone; likewise our cattle are gone. Neither are you unaware that we have nothing left but our bodies and our land.
verses.textLa: Venerunt quoque anno secundo, et dixerunt ei: Non celabimus dominum nostrum quod deficiente pecunia, pecora simul defecerunt: nec clam te est, quod absque corporibus et terra nihil habeamus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, why should you watch us die? Both we and our land will be yours. Buy us into royal servitude, but provide seed, lest by the dying off of cultivators the land be reduced to a wilderness.”
verses.textLa: Cur ergo moriemur te vidente? et nos et terra nostra tui erimus: eme nos in servitutem regiam, et præbe semina, ne pereunte cultore redigatur terra in solitudinem.
verses.notes: In this unusual situation, the people needed seed to grow crops. Ordinarily, they would save some seed from one crop in order to grow the next crop. But the famine was caused by an inability to grow crops, almost certainly due to a lack of rain. This drought would reduce the amount of crops that could be grown to the extent that they could not (or would not) save some seed for the next crop. The drought would also keep the Nile from flooding its banks (which would have provided water and rich soil for crops grown in the flood plain).

verses.textEn: Therefore, Joseph bought all the land of Egypt, each one selling his possessions because of the magnitude of the famine. And he subjected it to Pharaoh,
verses.textLa: Emit igitur Ioseph omnem Terram Ægypti, vendentibus singulis possessiones suas præ magnitudine famis. Subiecitque eam Pharaoni,

verses.textEn: along with all of its people, from the newest borders of Egypt, even to its furthest limits,
verses.textLa: et cunctos populos eius a novissimis terminis Ægypti usque ad extremos fines eius,

verses.textEn: except the land of the priests, which had been delivered to them by the king. To these also a portion of food was supplied out of the public storehouses, and, for this reason, they were not compelled to sell their possessions.
verses.textLa: præter terram sacerdotum, quæ a rege tradita fuerat eis: quibus et statuta cibaria ex horreis publicis præbebantur, et idcirco non sunt compulsi vendere possessiones suas.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Joseph said to the people: “So, as you discern, both you and your lands are possessed by Pharaoh; take seed and sow the fields,
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Ioseph ad populos: En ut cernitis, et vos et terram vestram Pharao possidet: accipite semina, et serite agros,

verses.textEn: so that you may be able to have grain. One fifth part you will give to the king; the remaining four I permit to you, as seed and as food for your families and children.
verses.textLa: ut fruges habere possitis. Quintam partem regi dabitis: quatuor reliquas permitto vobis in sementem, et in cibum familiis et liberis vestris.

verses.textEn: And they responded: “Our health is in your hand; only let our lord look kindly upon us, and we will serve the king with gladness.”
verses.textLa: Qui responderunt: Salus nostra in manu tua est: respiciat nos tantum dominus noster, et læti serviemus regi.

verses.textEn: From that time, even to the present day, in the entire land of Egypt, the fifth part is turned over to the kings, and it has become like a law, except in the land of the priests, which was free from this condition.
verses.textLa: Ex eo tempore usque in præsentem diem in universa terra Ægypti regibus quinta pars solvitur, et factum est quasi in legem, absque terra sacerdotali, quæ libera ab hac conditione fuit.

verses.textEn: And so, Israel lived in Egypt, that is, in the land of Goshen, and he possessed it. And he increased and was multiplied exceedingly.
verses.textLa: Habitavit ergo Israel in Ægypto, id est, in Terra Gessen, et possedit eam: auctusque est, et multiplicatus nimis.

verses.textEn: And he lived in it seventeen years. And all the days of his life that passed were one hundred and forty-seven years.
verses.textLa: Et vixit in ea decem et septem annis: factique sunt omnes dies vitæ illius centum quadraginta septem annorum.

verses.textEn: And when he discerned that the day of his death was approaching, he called his son Joseph, and he said to him: “If I have found favor in your sight, place your hand under my thigh. And you shall show me mercy and truth, not to bury me in Egypt.
verses.textLa: Cumque appropinquare cerneret diem mortis suæ, vocavit filium suum Ioseph, et dixit ad eum: Si inveni gratiam in conspectu tuo, pone manum tuam sub femore meo: et facies mihi misericordiam et veritatem, ut non sepelias me in Ægypto:

verses.textEn: But I shall sleep with my fathers, and you will carry me from this land and bury me in the sepulcher of my ancestors.” And Joseph answered him, “I will do what you have ordered.”
verses.textLa: sed dormiam cum patribus meis, et auferas me de terra hac, condasque in sepulchro maiorum meorum. Cui respondit Ioseph: Ego faciam quod iussisti.

verses.textEn: And he said, “Then swear it to me.” And as he was swearing, Israel adored God, turning to the head of his resting place.
verses.textLa: Et ille: Iura ergo, inquit, mihi. Quo iurante, adoravit Israel Deum, conversus ad lectuli caput.

verses.textEn: After these things were done, it was reported to Joseph that his father was sick. And taking his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim, he went directly to him.
verses.textLa: His ita transactis, nunciatum est Ioseph quod ægrotaret pater suus: qui, assumptis duobus filiis Manasse et Ephraim, ire perrexit.

verses.textEn: And it was told to the old man, “Behold, your son Joseph is coming to you.” And being strengthened, he sat up in bed.
verses.textLa: Dictumque est seni: Ecce filius tuus Ioseph venit ad te. Qui confortatus sedit in lectulo.

verses.textEn: And when he had entered to him, he said: “Almighty God appeared to me at Luz, which is in the land of Canaan, and he blessed me.
verses.textLa: Et ingresso ad se ait: Deus omnipotens apparuit mihi in Luza, quæ est in Terra Chanaan: benedixitque mihi,

verses.textEn: And he said: ‘I will increase and multiply you, and I will make you influential among the people. And I will give this land to you, and to your offspring after you, as an everlasting possession.’
verses.textLa: et ait: Ego te augebo et multiplicabo, et faciam te in turbas populorum: daboque tibi terram hanc, et semini tuo post te in possessionem sempiternam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, your two sons, who were born to you in the land of Egypt before I came here to you, will be mine. Ephraim and Manasseh will be treated by me just like Reuben and Simeon.
verses.textLa: Duo ergo filii tui, qui nati sunt tibi in Terra Ægypti, antequam huc venirem ad te, mei erunt: Ephraim et Manasses, sicut Ruben et Simeon reputabuntur mihi.

verses.textEn: But the remainder, whom you will conceive after them, will be yours, and they will be called by the name of their brothers among their possessions.
verses.textLa: Reliquos autem quos genueris post eos, tui erunt, et nomine fratrum suorum vocabuntur in possessionibus suis.

verses.textEn: As for me, when I came from Mesopotamia, Rachel died in the land of Canaan on the very journey, and it was springtime. And I entered Ephrath and buried her next to the way of Ephrath, which by another name is called Bethlehem.”
verses.textLa: Mihi enim, quando veniebam de Mesopotamia, mortua est Rachel in terra Chanaan in ipso itinere, eratque vernum tempus: et ingrediebar Ephratam, et sepelivi eam iuxta viam Ephratæ, quæ alio nomine appellatur Bethlehem.

verses.textEn: Then, seeing his sons, he said to him: “Who are these?”
verses.textLa: Videns autem filios eius dixit ad eum: Qui sunt isti?

verses.textEn: He responded, “They are my sons, whom God gave to me as a gift in this place.” “Bring them to me,” he said, “so that I may bless them.”
verses.textLa: Respondit: Filii mei sunt, quos donavit mihi Deus in hoc loco. Adduc, inquit, eos ad me, ut benedicam illis.

verses.textEn: For Israel’s eyes were clouded by reason of his great age, and he was unable to see clearly. And when they were placed up against him, he kissed and embraced them.
verses.textLa: Oculi enim Israel caligabant præ nimia senectute, et clare videre non poterat. Applicitosque ad se, deosculatus et circumplexus eos,

verses.textEn: And he said to his son: “I have not been cheated out of seeing you. Moreover, God has shown me your offspring.”
verses.textLa: dixit ad filium suum: Non sum fraudatus aspectu tuo: insuper ostendit mihi Deus semen tuum.

verses.textEn: And when Joseph had taken them from his father’s lap, he reverenced prone on the ground.
verses.textLa: Cumque tulisset eos Ioseph de gremio patris, adoravit pronus in terram.

verses.textEn: And he placed Ephraim on his right, that is, towards the left hand of Israel. Yet truly Manasseh was on his left, namely, towards his father’s right hand. And he placed them both up against him.
verses.textLa: Et posuit Ephraim ad dexteram suam, id est, ad sinistram Israel: Manassen vero in sinistra sua, ad dexteram scilicet patris, applicuitque ambos ad eum.

verses.textEn: And he, extending his right hand, placed it over the head of Ephraim, the younger brother, but the left hand was on the head of Manasseh, who was the elder, so that his hands were crossed.
verses.textLa: Qui extendens manum dexteram, posuit super caput Ephraim minoris fratris: sinistram autem super caput Manasse qui maior natu erat, commutans manus.

verses.textEn: And Jacob blessed the sons of Joseph, and he said: “God, in whose sight my fathers, Abraham and Isaac, walked; God, who pastured me from my youth until the present day;
verses.textLa: Benedixitque Iacob filiis Ioseph, et ait: Deus, in cuius conspectu ambulaverunt patres mei Abraham, et Isaac, Deus qui pascit me ab adolescentia mea usque in præsentem diem:

verses.textEn: the Angel, who rescues me from all evils: bless these boys. And let my name be invoked over them, and also the names of my fathers, Abraham and Isaac. And may they increase into a multitude across the earth.”
verses.textLa: Angelus, qui eruit me de cunctis malis, benedicat pueris istis: et invocetur super eos nomen meum, nomina quoque patrum meorum Abraham, et Isaac, et crescant in multitudinem super terram.

verses.textEn: But Joseph, seeing that his father had placed his right hand over the head of Ephraim, took it gravely. And grasping his father’s hand, he tried to lift it from Ephraim’s head and transfer it onto the head of Manasseh.
verses.textLa: Videns autem Ioseph quod posuisset pater suus dexteram manum super caput Ephraim, graviter accepit: et apprehensam manum patris levare conatus est de capite Ephraim, et transferre super caput Manasse.

verses.textEn: And he said to his father: “It should not have come to pass this way, father. For this one is the firstborn. Place your right hand over his head.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad patrem: Non ita convenit, pater: quia hic est primogenitus, pone dexteram tuam super caput eius.

verses.textEn: But refusing, he said: “I know, my son, I know. And this one, indeed, will be among the people and will be multiplied. But his younger brother will be greater than he. And his offspring will increase among the nations.”
verses.textLa: Qui renuens, ait: Scio fili mi, scio: et iste quidem erit in populos, et multiplicabitur: sed frater eius minor, maior erit illo: et semen illius crescet in gentes.

verses.textEn: And he blessed them at that time, saying: “In you, Israel will be blessed, and it will be said: ‘May God treat you like Ephraim, and like Manasseh.’ ” And he established Ephraim before Manasseh.
verses.textLa: Benedixitque eis in tempore illo, dicens: In te benedicetur Israel, atque dicetur: Faciat tibi Deus sicut Ephraim, et sicut Manasse. Constituitque Ephraim ante Manassen.

verses.textEn: And he said to his son Joseph: “See, I am dying, and God will be with you, and he will lead you back to the land of your fathers.
verses.textLa: Et ait ad Ioseph filium suum: En ego morior, et erit Deus vobiscum, reducetque vos ad terram patrum vestrorum.

verses.textEn: I give you one part beyond that of your brothers, which I took from the hand of the Amorite with my sword and my bow.”
verses.textLa: Do tibi partem unam extra fratres tuos, quam tuli de manu Amorrhæi in gladio et arcu meo.

verses.textEn: Then Jacob called his sons, and he said to them: “Gather together, so that I may announce what will happen to you in the last days.
verses.textLa: Vocavit autem Iacob filios suos, et ait eis: Congregamini, ut annunciem quæ ventura sunt vobis in diebus novissimis.
verses.notes: This passage is the eschatological discourse of Jacob. It describes the state of the twelve parts of the one Catholic Church prior to the Return of Christ. Currently, the Church as two parts, east and west. After the unification of all the Christian Churches in one Catholic Church (in the early 2020’s), there will be seven parts within the one Church. Much later, these seven will become twelve parts of one Church, like the twelve tribes of Israel. It is these twelve tribes of the future Church that Jacob describes on his death bed.

verses.textEn: Gather together and listen, O sons of Jacob. Listen to Israel, your father.
verses.textLa: Congregamini, et audite filii Iacob, audite Israel patrem vestrum:

verses.textEn: Reuben, my firstborn, you are my strength and the beginning of my sorrow: first in gifts, greater in authority.
verses.textLa: Ruben primogenitus meus, tu fortitudo mea, et principium doloris mei: prior in donis, maior in imperio.

verses.textEn: You are being poured out like water, may you not increase. For you climbed onto your father’s bed, and you defiled his resting place.
verses.textLa: Effusus es sicut aqua, non crescas: quia ascendisti cubile patris tui, et maculasti stratum eius.

verses.textEn: The brothers Simeon and Levi: vessels of iniquity waging war.
verses.textLa: Simeon et Levi fratres: vasa iniquitatis bellantia.

verses.textEn: Let not my soul go by their counsel, nor my glory be within their meeting. For in their fury they killed a man, and in their self-will they undermined a wall.
verses.textLa: In consilium eorum non veniat anima mea, et in cœtu illorum non sit gloria mea: quia in furore suo occiderunt virum, et in voluntate sua suffoderunt murum.

verses.textEn: Cursed be their fury, because it was obstinate, and their indignation, because it was harsh. I will divide them in Jacob, and I will scatter them in Israel.
verses.textLa: Maledictus furor eorum, quia pertinax: et indignatio eorum, quia dura: dividam eos in Iacob, et dispergam eos in Israel.

verses.textEn: Judah, your brothers will praise you. Your hand will be at the necks of your enemies; the sons of your father will reverence you.
verses.textLa: Iuda, te laudabunt fratres tui: manus tua in cervicibus inimicorum tuorum, adorabunt te filii patris tui.

verses.textEn: Judah is a lion’s young. You have gone up to the prey, my son. While resting, you have lain like a lion. And just like a lioness, who would rouse him?
verses.textLa: Catulus leonis Iuda: ad prædam fili mi ascendisti: requiescens accubuisti ut leo, et quasi leæna, quis suscitabit eum?

verses.textEn: The scepter from Judah and the leader from his thigh will not be taken away, until he who will be sent arrives, and he will be the expectation of Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Non auferetur sceptrum de Iuda, et dux de femore eius, donec veniat qui mittendus est, et ipse erit expectatio Gentium.

verses.textEn: Tying his young colt to the vineyard, and his donkey, O my son, to the vine, he will wash his robe in wine, and his cloak in the blood of the grape.
verses.textLa: Ligans ad vineam pullum suum, et ad vitem, o fili mi, asinam suam. Lavabit in vino stolam suam, et in sanguine uvæ pallium suum.

verses.textEn: His eyes are more beautiful than wine, and his teeth whiter than milk.
verses.textLa: Pulchriores sunt oculi eius vino, et dentes eius lacte candidiores.

verses.textEn: Zebulun will live at the seashore and by the outpost of ships, reaching as far as Sidon.
verses.textLa: Zabulon in littore maris habitabit, et in statione navium pertingens usque ad Sidonem.

verses.textEn: Issachar will be a strong donkey, reclining between the borders.
verses.textLa: Issachar asinus fortis accubans inter terminos.

verses.textEn: He saw that rest would be good, and that the land was excellent. And so he bent his shoulder to carry, and he became a servant under tribute.
verses.textLa: Vidit requiem quod esset bona: et terram quod optima: et supposuit humerum suum ad portandum, factusque est tributis serviens.

verses.textEn: Dan will judge his people just like any other tribe in Israel.
verses.textLa: Dan iudicabit populum suum sicut et alia tribus in Israel.

verses.textEn: Let Dan be a snake in the way, a viper in the path, biting the hooves of horses, so that his rider may fall backward.
verses.textLa: Fiat Dan coluber in via, cerastes in semita, mordens ungulas equi, ut cadat ascensor eius retro.
verses.notes: A ‘cerastes’ is a type of viper found in Africa, very poisonous and with a horn-like protuberance above each eye.

verses.textEn: I will wait for your salvation, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Salutare tuum expectabo Domine.

verses.textEn: Gad, being girded, will fight before him. And he himself will be girded backward.
verses.textLa: Gad, accinctus præliabatur ante eum: et ipse accingetur retrorsum.

verses.textEn: Asher: his bread will be fat, and he will provide delicacies to the kings.
verses.textLa: Aser, pinguis panis eius, et præbebit delicias regibus.

verses.textEn: Naphtali is a stag sent forth, offering words of eloquent beauty.
verses.textLa: Nephthali, cervus emissus, et dans eloquia pulchritudinis.

verses.textEn: Joseph is a growing son, a growing son and stately to behold; the daughters run back and forth on the wall.
verses.textLa: Filius accrescens Ioseph, filius accrescens et decorus aspectu: filiæ discurrerunt super murum.

verses.textEn: But those who held darts, provoked him, and they contend with him, and they envied him.
verses.textLa: Sed exasperaverunt eum, et iurgati sunt, invideruntque illi habentes iacula.

verses.textEn: His bow sits in strength, and the bands of his arms and hands have been let loose by the hands of the mighty one of Jacob. From there he went forth as a pastor, the stone of Israel.
verses.textLa: Sedit in forti arcus eius, et dissoluta sunt vincula brachiorum et manuum illius per manus potentis Iacob: inde pastor egressus est lapis Israel.

verses.textEn: The God of your father will be your helper, and the Almighty will bless you with the blessings of heaven above, with the blessings of the abyss that lies beneath, with the blessings of the breasts and of the womb.
verses.textLa: Deus patris tui erit adiutor tuus, et omnipotens benedicet tibi benedictionibus cæli desuper, benedictionibus abyssi iacentis deorsum, benedictionibus uberum et vulvæ.

verses.textEn: The blessings of your father are strengthened by the blessings of his fathers, until the desire of the hills of eternity shall arrive. May they be at the head of Joseph, and at the summit of the Nazarite, among his brothers.
verses.textLa: Benedictiones patris tui confortatæ sunt benedictionibus patrum eius: donec veniret desiderium collium æternorum: fiant in capite Ioseph, et in vertice Nazaræi inter fratres suos.

verses.textEn: Benjamin is a ravenous wolf, in the morning he will eat the prey, and in the evening he will divide the spoil.”
verses.textLa: Beniamin lupus rapax, mane comedat prædam, et vespere dividet spolia.

verses.textEn: All these are the twelve tribes of Israel. These things their father spoke to them, and he blessed each one with their proper blessings.
verses.textLa: Omnes hi in tribubus Israel duodecim: hæc locutus est eis pater suus, benedixitque singulis benedictionibus propriis.

verses.textEn: And he instructed them, saying: “I am being gathered to my people. Bury me with my fathers in the double cave, which is in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
verses.textLa: Et præcepit eis, dicens: Ego congregor ad populum meum: sepelite me cum patribus meis in spelunca duplici quæ est in agro Ephron Hethæi,

verses.textEn: opposite Mamre, in the land of Canaan, which Abraham bought, along with its field, from Ephron the Hittite, as a possession for burial.
verses.textLa: contra Mambre in Terra Chanaan, quam emit Abraham cum agro ab Ephron Hethæo in possessionem sepulchri.

verses.textEn: There they buried him, with his wife Sarah.” And there Isaac was buried with his wife Rebekah. There also Leah lies preserved.
verses.textLa: Ibi sepelierunt eum, et Saram uxorem eius: ibi sepultus est Isaac cum Rebecca coniuge sua: ibi et Lia condita iacet.

verses.textEn: And having finished these commands by which he instructed his sons, he drew his feet onto the bed, and he passed away. And he was gathered to his people.
verses.textLa: Finitisque mandatis quibus filios instruebat, collegit pedes suos super lectulum, et obiit: appositusque est ad populum suum.

verses.textEn: Joseph, realizing this, fell upon his father’s face, weeping and kissing him.
verses.textLa: Quod cernens Ioseph, ruit super faciem patris flens et deosculans eum.

verses.textEn: And he instructed his servant physicians to embalm his father with aromatics.
verses.textLa: Præcepitque servis suis medicis ut aromatibus condirent patrem.

verses.textEn: And while they were fulfilling his orders, forty days passed. For this was the method of embalming dead bodies. And Egypt wept for him for seventy days.
verses.textLa: Quibus iussa explentibus, transierunt quadraginta dies: iste quippe mos erat cadaverum conditorum. Flevitque eum Ægyptus septuaginta diebus.

verses.textEn: And when the time for mourning was fulfilled, Joseph spoke to the family of Pharaoh: “If I have found favor in your sight, speak to the ears of Pharaoh.
verses.textLa: Et expleto planctus tempore, locutus est Ioseph ad familiam Pharaonis: Si inveni gratiam in conspectu vestro, loquimini in auribus Pharaonis:

verses.textEn: For my father made me swear, saying: ‘See, I am dying. You shall bury me in my sepulcher which I dug for myself in the land of Canaan.’ Therefore, I shall go up and bury my father, and then return.”
verses.textLa: eo quod pater meus adiuraverit me, dicens: En morior, in sepulchro meo quod fodi mihi in terra Chanaan, sepelies me. Ascendam igitur, et sepeliam patrem meum, ac revertar.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh said to him, “Go up and bury your father, just as he made you swear.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ei Pharao: Ascende et sepeli patrem tuum sicut adiuratus es.

verses.textEn: So as he went up, all the elders of the house of Pharaoh went with him, along with every patriarch in the land of Egypt,
verses.textLa: Quo ascendente, ierunt cum eo omnes senes domus Pharaonis, cunctique maiores natu Terræ Ægypti:

verses.textEn: and the house of Joseph with his brothers, except their little ones and flocks and also the herds, which they left behind in the land of Goshen.
verses.textLa: domus Ioseph cum fratribus suis, absque parvulis et gregibus, atque armentis quæ dereliquerant in Terra Gessen.

verses.textEn: Likewise, he had in his company chariots and horsemen. And it became a crowd without restraint.
verses.textLa: Habuit quoque in comitatu currus et equites: et facta est turba non modica.

verses.textEn: And they arrived at the threshing place of Atad, which is situated beyond the Jordan. There they spent seven full days celebrating the funeral rites with a great and vehement lamentation.
verses.textLa: Veneruntque ad Aream Atad, quæ sita est trans Iordanem: ubi celebrantes exequias planctu magno atque vehementi, impleverunt septem dies.

verses.textEn: And when the inhabitants of the land of Canaan had seen this, they said, “This is a great Lamentation for the Egyptians.” And for this reason, the name of that place was called, “The Lamentation of Egypt.”
verses.textLa: Quod cum vidissent habitatores Terræ Chanaan, dixerunt: Planctus magnus est iste Ægyptiis. Et idcirco vocatum est nomen loci illius, Planctus Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And so, the sons of Jacob did just as he had instructed them.
verses.textLa: Fecerunt ergo filii Iacob sicut præceperat eis:

verses.textEn: And carrying him into the land of Canaan, they buried him in the double cave, which Abraham had bought along with its field, from Ephron the Hittite, as a possession for burial, opposite Mamre.
verses.textLa: Et portantes eum in Terram Chanaan, sepelierunt eum in spelunca duplici, quam emerat Abraham cum agro in possessionem sepulchri ab Ephron Hethæo contra faciem Mambre.

verses.textEn: And Joseph returned into Egypt with his brothers and all those of his company, having buried his father.
verses.textLa: Reversusque est Ioseph in Ægyptum cum fratribus suis, et omni comitatu, sepulto patre.

verses.textEn: Now that he was dead, his brothers were afraid, and they said to one another: “Perhaps now he may remember the injury that he suffered and requite us for all the evil that we did to him.”
verses.textLa: Quo mortuo, timentes fratres eius, et mutuo colloquentes: Ne forte memor sit iniuriæ quam passus est, et reddat nobis omne malum quod fecimus,

verses.textEn: So they sent a message to him, saying: “Your father instructed us before he died,
verses.textLa: mandaverunt ei dicentes: Pater tuus præcepit nobis antequam moreretur,

verses.textEn: that we should say these words to you from him: ‘I beg you to forget the wickedness of your brothers, and the sin and malice that they practiced against you.’ Likewise, we petition you to release the servants of the God of your father from this iniquity.” Hearing this, Joseph wept.
verses.textLa: ut hæc tibi verbis illius diceremus: Obsecro ut obliviscaris sceleris fratrum tuorum, et peccati atque malitiæ quam exercuerunt in te: nos quoque oramus ut servis Dei patris tui dimittas iniquitatem hanc. Quibus auditis flevit Ioseph.

verses.textEn: And his brothers went to him. And reverencing prostrate on the ground, they said, “We are your servants.”
verses.textLa: Veneruntque ad eum fratres sui: et proni adorantes in terram dixerunt: Servi tui sumus.

verses.textEn: And he answered them: “Do not be afraid. Are we able to resist the will of God?
verses.textLa: Quibus ille respondit: Nolite timere: num Dei possumus resistere voluntati?

verses.textEn: You devised evil against me. But God turned it into good, so that he might exalt me, just as you presently discern, and so that he might bring about the salvation of many peoples.
verses.textLa: Vos cogitastis de me malum: sed Deus vertit illud in bonum, ut exaltaret me, sicut in præsentiarum cernitis, et salvos faceret multos populos.

verses.textEn: Do not be afraid. I will pasture you and your little ones.” And he consoled them, and he spoke mildly and leniently.
verses.textLa: Nolite timere: ego pascam vos et parvulos vestros. Consolatusque est eos, et blande ac leniter est locutus.

verses.textEn: And he lived in Egypt with all his father’s house; and he survived for one hundred and ten years. And he saw the sons of Ephraim to the third generation. Likewise, the sons of Machir, the son of Manasseh, were born onto Joseph’s knees.
verses.textLa: Et habitavit in Ægypto cum omni domo patris sui: vixitque centum decem annis. Et vidit Ephraim filios usque ad tertiam generationem. Filii quoque Machir filii Manasse nati sunt in genibus Ioseph.

verses.textEn: After these things happened, he said to his brothers: “God will visit you after my death, and he will make you ascend from this land into the land which he swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”
verses.textLa: Quibus transactis, locutus est fratribus suis: Post mortem meam Deus visitabit vos, et ascendere vos faciet de terra ista ad terram quam iuravit Abraham, Isaac, et Iacob.

verses.textEn: And when he had made them swear and had said, “God will visit you; carry my bones with you from this place,”
verses.textLa: Cumque adiurasset eos atque dixisset: Deus visitabit vos: asportate ossa mea vobiscum de loco isto:

verses.textEn: he died, having completed one hundred and ten years of his life. And having been embalmed with aromatics, he was laid to rest in a coffin in Egypt.
verses.textLa: mortuus est, expletis centum decem vitæ suæ annis. Et conditus aromatibus, repositus est in loculo in Ægypto.
